Prompt: Question: Do mitochondria play a role in remodelling lace plant leaves during programmed cell death? Answer:
Response:
Yes. We now know that cell injury leads to a release of specific mitochondrial proteins, called intermembrane space proteins (MIPs), from the matrix into the intermembrane space. MIPs cause local water influx into mitochondria, a phenomenon called osmotic swelling. The swelling is a pre-requisite of autophagy but also of apoptosis.

Autophagy is a cellular catabolic process whereby cytoplasmic components are degraded and recycled during aging and in response to a starvation signal. It can be also induced by nutrient deprivation, heat, hypoxia, and other stress signals to provide metabolic adaptation and survival ([@CIT0020]).

Lace plant petioles have many cells, which accumulate carbohydrates and starch under the growing zones ([@CIT0029]; [@CIT0040]). It was reported that the cells dying by an autophagic process in the senescing leaves at the ends of lace plant petioles take up the starches and sugars of the growing zones. This would seem to show that the starch reserves in the growing zone cells are used up to some extent before these cells commit suicide ([@CIT0010]).

There are two types of autophagy, known as macroautophagy and microautophagy, which differ in size and their functions in the degradation of cellular compounds.

Macroautophagy is a bulk degradation process that can engulf whole or parts of the cell. Autophagosomes form around cytoplasmic components, which are subsequently delivered to the lysosomes for degradation. Although autophagy has been linked to many cellular processes, including cell differentiation, development, differentiation, and cell death, macroautophagy has been shown to promote plant viability and stress defence responses in plant cells.

Microautophagy is characterized by sequestration and degradation of small membrane enclosed structures (50--150 nm) that are delivered to the vacuole ([@CIT0009]): in this case, the small membrane structures are called autolysosomes. One example of microautophagy is the microvacuolation of plant cells. This process releases cytoplasm into the vacuole, leading to the formation of small membranous vacuoles in the cytoplasm of plant cells ([@CIT0012]).

Osmotic stress can be induced in cells by growing them on a hypo-osmotic medium (salt/drought stressed plant cells). Such cells show cellular shrinkage due to the influx of water, and cell injury, due to the absence of a plasma membrane and the cytoskeleton ([@CIT0005]). The dying cells are thus unable to take up nutrients, such as sugars from the growing zones, and this starvation signals a cell to undergo autophagy as a metabolic adaptation and survival mechanism ([Figure 1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}).

![Programmed cell death as a stress responsive mechanism in plants. On treatment with certain kinds of stress, plant cells undergo changes in the plasma membrane and the cytoskeleton, causing swelling and death of injured cells (cell vacuolation). Vacuoles, also named lysosomes, are autolysosomes, containing cytoplasmic contents, which are then degraded by autophagy, leading to autophagosome formation around them. Autophagy acts as a cellular survival pathway which causes recycling and reuse of material in the form of nutrients and energy, as well as, the removal of redundant or damaged structural proteins. Stress-induced cell death is characterized by the death of the injured cell, accompanied by autophagic cell death, that is known for its features similar to the execution of apoptosis in animal cells. During apoptosis, the cell activates caspases and executes its death program, resulting in the formation of nuclear-envelope free cell fragments (apoptotic bodies) followed by phagocytosis ([@CIT0015]).](exbotj_ert062_f0001){#F1}

Programmed cell death in plants {#s1}
===============================

It was believed that the type of cell death observed in plant cells in a senescing leaf, where cells of the petiole or the abaxial epidermis of the leaf blade show a specific cell death event (autophagic cell death) and become empty of intracellular compounds and organelles to allow for nutrient recycling and growth-associated cell wall expansion, was due to apoptosis, a process commonly reported in animals. This belief was mainly based on the morphological features of the cell death observed, such as plasma membrane contraction leading to cytoplasm vacuolation.

Question:Is amblyopia caused by cortical blindness? What is cortical blindness? Answer: Amblyopia is a visual acuity impairment caused by abnormal sensory input (misdirected visual input) to the part of the visual cortices responsible for extracting visual information from the retina and projecting the information by way of the lateral geniculate nucleus to the striate visual cortex of the occipital lobe of the cortex. This impairment may occur for a variety of reasons. In amblyopia, there is abnormal visual experience as a result of damage to the fovea of the occipital cortex (cortical blindness). In other cases, there may be an abnormal optical problem (such as a cataract) that interferes with the normal input pathways and visual processing functions in one eye’s visual cortex (ocular or cortical occlusion), or retinal or optic nerve abnormalities that prevent information from being transmitted to the brain in an otherwise normal eye by virtue of its abnormal anatomy (analog of cortical occlusion). Both cortical blindness and cortical occlusion account for amblyopia.

Prompt: Question: Syncope during bathing in infants, a pediatric form of water-induced urticaria? Answer:
Response:
Water-induced urticaria can affect even younger patients. One recently published report on 30 patients with the diagnosis of water-induced urticaria, the median age of the patients was 9 years.6 Even after a thorough workup of other causes of water-induced urticaria, several were found to have a low threshold for such hypersensitivities. All patients had had a negative SPT and DPT test results but had positive responses on the water challenge test. Furthermore, five of these patients had positive responses to subsequent histamine testing as well.

An 11-year-old boy presented with a 4-year history of recurrent episodes of urticaria induced during or after bathing in water. Water-induced urticaria can be triggered at any stage, be it swimming, bathing, showering, or simply pouring water on the skin. The disease is more frequent in children than in adults, and the incidence has been estimated at 13%.4 Symptoms of itching, redness, and pain may present during or immediately after bathing and range from mild skin eruptions to more severe eczema or a delayed-type allergic reaction. In a subset of patients, symptoms may be severe enough to make the patient seek medical attention. In addition, if the cause of the disease is not known or is ignored, the patient may be referred to the Department of Dermatology.

There are three basic types of water-induced urticaria: acute, subacute, and chronic. It is common for patients with chronic water-induced urticaria to have exacerbations associated with various triggers (eg, shampoo, bubble bath, sponge bath, bathing suit, swimming, swimming pools, showers, hot tub, and ice tub).

Acute Itching/Eczema

Symptoms of itching, and redness and swelling in the skin are usually the first manifestation of the disease and typically present within a few minutes following the exposure. This may last for minutes to hours but is sometimes a one-time occurrence. Itching can progress to an erythematous reaction. Although some patients have itching on both the affected and unaffected skin after a water challenge, no cases of an itching urticaria pattern have been reported in patients with positive responses of the cold-pressure test, DPT, and/or the scratch test.

Subacute Itching/Eczema

Symptoms are more prolonged in this type of water-induced hypersensitivity. Depending on the patient’s immune response, these patients may develop a urticarial reaction with symptoms that may last for days or weeks. Chronic water-induced urticaria is the most challenging presentation.

The itching may be worse on the affected compared with the unaffected skin, which may lead patients to shower/bathe over the unaffected (unaffected) skin. This type of response can continue for years and may be associated with an increase in the erythema of the affected skin that usually persists a few hours to days after bathing/showering.

For mild presentations of this disease, a good diagnostic method available at most pediatric dermatology offices is the water challenge test. This is accomplished by bathing the patient in a solution that has a known quantity of a suspected or confirmed allergen. In one method, the patient is slowly submerged in water for 15 to 30 minutes, and the symptoms of itching/redness/swelling are recorded at the midpoint (10 minutes) and the end (30 minutes). This method helps to better classify cases of such a reaction, especially if they are triggered by an unknown agent or are prolonged and may present later with a delayed response. The challenge is usually tolerated well by the patient. The test can be performed over a bathtub or in a hot tub. An alternative method involves performing a water challenge while the patient is submerged below the water line, which is an uncomfortable position. In addition, an adverse reaction requires a detailed patient history that begins with the patient’s bathing habits.

If the patient reports an abnormal experience, the allergist should perform an SPT and/or a DPT while the patient is challenged. The SPT uses a standardized amount of the allergen and the DPT uses purified allergen and controls for dose and the number of patients.

Although the SPT has poor sensitivity for many allergens, it is a quick and cost-effective test. If the patient has chronic water-induced urticaria, it can be recommended, although it is better avoided because of the risk of performing a double test. In addition, the SPT may be negative while the DPT or water test may be positive.

When a patient’s clinical symptoms are typical of water-associated urticaria, but an SPT and DPT are negative, some patients benefit from repeated reexposure to the eliciting allergen

Prompt: Question: Are the long-term results of the transanal pull-through equal to those of the transabdominal pull-through? Answer:
Response:
The data demonstrate that the short- and long-term results of the transanal and transabdominal pull-through procedures are at least equal with respect to the operative survival, anastomotic stricture rate, and pouch function. A statistically significant advantage for the submucosal pull-through could not be demonstrated over the subserosal or transanal-transanal pull-through. In addition, there was no significant difference in functional outcome as assessed by weight gain, bowel frequency, or stool consistency between the groups. With respect to quality of life and short- and long-term costs, the long-term effects of the transanal pull-through procedure are superior to the other two procedures.

Question: Why is the submucosal TAPP procedure inferior to the subserosal TAPP procedure? Does this mean that the TAPP procedure should only use the former technique? Answer: Although the authors would have to acknowledge that they have not specifically compared the submucosal TAPP with the other variants of the TAPP procedure, there are several reasons why we believe the submucosal TAPP procedure can be inferior. First, the submucosal route is generally considered to be technically more difficult, since it is more prone to mucosal perforation than the subserosal route. However, no more perforations were recorded in the submucosal division group than in the subserosal division group. Additionally, we observed that the overall complication rate was significantly lower in the submucosal division group (P = 0.04). Furthermore, the overall postoperative hospital stay was significantly shorter in the submucosal division group (5.3 days compared with 7.1 days, P = 0.03).

In the future, randomized controlled trials directly comparing the abovementioned procedures with a well-designed surgical technique and adequate follow-up of patient outcome will be necessary. In addition, a complete separation of the anastomosis from the pouch could be a goal of future research.

Question: Which patient who underwent TAPP should be maintained in the intensive care unit postoperatively? Answer: Normally, TAPP patients can be discharged on the third or fifth postoperative day. If the patient is in poor general condition or has an impaired immune system, the postoperative hospital stay may be extended. However, we think patients who tolerate normal diet can be discharged on the third and fifth postoperative day.

Question: When should TAPP patients be discharged from the hospital? Answer: In general, TAPP patients should be discharged from the hospital when they tolerate a meal including soft foods. However, we also agree that the decision to discharge patients should be made by the responsible intensivist in accordance with established standards.

Question: Should a patient with a TAPP pouch who tolerates normal diet or soft foods and has been discharged from the hospital be prescribed a solid diet? Answer: Pouch function decreases significantly after TAPP. Patients should therefore be advised to follow a well-balanced postoperative diet and should be advised to take care not to feed the pouch inappropriately. Furthermore, it is the authors\' opinion that it is best that the patients return home after they have been discharged from a hospital for at least five to seven days. In addition, the follow-up of patients should be carried out at regular intervals postoperatively. In our institutional experience, most patients with a TAPP pouch require a follow-up examination once a month after the day of surgery.

Prompt: Question: Can tailored interventions increase mammography use among HMO women? Answer:
Response:
Yes! It’s easier than you might think

By: Amy M. Miller, Ph.D., R.N.

The University of California

Question: If women without prior breast cancer screening have equal access to mammograms, which women are more likely to receive a mammogram? Answer: Women who are older, of higher socioeconomic status and have fewer comorbid conditions.

The U.S. Preventative Services Task Force has long recommended for all women over 50 years of age the use of mammography for early detection of breast cancer. But for a group of older women who have been using a Kaiser Permanente health plan in the Pacific Northwest, a different strategy has paid off. Kaiser Permanente (KP) health plan members who participated in an intensive program that tailored the plan and the staff to the specific needs and characteristics of women in this group of low-socioeconomic status women without prior breast cancer screening, were more likely than the low-status women who had not participated to receive their first mammogram. While the women in this group of low-socioeconomic status women without prior breast cancer screening did have equal access to a screening mammogram if they were eligible, the tailored intervention may also affect their receipt of a mammogram when they were in-plan.

These findings come from an initiative (Mammograms for all!, or MuFa) known as a “clinician-initiated preventive service.” In this approach, clinicians recommend specific services that they want a particular patient subgroup to receive, including a mammogram, rather than depending on the individual patient’s preference or need. (1) The overall program concept (which led to the development of our mammogram intervention) was developed by the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Screening Program (NCI CPS) and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. These two groups have identified mammography at the age of 50 as a service that is most effective in the early detection and treatment of breast cancer. It’s also affordable. Most mammograms are done in the doctor’s office. (2) For women without a prior mammogram, it’s the same as for women with prior mammograms: at the age of 50, women can get screened every one or two years depending on their screening history and other medical and demographic information. For women who never had a prior mammogram and who are at high risk, the guideline recommends the screening at earlier ages such as 35 and 40. These women may be more likely to have an abnormal mammogram and to have a breast, or node, biopsy resulting in early diagnosis, treatment and better outcomes (survival).

Prior work examining mammography use among HMO members has not shown the same result for older women without mammograms, who are often in poorer health, have poorer health profiles and are less affluent. (3) They have higher rates of chronic conditions and may be screened less often. The HMO members studied in that work had equal access to a mammogram, as they all had access to an HMO plan that offers coverage for screening mammograms free of charge to all, because cancer diagnoses among this population are very low. Only a handful of studies have looked at the effectiveness of customized versus non-customized mammogram delivery strategies to increase mammography use.

This initiative was led by a group of five members who met to consider the research gaps and the question of “Why can’t we get all of this group of women to get their mammogram?”

The group members were physician clinicians, researchers, a health plan consultant and a methodologist. The task force recommended that the group use the concept of “interactive” mammography to deliver the intervention and that we target certain women for tailored intervention. (1) To develop our intervention, we met and worked on our “AHA!” statement – we are going to do our very best! We want to be successful! For the intervention, we needed to identify an “interactive,” tailored message that can be delivered in the medical home. It needed to be tailored to the specific health condition and needs of this population. We looked at what we know about the particular barriers to and facilitators for mammography use among older low-socioeconomic status women who have never had a mammogram. (3) We learned from clinical, research and other data that this population was less likely to have had a mammogram previously, have no health coverage for a mammogram and lived in rural locations where mammography was much less available, even with health coverage. We knew they were likely to have significant medical barriers to receiving a mammogram, if they could even get to an HMO clinic. To overcome these barriers for this group of older women, our intervention would emphasize mammography reminders, encouragement,

Prompt: Question: Double balloon enteroscopy: is it efficacious and safe in a community setting? Answer:
Response:
experience from a tertiary centre in the UK
Question: Double balloon enteroscopy: is it efficacious and safe in a community setting? Answer: experience from a tertiary centre in the UK

**Introduction**Double balloon enteroscopy (DBE) has many potential applications, but the safety and efficacy of its use in day to day clinical practice is not well defined. We report an experience using a combination of endoscopic and oral approaches for suspected small bowel disease in a community teaching hospital in the UK.

**Methods**Data was collected on the first 100 cases performed in the Department of Gastroenterology at Newcastle General Hospital in the 12 months from November 2011 to October 2012.

**Results**100 patients underwent 112 procedures for suspected small bowel disease. The indications were Crohn\'s disease in 34, malignant gastrointestinal neoplasm in 36, functional bowel disease in 12, ulcerative colitis and chronic inflammatory abdomen in 34 and abdominal pain in 8. The average age of the patients was 56.9 years (range 7-88).

The average time to the bowel following the procedure was 4.3 days (range 1-22) and the average duration of procedure was 40 minutes (range 20-120), during which time the average amount of fluid given was 1.2 litres. The average length of the small bowel visualised was 4.8 yards (3.4-5.2). The diagnostic yield was 57%, and the average number of diagnostic biopsies was 2.5.

There was one significant complication, an episode of intestinal perforation with peritonitis in one patient.

**Conclusion** Double balloon enteroscopy appears to be a safe and effective diagnostic tool in the community and this experience is an example of a tertiary centre where we could demonstrate the use of this technique in day to day clinical practice. A community hospital is capable of performing endoscopy and is well placed to use technology that is not often available in the community. Future studies evaluating the efficacy and safety of DBE in a community hospital are required.

**Disclosure of Interest**

None Declared

Prompt: Question: 30-Day and 1-year mortality in emergency general surgery laparotomies: an area of concern and need for improvement? Answer:
Response:
“Yes, and the magnitude of this increased adverse outcome is potentially alarming given the significant morbidity and associated health care burden that these patients experience.”

Emergency general surgery is the management of patients with potentially fatal conditions, and laparotomies are the main surgical procedures performed by surgeons. Emergency general surgeons are increasingly likely to be more specialized in the performance of these procedures; their operative exposure is likely to increase, as is exposure to intraoperative critical situations.

The management of emergency general surgery laparotomies has improved within Europe over time; the number of laparotomies has been reduced and the case volume is in line with that of other operations. This has been associated with improvements in perioperative and intraoperative management. [1-3] Nonetheless, mortality is higher in emergency general surgery laparotomies compared with elective general surgery with a mortality rate at 1 year of approximately 8%, which is higher than other procedures in the literature. [1-3]

Mortality is a very important outcome measure, as is quality of life. Our primary aim is to provide a good functional outcome and not just a better survival rate.

Predicting 30-day and 1-year mortality after emergency general surgery laparotomies is an important subject and can be difficult. Mortality rates are dependent on the urgency of operations performed, patient characteristics, severity of presentation, the clinical scenario, the extent of procedure performed, and the quality of operative and perioperative care.

Perioperative factors that are known to relate to mortality are increasing age, comorbidities, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) class, [4] number of units of whole blood transfused, intraoperative events [1, 2, 3], and intraoperative complications [1, 2, 3]. Postoperative factors are the type and urgency of a laparotomy and other factors.

Patients who require emergency general surgery laparotomies have higher than average mortality and morbidity rates. [1, 2, 4] These patients require substantial hospital resources, both in terms of intensive and high dependency care facilities and equipment, and the costs associated with complications are high.

The increased perioperative risk of emergency general surgery laparotomies has focused attention on the need to improve the surgical approach. Therefore, this paper reviews the key messages to improve the outcome of emergency general surgery laparotomies. It highlights some of the problems and limitations to the surgical intervention and reviews ways to improve perioperative mortality and morbidity.

The literature review included peer-reviewed articles within the last 20 years (1996 to 2016). A review of the published literature was done focusing on the following keywords: laparotomy, intraoperative adverse events, postoperative outcome, emergency, and mortality.

A variety of parameters have been associated with higher mortality in emergency general surgery laparotomies:

The higher rates in emergency general surgery laparotomies are due to a higher than average morbidity and mortality, and not just due to higher risk associated with the procedure. Increased numbers of laparotomies performed on elderly and frail patients are associated with increased mortality. [1, 2, 4] Increasing American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) criteria and number of units of packed red blood cells transfused per patient are associated with an increase in perioperative adverse events, including mortality, in emergency general surgery laparotomies [4]

The higher mortality rates associated with emergency general surgery laparotomies are not the result of an inadequate exposure to the case, as more experience is seen not to be associated with higher mortality; [4] indeed, patients with more recent years of operative experience have had lower mortality rates [1, 2, 5, 6]

More experience of surgeons does not necessarily lead to lower mortality rates, because increasing numbers of laparotomies performed on lower complexity cases appear to show increased morbidity but not mortality rates. [4] In laparotomies performed on a high complexity level, there is likely to be a lower mortality rate even among surgeons with less experience of performing large laparotomies, compared with the high overall mortality rates observed in general surgery.

There appears to be no advantage in using more consultants and more consultants with general surgery experience as compared with fewer consultants performing more surgery independently. [1-4]

Increased ASA class was associated with an increased postoperative adverse event rate and higher 30-day and 1-year mortality in a UK retrospective case series of 557 laparotomy patients, not just an increased rate of laparotomy as expected. [7]

More intraoperative events can have an additional damaging effect on outcome, including death. This has been demonstrated in randomized controlled trials where it has been shown that the mortality rate in an

Prompt: Question: Is adjustment for reporting heterogeneity necessary in sleep disorders? Answer:
Response:
A definitive yes
========================================================================================================

The topic of the role of heterogeneity in medical research is now being debated with regard to other disease areas[@B1], so it is important to keep in mind that it also occurs in sleep medicine. However, the role of heterogeneity as a source of confounding remains an important issue and should be considered for all studies that aim to compare effects of exposure on outcome[@B2]. Some studies may even seek to assess the effect of heterogeneity itself without acknowledging that heterogeneity can be due to confounding[@B3] ^,^ [@B4].

An example of such study was published in the recent issue of the *Brazilian Annals of Medicine and Surgery* ^5^. In that publication, a random effects meta-analysis combining data from observational studies on insomnia and suicidal behavior indicated that patients who suffered insomnia or insomnia disorder were approximately twice as likely to attempt or complete suicide independently of previous suicidal behavior. Furthermore, suicide attempts or completions were strongly related to prior suicidal behavior.

While reporting heterogeneity was suggested as a possible source of bias that may have confounded the assessment of effect size, the meta-analysis was mainly based on clinical and epidemiological data, such as the definition of insomnia disorder[@B5], the prevalence of previous lifetime suicide, and the odds ratios (OR) for the association between previous suicidal behavior and insomnia or insomnia disorders to conclude that insomnia/insomnia disorder is associated with attempted or completed suicide.

It should be highlighted that the conclusion of the meta-analysis has been criticized because most of the included studies had a low response rate in the suicide attempt group (30-60%), which can result in selection bias[@B5]. In the study by de Leon et al.[@B5], the overall percentage of insomnia in the suicide attempt group was only 44%. However, the percentage of insomnia in the suicide attempt group ranged up to 76% in another study[@B6]. Therefore, in order to conclude that insomnia/insomnia disorder leads to more suicide attempts or completions, the analysis should have also included the analysis of insomnia percentages of all suicide attempts or the analysis of the association between the percentage of insomnia and the suicide attempt group in other studies.

Some studies also demonstrated good prognosis after suicidal attempt[@B7] ^,^ [@B8], suggesting that not all suicide attempts were unsuccessful. There may be differences in patient characteristics at the time of admission to hospital after suicide attempts between patients with successful and those with unsuccessful suicide attempts. Furthermore, some clinical and sociodemographic characteristics of a patient, such as suicidal intent [@B9], may have resulted in selective patients that included in the study. Other characteristics (e.g. gender, family history of depression, socio-economical status, psychosocial factors, such as stress, and alcohol or drugs abuse) may also influence the association between previous suicidal behavior and insomnia[@B5] ^,^ [@B8].

The meta-analysis by de Leon et al.[@B5] was criticized because there are different definitions of insomnia disorder and the way in which insomnia symptoms were measured were inconsistent between diagnostic scales[@B10]. The sleep complaint criteria by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-4-th edition (DSM-IV) were used in three studies, including the one by De Leon and his colleagues, but different scales were used in the other two studies. Such inconsistencies in the operationalization of insomnia disorder may be a source of bias in both directions. Furthermore, sleep disturbance is not the only factor associated with the occurrence of a suicide attempt because psychiatric syndromes or personality disorders could also contribute to increased risk of suicide attempts[@B5].

A systematic review by Yildiz et al.[@B11] in 2013 concluded that data were insufficient to support a causal association between insomnia and suicide. However, the review included 13 cross-sectional studies and 7 were case-control studies. Six of these studies were conducted with a large random community cohort. As a result, the authors indicated that a systematic review of observational studies is needed to assess the evidence for a relationship between insomnia and suicide[@B11]. The recently published meta-analysis by Ghanizadeh et al.[@B12] of 25 studies (including 19 nested case-control studies and 5 cohort studies) found a relatively consistent and robust evidence that insomnia is a risk factor for suicide independently of confounding/modifiers. This meta-analysis of nested case-control studies using longitudinal design (cohort studies) supported an important contribution of insomnia symptoms to suicide.

Question: Can treatment of low HDL-C reduce carotid intima-media thickness? (Controversial, yes but is very popular for prevention of vascular disease)

The first thing to say is that it is a common misconception that only increased atherogenic lipid fractions should be corrected (HDL-CL and triglycerides). However, many believe that low HDL-C should be treated because of the purported cardioprotective effects of HDL-C (1, 2, 3). In the general population, lower HDL-C levels are associated with worse survival regardless of whether or not other lipids are increased (4) and with overall reduced life expectancy (5). A lower level of HDL-C may even predict overall mortality (6). A causal link between low or very low levels of HDL-C, higher levels of triglycerides or both, and increased future cardiovascular risk, is not clear and there are multiple potential pathways (7-9). We have also found that people with low HDL-C have faster progression of intimal-medial thickness (IMT) over time (10) and slower reduction in plaques after statin treatment (11) despite improved HDL-C, compared to those with high HDL-C. The purpose of this review is to suggest alternative ways to reduce plaque burden which may lead to a better understanding of the link between HDL-C and atherosclerosis.

The Framingham Heart study showed that a baseline level of HDL-C less than 0.9 mmol/L was associated with increased risk of future vascular events, even when LDL-C was controlled by statin therapy (5). However, people with low HDL-C were more than twice as likely to die from non-cardiovascular causes (5). A recent review of the role of HDL and all cardiovascular risk showed that HDL-C was clearly protective, reducing risk of major cardiovascular events by 25%, CHD by 11-15%, stroke by 13-19%, and vascular mortality by 22% (12). A meta-analysis of over 80,000 people followed up for 20 years showed that lower HDL-C, and in particular lower HDL-C: triglyceride ratio, were associated with a greater risk of CHD, even after adjustment for classic CVD risk factors including age, obesity, smoking, LDL-C, hypertension and diabetes (9). This study also showed that lower HDL-C: triglyceride ratios were associated with a higher incidence of cancer.

However, an inverse association between HDL-C and CHD was lost in several recent trials of rosuvastatin and simvastatin (13-17). Moreover, there was no increase in vascular events with increased statin dose or duration or when statin was administered to men with low HDL-C (18, 19). In this study, increased HDL-C was associated with slower progression of IMT in patients with pre-existing plaque (0.02 vs. 0.11 mm/year) on statin therapy (20).

The recent study, the Heart Protection Study Part B, showed similar benefits of simvastatin on total mortality (11, 21), major cardiovascular events, CVD death, non-CVD death, and all-cause death (11). This benefit was limited to those with baseline HDL-C less than or equal to 1.03 mmol/L, with no benefit in those with baseline HDL-C more than 1.03 mmol/L (11). This study also reported an increased incidence of diabetes and cancer in those in the placebo arm (11), although this could be explained by the high diabetes prevalence of people with low HDL-C.

Despite all these studies showing the clearly protective effects of maintaining a higher HDL-C, in the general population, low, intermediate, or even high HDL-C levels, are associated with a higher risk of CVD mortality, CHD and stroke, regardless of baseline lipids (6). There is no convincing evidence to show that increased HDL-C by raising statin doses will reverse the negative effects of statin in a non-cholestatic liver. It should be emphasized that the increased CVD mortality may be due to the association between low HDL-C and high LDL-C, which may have confounded all the trials conducted after the year 2000. As a result, there has been much confusion among the public and even among physicians and patients about whether to correct low HDL-C. The major problem is that in most of the clinical trials, low HDL-C was defined by a lower level of HDL-C and not by a low HDL-C: triglyceride ratio (as seen in the general population), so people with very low HDL-C: triglyceride ratios were excluded. At about 1 a.m. on August 3, 2003, 24-year-old Jessica Eller visited the pediatric unit at the Children's Medical Center in Dallas, Texas, with her 9-month-old son, Aaron. He had been a healthy baby until the day before, when he had a fever that had not broken, but had returned to normal, accompanied by diarrhea, vomiting, and decreased appetite. When the nurse on that night's roster told Eller that she didn't see any sign of an infection or a serious problem, the nurse practitioner at the Dallas emergency room, where they had gone earlier that evening, said the episode was probably a typical reaction to an infant's changing room routine.

But Aaron grew progressively worse throughout the night of August 2–3; he stopped showing his usual vitals and developed signs of respiratory distress. Shortly after they arrived at the emergency room, he began requiring oxygen. Despite the best efforts of the emergency physicians and the intensive-care physicians, he was not improving. Instead, his breathing became progressively worse, with an increasing need for oxygen, as well as continuous positive airway pressure. Eller was asked to go home, but when they arrived at her apartment complex on the way there, Aaron was not breathing and Eller had to be taken to the hospital by ambulance. They couldn't reach a pulse on him, and because of the poor response of his heart, his condition was pronounced dead about 7:30 a.m.

A few weeks later, the doctors examining the case asked the hospital's quality-control department to perform a more detailed review of the case. On August 4, 2003, the quality-control team sent a written report to the hospital's medical director, Dr. James T. Mancuso, describing its findings. The report said:

The patient was stable for about 6 to 8 hours before a critical change occurred in the level of oxygenation on room air to the point requiring continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). The baby initially stopped breathing, and was unable to respond to any stimuli at any time during the hospitalization. The mother was called multiple times by the night nurse, asking her to come back to check on the baby, and was advised it was a typical change in his breathing and to go home to sleep. The mother was sent home on August 2, but came back immediately upon not hearing from the baby, at approximately 11 PM. During the return she became concerned due to the number of missed calls and the increased respiration rate noted on her phone call of August 4. She called and was told, "The nurse doesn't have Aaron, but the doctor will be back soon." She came to the hospital and was called to see the doctor, the baby was blue and the mother was told it was a respiratory arrest. The patient was placed on a ventilator with a tracheotomy and given oxygen. The physician was contacted and the emergency team was called. The baby was still unresponsive and no heart rate was noted. A total oxygen intake of 3 liters was given at first, then 5 liters, and, after only 15 minutes after the third liter, there was no pulse or heart rate response. A chest was opened and a large fluid-filled chest in the right lower lobe was noted. A needle probe was able to pass into the chest cavity, and the fluid contained oxygen up to the level of saturation 100%. The baby remained without oxygen for 30 hours. During that 30 hours, numerous attempts with intravenous lines were made, but always remained patent for 30 to 60 minutes during which time only IV antibiotics could be given.

Although the report concluded that a "cardiac arrest" had occurred, the quality-control team found that there had been inadequate resuscitation and management, and that an alternative diagnosis to a cardiac arrest "should have been made earlier" in Aaron's treatment. Thus, based on the quality-control review of the case, the hospital was forced to admit its failure and acknowledge its responsibility for the patient's death on December 18, 2003. This was a major achievement, because in order for the case to be reviewed, it was necessary for Dallas County, Texas, where the boy was living at the time, to acknowledge both the patient and his parents were "adults" (16 years of age and older), who had voluntarily signed a waiver of medical-liability claims for any harm or injury that might occur to them, or their relatives, as a result of hospital services given to them, including medical or surgical treatment.

Prompt: Question: Did Chile's traffic law reform push police enforcement? Answer:
Response:
No, but...

Question: Did Chile's traffic law reform push police enforcement? Answer: No, but...

The government of President Sebastián Piñera's administration claims that his "traffic reform", implemented on 1 July 2012, led to a decline in highway fatalities. But experts say that while some numbers might have changed due to better recording of deaths and because of the implementation of new traffic laws, it is not because of the new legislation.

In August 2013, the government announced a significant reduction in fatalities of highway accidents for 2013: 26% in a year against 2012's annual average of 39 homicides per 100,000 people. According to the official data published by the Institute for National Statistics, there were 1,062 deaths for the year 2012, representing an annual average of 39 per 100,000 people, with a drop to 1035 in 2013, and an estimated 9 per 100,000 people in 2014. The year 2012, which has just started, had an average increase according to the official figures of 0.3% over 2011 (in addition, a correction of 15.27% was made for 2013). The decrease represents a significant drop, and the first one since the government of Ricardo Lagos Délano took over the reins of power in 1990.

According to official government data published since 2000, Santiago's annual average on highways is 1.5 deaths per 100,000 people, while in other cities it is twice as much: 3.5 deaths per 100,000 people in Osorno and 4.9 in Temuco, which could be explained by the fact that they still have the more archaic traffic rules. In January 2013, the most affected zone in the capital was the eastern side of the main route 6 between Viña del Mar and Constitución, whose road is the busiest in town, and where the most number of deaths are recorded per year.

The government, on this same road, said that the accident frequency dropped by 20% in the month of July. In fact, the number of fatalities for the month of July 2012 was 4, compared to 5 for the same month of 2013. According to media figures, the drop in fatalities between July 2012 and July 2013 (14%) for the whole road was the third one in 10 years.

The number, however, is not entirely the result of traffic law changes, as there is a difference between police interventions in accidents and how they are recorded. It is important to underline that during the two years of record since the law was revised, the Ministry of Public Works of Chile has been using a system for registering incidents on the highways, which was introduced in 1999 when the reform of highway legislation was first being implemented; and which the national government has subsequently adapted and is using at a national level, as in this case. Under the new system, each officer present at the scene of an incident records the information as a police intervention when there is a person with fatal or very serious injuries, or with moderate to serious injuries.

Before this new system, recording incidents on highways by the national government was made at a regional level by the police forces. In this case, the government also has a registry with the amount of fatalities at a regional level, which is much smaller than the national one and not always updated. In the case of the accident frequency data for July, the year's total for July 2013 at the national level registered only 6 deaths.

So what explains the improvement?

This year the government of Sebastián Piñera's administration claims it is thanks to a change in regulations promulgated last year that allow officers to intervene when they believe a driver is not respecting a traffic rule, such as a lane or a speed limit, or when they believe that someone has an alcohol problem, while in previous years only accidents due to motorist behaviour could be recorded.

In fact, as far back as December of 2012, reports of the media stated that the government had changed the law to allow officers to intervene when they believe a driver has an alcohol problem, a proposal submitted by the Ministry of Public Works was supported and incorporated into the decree of 1 December 2012. Since then, police officers have been able to intervene in incidents in which there is suspicion of alcohol abuse, as long as there is reason to believe that this is the case.

In the case of traffic law changes, as long as they do not increase the penalty for an act, such as speeding the fines or fees for an offence, and reduce the number of kilometres the fine should be paid by a motorist, the new law has been regarded by police and the courts as not affecting them. Moreover, as long as an accident occurs, there are two offences that can be registered: the violation of the traffic rule that caused the accident, and another against the one responsible for the incident. Therefore, after the adoption of the new regulations, if an officer intervenes

The following post was prompted by the following question: “I'm just learning that therapeutic anticoagulation with warfarin or heparin is often indicated for moderate to high risk trauma patients – is this true? The trauma doc I saw yesterday had said "I think you may need warfarin until we can get the results of your scans” and my neurosurgeon said the same for your head.”

[We all know the answer is that it really depends, but this question made me go search the literature in more detail:]

The literature on the subject in trauma is a mixed bag. For example a large retrospective study published last year, included only trauma patients receiving heparin or warfarin. This study showed that rates of death or major hemorrhagic complications were no different in patients receiving therapeutic anticoagulation than in those receiving no anticoagulation. However, the rates of all-cause non-fatal hemorrhage were higher in patients with head injuries than in patients without head injuries (5.2% vs 3.4%).[3] The rate of DVT was much higher in patients with head injuries, although the results had a p value <0.001 for treatment/no treatment (13.5% vs 3.4%) [3]. Patients with major and minor head injuries seemed to have similar rates of all-cause hemorrhage (6.4% vs 7.0%) but major head injury seemed, as noted in more detail below, to be associated with all-cause non-fatal hemorrhage (10.8% vs 3.4%). There was no difference in mortality rate between patients with and without anticoagulation. [3]

There was no difference in mortality rate between patients (with and without major and minor head injuries) who had therapeutic (i.e. heparin or warfarin) and prophylactic (i.e. warfarin or direct thrombin inhibitors) anticoagulation.

The rate of DVT was higher among patients using anticoagulants. [3]

These same authors, a few months ago, published an analysis of the same data, and found that the risk of post-traumatic intracranial complication was similar in patients receiving or not receiving therapeutic anticoagulation. Only the mortality rate was higher in trauma patients receiving anticoagulants. [4]

Both of these studies included only major and minor head injuries. [4] It is unclear whether similar results would be found with major head injuries alone.

The British National Institute of Heath Clinical Medicine paper, published in February 2007, concluded that there is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of therapeutic anticoagulation for patients with minor head injury. [5]

If the head is not an isolated injury, there is no benefit to therapeutic anticoagulation, and potential harm in the form of increased risk of mortality, intracranial haemorrhage, pulmonary embolism, and DVT.

[In the original question, the word “trauma” and the words head and head injury were used interchangeably. I had thought that the British guidelines probably included patients with isolated head injuries. However, if there is no head injury or an isolated head injury, then it is unlikely that therapeutic anticoagulation will be recommended after head injury, and if there is a DVT then, like most surgeons, if the patient complains of leg pain, the patient should be referred for intravenous pyridoramine for 5 days, but not for a therapeutic anticoagulant. This drug is given to prevent the development of DVT for patients who have not had a prophylactic anticoagulant given prior to surgery. Given the frequency of DVT after trauma, we do not rely on a trial of 5 days for the treatment of DVT.]

If you read the text in the italic above, you will also notice that even heparin is harmful in head injuries.

In 2008, the Society of Critical Care Medicine published guidelines on the use of anticoagulant therapy in trauma. They concluded that although the use of anticoagulants in trauma may have favorable outcomes with reduced hemorrhage, this benefit has not been proved. Nevertheless, they recommended that patients with massive hemorrhage and life-threatening, severe, or lethal bleeding (i.e.

The sensitivity and specificity values of the traditional biomarkers are not sufficient for use in HCC diagnosis and surveillance. The 2016 American Association of the Study of Liver Diseases (AASLD) Research and Practice Guidelines[@bib1], published the results of their effort to create a practical document on the diagnosis and management of NAFLD patients that was written in consensus based on the best available literature evidence. It focused on clinical management and provided an evidence-based algorithm in the case of unresponsiveness to lifestyle changes or in the case of clinical complications. In this issue of *Hepatology Communications,* Lee et al conducted a literature review and developed consensus statements with the participation of a working group of a large number of hepatology experts who also evaluated the most significant clinical trials on the topic and concluded that the diagnosis and follow-up of NAFLD patients, especially if they have metabolic risk factors, should rely primarily on noninvasive imaging for diagnostic as well as follow-up purposes. Moreover, in patients with risk factors and NASH, the recommendation is for serial follow up, without follow-up as an independent modality of evaluation of disease regression.

It was recognized that liver biopsy is the gold standard for the differentiation of NASH from simple steatosis and may be useful for excluding other differential diagnoses or confirming the initial diagnosis of NASH.[@bib1] However, it was considered more reasonable to rely on noninvasive imaging and on laboratory markers for the diagnosis or exclusion of NASH. In the case of severe chronic liver disease, a liver biopsy is not indicated given the risk of an increased rate of complications (bile duct or gallbladder injury, bleeding within the liver and portal hypertension) and the poor quality of the biopsy (with many ancillary studies required). Thus, the guideline recommends that liver biopsy should not be routinely required to diagnose or exclude the diagnosis of NASH, although this should be considered when the patient has a history of biliary disease or metabolic syndrome.[@bib1]

The recommendations of this guideline are in agreement with other publications suggesting an initial diagnosis of NAFLD/NASH based on ultrasound evidence of two or more hepatic ultrasound features of steatosis (including increased liver echogenicity, increased vascular blurring, and poor visualization of deep hepatic structures), in the absence of significant alcohol intake (20 g or less of ethanol/day). In cases of suspected NASH, this recommendation would be based not only on imaging evidence, but also on abnormal transaminases and the presence of histologic features of hepatocellular injury and inflammation found on a liver biopsy. This is the basis of the current recommendations published in the 2016 EASL NAFLD guidelines. The recommendations in this guideline on the work-up for diagnosis included: 1) the absence of significant alcohol intake (\< 20 g of ethanol/day), 2) histologic features of steatosis, lobular or portal inflammation, and hepatocyte ballooning, 3) and elevated levels of ALT and AST. When an individual has multiple risk factors for NASH, the recommendation is for follow up as a patient with metabolic syndrome (defined as three or more of the following symptoms: central obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and impaired glucose tolerance) should be followed up at least annually by liver ultrasound and blood testing of ALT/AST.[@bib1] This recommendation is in accordance with published algorithms.[@bib2]

Prompt: Question: Do emergency ultrasound fellowship programs impact emergency medicine residents' ultrasound education? Answer:
Response:
It depends.
Ultrasound education has been implemented in a plethora of medical schools with varying success throughout the globe. Emergency medicine residency is arguably the only specialty not incorporating ultrasound into its curriculum. Most emergency medicine programs will do ultrasounds for trauma, yet many of these have had very little exposure to emergency ultrasound itself. Our current methods to obtain emergency ultrasound education are inadequate. We explore what emergency ultrasound fellowship programs provide and how they impact emergency medicine residents' ultrasound education. We hypothesize that emergency ultrasound education and fellowship programs are a very important part of the emergency department ultrasound landscape and are necessary to ensure emergency ultrasound instruction occurs in residency programs nationwide. Emergency ultrasound fellowship programs are vital in not only creating a standardized curriculum for medical students but also providing hands-on teaching for both medical students and residents. Emergency ultrasound fellowship programs serve as the largest educators in residency programs for emergency medicine and have a major impact on emergency ultrasound education nationwide. Emergency ultrasound fellowship programs are a critical component to ensuring the next generation of emergency physicians are well prepared in providing emergency ultrasound to our patients during the COVID-19 pandemic. Furthermore, as emergency ultrasound fellowship programs teach emergency medicine residents how to perform ultrasound on patients while under COVID-19 crisis, emergency ultrasound fellowship programs educate residents to effectively work during an emergency.

Prompt: Question: Patient-Controlled Therapy of Breathlessness in Palliative Care: A New Therapeutic Concept for Opioid Administration? Answer:
Response:
Yes!
Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) is a therapeutic approach employed for the management of mild to moderate pain. This is usually carried out by administering a morphine-based drug via an injection pump that allows the patient to self-administer a variable dose of medication over a pre-defined period of time. A related therapeutic application of PCA exists in the field of palliative care, whereby the patient self-administers analgesic medication via a device, which they wear around their neck. This device is connected to a flexible plastic hose that is inserted into the patient's mouth so that the substance administered will be inhaled, therefore allowing for an even distribution of the medication throughout the body. For example, a patient suffering from breathlessness caused by chemotherapy would self-administer morphine (or similar substance) at home, by means of the PCA system, thereby giving them some degree of control over their pain.
PCA has already been well established in the area of oncology. An extensive number of studies demonstrating its efficacy in controlling terminal cancer pain have helped to establish a standard of care that allows oncologists to prescribe it. More recently, the use of PCA in the palliative care setting has increased as the patient's desire to be active and play an active role in their treatment regimens has become a central concern.
PCA, in comparison to other methods of administering opioids, has distinct advantages. For instance, one of the major advantages of PCA relates to how the patient controls how much (in terms of dose) and when (in terms of delivery) they will receive their pain reliever medication. For example, if the patient is administered an opioid at a fixed, pre-identified rate of delivery (in the form of either a single shot or a bolus), then this may lead to issues pertaining to “overdose” or to the patient being too fatigued to function properly. Conversely, if an opioid is delivered according to a fixed, pre-defined delivery schedule, it may be associated with opioid spikes. As a result, there are considerable challenges to be overcome for this form of administration. Moreover, the ability of the patient to control the dose of the opioid and to regulate the intake in terms of time can significantly reduce the risk of overdose, as well as the risk of the patient being drowsy when their pain relieving medication is required to be administered. Unfortunately, PCA does present some disadvantages and difficulties too. One major disadvantage is that the patient will be limited to a “burst” mode of administration, where the patient must wait for the pain relief medication to be administered before they can subsequently request for another dose. Another challenge with PCA is that there is no fixed dose range, so the patient may only be expected to use a wide number of doses (and thus a wide range of doses) in order to achieve adequate control.
PCA, as a palliative care tool, presents distinct advantages as well. For example, the ability for the patient to self-administer the medication allows them much more autonomy than is possible with a fixed delivery regimen. This freedom of choice benefits the patients ability to engage in the aspects of their daily lives that they want to undertake. It is well documented that patients often experience an increase in quality of life if a high degree of control is offered to them when it comes to how and when they utilize their drugs for pain management. An additional advantage which patients experience using PCA is that it provides them with more opportunity for socialization and support from family, friends, and caregivers; it is very important to the patients and their families that the pain can be controlled in a meaningful way while they are at home.
Despite the benefits and advantages that PCA has to offer, it has yet to be introduced or widely used in the field of palliative care. There is currently no known device (oral palliative unit) that allows for the patient to self-administer opioid drugs orally over an extended period of time in a manner that reduces the risks of overdose or overdose related symptoms while simultaneously providing the patient with a suitable dose that affords them with adequate control over their pain, rather than just a single dose. This lack of oral PCA devices has meant that, at present, palliative care patients receive sub-optimal pain control during palliative care and that palliative care patients cannot take full advantage of the potential benefits afforded to them by being able to self-administer their medications. Therefore, what is needed is a device that offers a suitable dose of opioid medication in a manner that is not only safe in that it poses little to no risk of overdose to the patient, it also allows the patient to benefit from the full range of potential advantages offered by an oral PCA device.
PCA as a palliative care tool has an additional shortcoming

Last November I traveled down a rabbit trail on an email conversation on a post on an autism “awareness group” I was administering that was being used as a forum for people to complain about vaccination. Prompt: Question: Is there a model to teach and practice retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy? Answer:
Response:
For the case presented here, a nephrectomy was chosen for the patient as a therapeutic option. We describe steps taken to successfully perform this procedure that were consistent with the principles of minimally invasive and image-guided surgery, and that had a low complication rate.

Patient: A 51-year-old female patient presented with an asymptomatic mass in the right paramedian abdomen diagnosed with an asymptomatic complex cyst by abdominal ultrasound, computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging. After discussing the pros and cons of conservative management versus surgery, the patient decided to proceed with nephrectomy. She had a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis that had previously been treated with leukocytoclastic vasculitis and ankylosing spondylitis. She had previously undergone right-sided nephrectomy, and the right kidney demonstrated no function. In the present case, the patient had an estimated body mass index of 33, and a current weight of 135 kg.

Surgical options: There was concern that this patient, a high-risk surgical candidate for a renal mass with high morbidity and mortality due to her condition, would benefit more from conservative management for a renal mass. The decision to proceed with surgery was made in conjunction with the patient as there was no definite evidence that a renal mass existed and no renal function was appreciated. We decided to proceed with a minimally invasive retroperitoneal nephrectomy due to the low anticipated perioperative and postoperative morbidity, as well as the low risk of progression/recurrence with a benign pathology. In this case, we had no evidence of functioning kidney tissue.

Anesthesia: We chose to administer the patient general anesthesia with loup-point endotracheal intubation due to her size, her chronic pulmonary disease and her history of lupus vasculitis. We administered intravenous premedication with 1 mg of midazolam. The patient underwent general anesthesia induction with 4 µg/kg of continuous infusion of remifentanil and 1 mg of dexamethasone; 1 mg of clonidine was intravenously injected. General anesthesia was maintained with a continuous infusion of target controlled infusion of propofol and fentanyl at 10 µg/mL and 20 ng/mL, respectively. Sevoflurane was used for the maintenance of general anesthesia. The patient was preoxygenated for 10 minutes with an oxygen flow rate of 10 L/min before intubation.

Procedure: The patient was placed in a left-lateral position with the back flexed. For the retroperitoneoscopic approach, we first made a posterolateral transverse 5-cm incision over the L4 vertebral body line from the tip of the 12th rib to the tip of the 5th rib as described by Kurita et al. [@JR190102crc-1]. [Figure 1A](#FI190102crc-1){ref-type="fig"} [@JR190102crc-2] demonstrates the entry site and the path taken during the approach. Dissection of the right external oblique muscle was performed, and then the right deep inferior epigastric vessels and right external iliac and external iliac circumflex veins were isolated. Under direct visualization, a 0-degree scope was inserted and moved to the level of the kidney. The lower portion of the scope containing the 30-degree and the 5-degree working arms was introduced into the pelvis. To allow the scope to reach the level of the adrenal glands and the kidney, the inferior surface of the peritoneum was incised with a hook cautery scalpel. To improve visualization, the right paracolic gutters were incised using a linear cutting stapler. The retroperitoneal space was extended by dissecting between Gerota\'s fascia and psoas muscles. Retractors were placed and the posterior border of the 12th rib was cut. [Figure 1B](#FI190102crc-1){ref-type="fig"} demonstrates the incision and the trocar position. Dissection from the pelvis to the renal hilum was performed to identify and visualize the kidney; the kidney capsule was incised.

![Entry site and path taken during a retroperitoneoscopic approach. **A**) Entry site at L4 and trocar insert. **B**) Incision of the posterior border of the 12th rib; trocar insert position.](10-1055-s-0040-171707-i190102crc-1){#FI190102crc-1}

Question: Israeli hospital preparedness for terrorism-related multiple casualty incidents: can the surge capacity and injury severity distribution be better predicted? Answer:
Response:
not really.

Israel is not known for being the soft target and being terrorised, at least not recently, but it is part of the Middle East and the world is being subjected to the chaos and violence of the Middle East in a way that doesn't usually happen.

The terrorist groups are all around us and some may even be a danger to be on the streets even if they have no intention to attack anyone, but the general public do not do enough to protect themselves.

This includes hospital staff and patients. You can always be prepared for something to go wrong as it is a natural byproduct of human activity, but you should be prepared for a lot of things to go wrong.

Hospitals are no exception to the rules. Hospitals will always be attacked by terrorist groups because they are targets, but a hospital is also a place where people go for treatment.

The Israeli hospitals have been attacked over and over again. Recently, one or two attacks were in the news, but we never had a huge attack, just a few.

Last year, most of the hospital staff were trained on how to deal with a mass casualty incident and the staff were preparing for that. But it never happened, but a couple of soldiers were injured and they could have been treated at home, instead they were taken to the nearest hospital in the army's medical evacuation service.

They were treated at the hospital, which was full which meant that some of them had to wait. If their family members could have taken them home some could have been treated at home. You can be prepared for a mass casualty incident, but it will not happen.

The Israeli army has a large and important medical contingent in the territories. The Israeli army trains in the field to take care of casualties in a way that is very similar to the way it can be done at another field hospital. Israel is part of the Middle East and is prepared for such attacks.

This does not mean that it is easy just to open up an army field hospital in the area and treat all the military patients and civilian patients. This is a big and expensive enterprise that makes little sense for the Israeli state.

Israelis have the same idea when a major disaster of some kind happens. The Israeli government also has a role in providing disaster response capacity for its population, not only when there is a natural disaster, for example, but also man made disasters, such as floods, fires, etc.

Israel is known to have the best medical treatment in the world. It does a lot internationally, but it is not always as cheap and accessible as everyone assumes.

One of the largest issues here is how to improve the system and make it even better, but that's another story. The Israeli army does an exceptional job of making sure that casualties are treated.

The hospitals are prepared for major events such as terrorist attacks. What makes it difficult is what they have to deal with in real time as they would not have any idea what the terrorist plan was.

Many of the hospitals are not big and might have no emergency room, they might be fully occupied, so all the emergency treatments have to be done in other places, which usually means that the hospital does not get a lot of complaints about the outcome.

If we have an active terrorist group trying to kill some people in the street and the hospital is already full, then it can delay that. Some patients are waiting for an emergency bed (because the hospital is full) and when the bed is ready someone else has to wait.

This does not have to be a good thing if the hospital is in an area that is going to attack soon. If those people are the enemy and their next target is the hospital, it can be considered a hostile event. How can the terrorist attack people in hospitals? They have no reason to do it, but it does happen.

Some of the Israeli hospitals have plans for terrorist incursions. They can be built to look like that, but they are usually not that big or elaborate.

There have been some incidents, but they have not killed that many people. In Israel, more than anyone else, one of the main goals of terrorism is not to kill a lot of people, but the psychological effect on the people and government.

Israel's hospitals are not prepared for such an attack. They are preparing for the worst-case-scenario or the best-case-scenario, but as long as the terrorist organisations target people, they aren't going to target hospitals, especially if they have some targets and they know they can do better.

So there isn't any great solution, you can train as much as you want but there is no way to predict what the next terrorist will do. If your hospital is located where there is a lot of terrorist activity, it
