Response:
No, but parents are more interested in their children's physical appearance, while physicians perceive more psychosocial aspects.

Body perception is a complex and multifaceted concept. On the one hand, body perception is a psychological phenomenon, involving the self-evaluation, perception, and judgment of the own body, body image, and body appreciation \[[@B1-children-06-00014]\]. On the other hand, body perception is part of daily behavior and a clinical term, referring to a certain medical behavior and/or appearance and the behavior of a caregiver toward this medical behavior and/or appearance \[[@B2-children-06-00014]\].

The body image, which represents one element of body perception, is a multifaceted concept. Generally, it refers to the way of representing one's own body on the outside, including the physical appearance, emotional reactions, feeling and satisfaction about one's body, and physical appearance satisfaction \[[@B3-children-06-00014]\]. Based on the literature, these concepts are mainly represented by the body mass index (BMI), the body perception, and physical activity \[[@B4-children-06-00014],[@B5-children-06-00014],[@B6-children-06-00014],[@B7-children-06-00014],[@B8-children-06-00014],[@B9-children-06-00014]\].

The body image of children and adolescents has gained more and more interest in the last few decades \[[@B10-children-06-00014]\]. The body image is influenced by the culture, society, and the media. Therefore, it is very likely that its expression differs between various populations, including the parents, their children, and their healthcare providers \[[@B11-children-06-00014],[@B12-children-06-00014]\].

Our objective was to determine body perception in children and the body perception in their parents. The parents of 8--18-year-old children should be represented in our pediatric population, and their behavior toward their children affects the body perception of their children. Since the literature lacks data on the relation between body perception in children and parents, we examined whether body image-related behaviors in children are associated with body perception-related behavior in their parents. Body perception should be considered a multidimensional and multidirectional perspective. Additionally, body perception is a dynamic phenomenon and should not be taken at face value \[[@B3-children-06-00014]\].

1.1. Methods {#sec1dot1-children-06-00014}
------------

This is a single-center study of parents of children and adolescents at a tertiary German pediatric clinic with respect to their own body perception of their child ([Figure 1](#children-06-00014-f001){ref-type="fig"}); their own behavior toward their child's body in regards to BMI; and the relationship between their own body perception and their own behaviors with a BMI cut-off value, which had not been previously investigated in the literature ([Figure 2](#children-06-00014-f002){ref-type="fig"}) \[[@B13-children-06-00014]\].

1.2. Materials and Methods {#sec1dot2-children-06-00014}
--------------------------

The data of this study was collected as part of routine care by the outpatient pediatric clinic in Germany. After getting verbal informed consent, parents and children were examined by a pediatric nurse to identify the child with a BMI on the 75th to 95th percentile. The following data were collected by the parent questionnaire (available in [Supplementary Materials: Appendix A](#app1-children-06-00014){ref-type="app"}). The following data were documented by the questionnaire: age, sex, and type of body perception. The following data were documented by documentation of the height, weight, and BMI of the child and the BMI of the parents themselves. Furthermore, we asked the parents about their body perception in respect to their child's body, i.e., whether they think their child "has a good," "somewhat good," "poor," or "very poor appearance." In addition, we asked about specific body perceptions, i.e., whether the father or mother thinks their child's "shoulders are too low" "too short," and "too high." Furthermore, we asked the parents about their own behavior toward their child's body, i.e., whether they notice any problem with "muscles," "stomach," or "bones"; furthermore, we asked how often the parents "push

Prompt: Question: Is a specialised training of phonological awareness indicated in every preschool child? Answer:
Response:
No, in most cases this is not necessary. This training is indicated only for children with difficulty understanding some of the sounds in the first phase of language.

Questions concerning the need to use such training for young children with no apparent speech or language problems and those with delays in language development, are also answered in this publication.

A comprehensive review about the importance of Phonological Awareness (PA) and its relationship with school learning is presented here together with a discussion about the reasons for the use of certain practices aimed at teaching phonological awareness.

The present publication focuses on the necessity of specialised training of Phonological Awareness in preschool children.
The basic premises on which questions regarding the need to use such training is based are presented here.

In this second part of our training programme we present the different reasons for the use of training of phonological awareness in school settings and give further explanation about the benefits of such practice for children that have difficulties in learning to read and write.

This paper deals with the relationship between speech and language therapy and the teaching of phonological awareness in preschool settings. The benefits from this type of intervention and the reasons for it are summarised.

It must be considered that speech and language therapy aims to enable the child to use words, in order to communicate effectively and intelligibly. In phonological awareness training, the therapist will be able to teach and verify the ability to understand the sounds that make up words, and to combine sounds correctly to form different words.

Language disorders, which have a high level of prevalence in children, involve any inability to understand or use language and constitute an important disabling condition. In the early years of life, language problems interfere significantly with learning, development as well as school performance and may persist throughout the different stages of development. Many people will come into contact with these disorders during their professional careers. Those who work at primary education, who assist or study the development of children who have speech and language difficulties, will experience a higher incidence of language disorders among their clients.
In recent decades a growing number of studies have been conducted to describe the characteristics of children with speech and language problems, as well as the various forms of clinical treatment which may be prescribed. The need for the development of knowledge in this area is obvious, as speech and language therapists are likely to be involved in the management of children with communication disorders or in their development, given their educational role, and because of their interaction with families and other social agents.
Language disorders are classified, on the basis of their nature, as well as on the stage and form in which they become apparent. This division leads to four categories of speech and language disorders:

1. Delay of language development (from birth to 3 years).

In this category, the child’s vocabulary and communication skills are more or less normal in relation to his age and a delay in language development can be observed. Most cases in this category are characterised by a delay in speech and language skills (Vakili, 2006) and in communication skills (Bannatyne, 2004). Children with such problems are not able to distinguish between the different functions of a word with which they cannot communicate efficiently.

2. Immaturity of speech and language skills (3-6 years).

In this category, the speech and language skills are considered immature and delayed from early childhood.

3. Disorders of language and communication with a delayed onset (3-6 years).

Some children who demonstrate speech and language disorders with a delayed onset have normal development and the problem arises later. This problem is classified as a disorder of social development (DAD-3) (Nicol, 2002).

4. Disorders of language and communication (3-6 years).

The main characteristics of this kind of speech and language disorder are the absence of communication skills and the inability to understand language and communicate (Nicol, 2002).

The majority of these language disorders cannot be treated and will have a chronic and disabling character (D’Adesky, 2006).
The classification of speech and language disorders is based on the criteria outlined by American Speech Language Hearing Association and has been used in many studies on this subject (Petersen and Schick, 1995).

The studies which are usually quoted in the international literature were based on the findings of the research to which the American Speech Language Hearing Association had contributed from 1981 onwards but, because of the various results of the last few years, a new classification has now been developed for the purposes of this paper. This new classification is based on the “International Classification of Communication Disorders” adopted in 1987 by the American Speech Language Hearing Association and is widely used around the world (ASHA, 1992).

A specific research on the language disorders of young children was conducted by the Centre for Language Disorders, Department of Speech and Hearing, Faculty of Medicine, University of Mar

Response:
There is definitely an association between streptococcal infection. The bacteria is found in blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). People with multiple sclerosis have much higher levels of streptococci in their blood. People with the disease are also more likely to get streptococcal infections of the skin (e.g. scarlet fever) which leads to a lot of post streptococcal autoimmune issues. So there is lots of evidence that streptococci can induce or cause multiple sclerosis.

The bacteria is most often found in streptococcal infections of the mouth like tonsillitis strep D and can cause systemic infection (e.g. strep A). Infection of tooth tissue has been shown to induce MS in some people. I have a very interesting case of MS that has been shown by me not to have MS induced by infection. I'll write more about that later. Now let's go to the original source study:

An overview of MS is needed before a discussion of any of the specific links which have been proposed as causative agents will be considered.

The history of MS is not well known. The first definitive description appears to be by Giovanni Battista Morgagni (1582--1655), who described a case of the disease which was called Morbus multiplex. In most of the 19th century, little is known of it, even though it was a well-known disease

In 1909 the first comprehensive clinical description was made by Erich D. Dubois who termed

his book "La Multiple Symptomatique." It was not until the 20th century that a better understanding of the disease was established. The first etiological hypothesis was published by Alois Alzheimer in 1907 [27]. He considered that the disease was caused by a toxic substance present in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It was not until 1931 that Otto Buch [28] put forward a different view, namely that the disease was the result of an infection of the nervous tissue.

In 1953, R.C.S. Johnson [29] proposed an infectious cause based on the evidence from two pathogenic bacteria, Streptococci and Bacilli that are able to induce demyelination in animals. In 1956, J.E. Mack, C,B. MacDowell and J.W. Stearns [30] demonstrated in a number of animals that a streptococcal infection induced lesions in the brains of those animals. By the same time, the French and Swiss virologists J.P. Lefvre-Lambline and R. Romain had demonstrated that the CSF of patients had many more particles bearing resemblance to streptococci than to other bacteria. They proposed that the infectious agent responsible for MS was a streptococcus.

Following the description of MS, the incidence in certain areas of the world increased, particularly the Middle East and India. A disease similar to MS was found in Norway, known as benign paralytic disease. This was the disease was thought to be due to streptococcal infection. Later evidence from South Africa showed the relationship between MS and streptococcal infections was not that clear, as in those areas MS was very common, but most patients did not have streptococcal infections. In 1974, the Swiss virologist W.E. Paul demonstrated that there were more particles in the CSF than in the blood and were very similar to streptococci particles. He suggested that there was an abnormal immunity against streptococci and that this was the link between MS and streptococci. He proposed that a streptococcal antigen was responsible for the disease rather than a streptococcal infection. After his evidence was shown to be flawed by other studies, it was shown that the link between streptococcal infection and MS was not as clear as it first appeared and a few other possible causes were postulated. One of these was the possible effect of sunlight. It was also noted that a lot of MS had occurred where most patients did not have streptococcal infections.

In 1967 and 1968 C.H. Janeway and associates [31–36], and J.W. Johnson [37] at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington, described a group of patients with demyelinating diseases including MS who developed a series of severe streptococcal infections. In 1972 the virologist G.J. Barlow [38] at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington, made several attempts to reproduce the streptococcal infections by isolating strains of these bacteria and testing them on guinea pigs. He failed at this, and his failure in obtaining evidence of streptococcal infections did not deter him from his belief that the infection induced MS. In 1976, T.

Prompt: Question: Is the combination with 2-methoxyestradiol able to reduce the dosages of chemotherapeutices in the treatment of human ovarian cancer? Answer:
Response:
I.H.

Biology and the fight against cancer {#S1-1}
====================================

Neoplasms are defined as malignant (cancer) growths of the body, which can affect many organs. According to the World Health Organization\'s list, there are about 15.000 malignant tumors in humans ([@B2]), which means that there are more than one new tumor developing every minute. This is one of the most important reasons cancer is the leading cause of death in high-income countries and the second cause of death worldwide. Tumors can also be classified as benign (neoplasms) and borderline, that is they require further evaluation. However, for our purposes, we will concentrate exclusively on the term, tumor (malignant or benign). Due to the high incidence of cancer and the associated medical expenses, this is an important global issue. Although we can treat these tumors surgically, to date, there are no effective strategies available to combat or eradicate this group of neoplasms.

It is well known that many cancers are caused by genetic instabilities, which cause an accumulation of critical defects (mutations) within cells. Cancer appears to initially originate in a very small population of tumor cells that multiply very rapidly, outrunning the host\'s immune response that may have detected the tumors. However, the tumor cell then begins adapting to its new environment and, in doing so, it may become more aggressive. This adaptation process is called malignant transformation and is a key cancer hallmark. There are many signaling pathways where tumor progression is controlled and the most important of these are the *Oestrogen Receptor* (ER) and *Aryl Hydrocarbon Receptor* (AR). The estrogen pathway is active in breast, endometrial and ovary cancer \[for a review, see ([@B3], [@B4])\]. It is possible to suppress this pathway with aromatase inhibitors (AI) that block the aromatase enzyme. Aromatase is involved in the production of estrogens. Therefore, AI inhibit the production of estrogens or block the action of liganded ER. Tamoxifen is the drug of choice as an AI but its long-term use is limited.

The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) is a ligand-dependent transcription factor, which exists in three different forms: AHR itself, AhR nuclear translocator (ARNT) and xenobiotic sensing factor Xmaf (X), which, in turn, interacts with co-activators such as Xap/Parp and transcriptional co- repressors such as C/EBP, SMRT, and SHP \[for reviews see ([@B5]--[@B8])\]. It is not fully understood whether natural ligands for this receptor are produced by the host, or whether they are exogenous in origin. Although some ligands are well defined for the AHR, such as benzo\[α\]pyrene (BaP) or polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) \[for reviews, see ([@B8]--[@B10])\], others are still undefined. AHR binds its natural ligands with high affinity and acts as a transcription factor regulating genes involved in many different physiological functions, such as development, metabolism, cell cycle progression, apoptosis, cancer, neurobiology, innate immunity, inflammation, and wound healing \[for a discussion, see ([@B5], [@B11])\]. Therefore, it is the most important transcription factor in cancer. AHR also plays an essential role in the metabolism and detoxification of dietary chemicals, making AHRs target for xenobiotics. Hence, xenobiotic compounds can both signal to the AHR as well as interact with the AHRs and compete with natural AHR ligands causing receptor inactivation and promoting tumor cell proliferation \[reviewed in ([@B7], [@B12], [@B13])\]. AHR expression within malignant growths is higher than in the adjacent normal tissue \[see e.g., ([@B13], [@B14])\].

2-Methoxyestradiol: A new molecule with potential for cancer therapy {#S1-2}
====================================================================

2-Methoxyestradiol (2ME2) is the only natural AHR antagonist in clinical practice that has been identified thus far. Prompt: Question: Assessing joint line positions by means of the contralateral knee: a new approach for planning knee revision surgery? Answer:
Response:
The best way to assess the range of motion is to observe how the patient moves about and to make observations of the patient's knee during his normal course of activities including walking, sitting, and standing. In this regard, if the patient can be examined and the motion of the knee joint can be accurately assessed by observing him during his normal course of activities, the motion is best assessed; otherwise, the motion is inaccurately assessed. We cannot assess the range of motion by merely observing it as the patient is taking a prescribed walk on a level treadmill or is riding a stationary cycle; such a situation is inaccurate for measuring the range of motion. During the normal course of activities, the joint line position tends to deviate toward full extension (full extension). When measuring the range of motion from knee flexion to full extension, the joints are generally assumed to move in the following series of steps: 1. passive flexion without any resistance, 2. passive extension without any resistance, 3. passive flexion with the knee joint supported and, 4. passive extension while bearing some weight ([Fig. 3](#f3-etm-0-0-4948){ref-type="fig"}). For full passive flexion, the joint line is at the anatomic knee joint line. During active flexion and extension, the joint line position moves in accordance with the joint line of the healthy knee. When the joint line moves toward greater flexion, the joint line position is closer to the joint center; when the joint line moves toward greater extension, the joint line position is closer to the anatomic knee joint line. Joint line shifts often develop with respect to the anatomic knee joint line and the joint center due to joint deformity such as osteoarthritis, osteophyte formation, and ligament instability. Joint line shifts can be evaluated more consistently using a goniometer or a tensiometer that is an apparatus for measuring the amount of joint laxity in the ligaments or anterior cruciate ligament. In addition, the joint line position can be assessed more precisely using a navigation system or a diagnostic arthroscopy.

Joint line shifts can induce osteoarthritic change, and the osteoarthritic changes are characterized by subchondral sclerosis on the femur and tibia, osteophyte formation, and cartilage damage ([@b38-etm-0-0-4948]). When the joint line is maintained at greater flexion (a flexion space) for a lengthy period of time, the joint line shifts closer to the joint center because osteoarthritic change starts to occur ([@b29-etm-0-0-4948]). If the joint line shifts toward greater flexion by the progression of osteoarthritic change, the joint line position becomes further apart from the joint center. In this regard, an intra-articular deformity in the knee joint can be improved by reducing this distance. Joint line shifts can also occur if the joint is too tight, which can induce the formation of joint scar tissue. If the joint scars are located on the distal third of the tibia, then a space can be opened and the distance from the joint center can be increased, which can ameliorate osteoarthritic changes ([@b39-etm-0-0-4948],[@b40-etm-0-0-4948]) ([Fig. 4](#f4-etm-0-0-4948){ref-type="fig"}).

6.. Factors influencing joint line displacement
===============================================

As already mentioned, when a joint line is positioned in a more distal location, it tends to be further away from the joint center, and the distance becomes gradually larger. This is because joint scars and the subchondral sclerosis increase as the joint is flexed; conversely, when the joint scars become larger and cartilage in the cartilage box is lost, the joint line shifts proximally ([@b7-etm-0-0-4948]). Various factors can cause this progressive change of joint line position. As an individual ages, there is a decrease in the cartilage volume in the articular cartilage and this may lead to the displacement of the joint line and the progression of osteoarthritic changes. In particular, the subchondral area in the femur becomes thinner and the subchondral sclerosis becomes thicker as an individual becomes older. Joint scars are frequently observed and are mainly located in the proximal areas of the joint; the femoral cartilage tends to become thinner, and this induces the development of joint scars. When joint scars emerge, the subchondral sclerosis becomes thicker and the cartilage volume in the femur is reduced, and, thereby, the joint line is displaced distally ([@b39

Prompt: Question: Does the type of tibial component affect mechanical alignment in unicompartmental knee replacement? Answer:
Response:
Yes, the type of component is critical. In our analysis we found that the most distal femur-tibial angle had a statistically significant effect on the overall postoperative range of motion, lateral patellar displacement and tibiofemoral rotation. The anterior tibial slope was found to be statistically significant for tibiofemoral rotation. In our multi-variate analysis we found a statistically significance effect of the distal femur-tibial angle on mechanical alignment \[[@R36]\].

The ideal rotational position of tibial components influences the overall range of motion as well as the displacement of the lateral patellar margin \[[@R37]\]. In uni-compartmental knee replacement, the tibial component is fixed at a rotational angle of 13° to the sagittal plane and the femoral component rotation at 30°. A too high rotational position of the tibial component is associated with excessive load at the menisci, due to increased rotation. In contrast, a too low rotational position of the tibial component results in an increased subluxation of the lateral patellar facet. The distal femur-tibial angle of 115° results in the best range of motion, lateral displacement of less than 1 mm and rotation of 30 degrees.

Range of motion
---------------

### In revision TKA

The most accepted standard for measuring the range of motion (ROM) is the straight-leg raise test (SLR) \[[@R38]\], where the knee is fully extended. However, in most studies, the flexed position is used in order to avoid the effects of femoral lengthening \[[@R25]\]. The most commonly used position is 90° of flexion, although this study demonstrated a statistically significant lower flexion angle of the implant in Group 3 in our multi-model comparison analysis. This would result in a theoretically larger and more stable tibial implant in Group 3.

The SLR test, which is performed on healthy subjects, has shown high intra-rater and inter-rater reliability. A systematic review of this test on patients with TKA showed that the reliability measures did not fall below 80% \[[@R39]\]. Our data analysis also showed a good agreement, with a kappa of κ = 0.68 for the 90° SLR test.

All SLR tests showed a high reliability, which is associated with a good patient understanding of the test. There are no other studies that have investigated the intra-rater and inter-rater reliability of the 90° flexed SLR test.

The SLR is commonly performed on both the uninjured and the operated knee. In this study, the SLR of the TKAs were performed on the non-operated knee. This enabled a more natural positioning of the knee, which is the most important factor during the test. This enabled a correct standard SLR assessment, which was confirmed by the test results of all patients.

Limitations
===========

A standard definition and implementation protocol was not followed while conducting this study. This was because all SLR tests were performed by physicians employed through the hospital and thus, were different than the testing protocol at our institution. Additionally, each test was performed using the same device by a single subject, in a single operating room. The only difference was in the use of a brace when performing the SLR.

Conclusion
==========

Our in vivo study demonstrated that the range of motion was dependent not only on the type of implant, but also on the implant version (i.e. the medialization, distal translation, proximal translation or both).

None.

===================

The study was partially funded by a research grant from Stryker Corporation.

Conflict of Interest
====================

The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

Re-use is allowed. The s-aui-mousses.s.vu were kindly supplied by Stryker Corporation.

Prompt: Question: Is tumour expression of VEGF associated with venous invasion and survival in pT3 renal cell carcinoma? Answer:
Response:
Tumour expression of VEGF is only present in 23.2% of pT3 metastatic RCC, but this was not associated with more aggressive pathological features (venous invasion) or poor patient survival. This was the case even when the primary RCC were considered separately from the metastases.

*The prognostic significance of tumour biology, as reflected by tumour markers and tissue markers, in patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma remains a matter of ongoing debate.* We have previously shown[@ref1] that both expression of the proangiogenic and hypoxia pathways in primary RCCs correlate, at least at the protein level of VEGF and HIF1α, with venous invasion and metastatic progression. Tumour cell expression of VEGF correlated with both pV and pM but did not predict early distant metastasis in a subgroup of tumours without metastasis[@ref1]. Similarly, tumour cell expression of HIF1α correlated with venous invasion and metastases but was not associated with early distant metastasis in a subgroup of renal tumours with no metastasis at diagnosis. Furthermore, the expression levels of hypoxia-inducible proteins were found not to correlate with survival in a group of patients where most were already metastatic[@ref2] or to be significant after adjusting for metastasis[@ref3]. The prognostic significance of hypoxic markers in renal metastatic disease has also been examined by another group[@ref4]. In summary, there is no overall evidence from the literature that VEGF and HIF1α are predictors of survival in renal cell patients with metastatic disease. This has also been demonstrated by other series[@ref5][@ref6][@ref7].

With regard to lymphangitic carcinomatosis, an independent prognostic biomarker has also been suggested[@ref8]. The reported incidence of lymphangitic RCC at presentation is 0.3-6%[@ref8][@ref9], thus the majority of patients with metastatic RCC do not present with this feature. In any case, although in a subset of patients RCC with lymphangitic carcinomatosis may present with synchronous metastases, this subset will be very small and the prognostic significance in this group will be even smaller.

In this study, we focused on whether tumour (tumour cell) expression of VEGF and HIF1α was associated with aggressive pathological features, as defined as extention, venous invasion and/or lymph node involvement, in patients with pT3 metastatic RCC and what impact this might have on survival.

Material & Methods {#sec1-2}
==================

This cohort study was carried out in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by the South East Wales Research Ethics Committee. Formalin-fixed paraffin embedded primary and metastatic renal cell tumour tissue collected with patient informed consent were retrieved from the Tissue Bank at The Institute of Cancer Research, London, UK. The histopathological subtypes of the primary tumours were grouped according to the 2004 World Health Organization classification of tumours of the kidney and, in cases where the tumours were metastatic, whether they were from a known or unproven primary tumour. Of the 732 primary renal tumours studied, 658 (90.6%) were clear cell and 53 were papillary subtypes. VEGF and HIF1α expression was correlated with both tumour grade and stage according to the 2004 WHO classification and pathologic, prognostic and survival variables. The survival analysis was carried out retrospectively using data from the Cancer Registry. All deaths and censoring were recorded on or before 31 March 2010. The survival times were calculated between the date of diagnosis and the date recorded as the cause of death, or the date of the last follow-up visit, whichever came first. All patients were followed up at 4-6 monthly intervals for the first month, at then approximately 6 monthly intervals until a second metastasis was recorded or until the patient died, as the case may be. Patients identified as having developed RCC were censored when they were last seen in the UK, that is when the data for cause of death in the Cancer Registry were final. Overall patient and tumour survival (as well as metastasis-free survival) were analysed using the Kaplan-Meier statistics to produce log-rank statistics. Only pT3 RCC metastatic cases were analysed.

Immunohistochemistry was carried out as previously described[@ref10]. The antibodies used for the detection of VEGF and HIF1α are detailed in *Table*. In brief, anti-VEGF antibody was from Dako, clone A-2

Prompt: Question: Injury and poisoning mortality among young men--are there any common factors amenable to prevention? Answer:
Response:
Yes.
This paper investigates the occurrence of suicide after head/neck/brain injury. A search of hospital emergency departments for diagnoses of accident or poisoning for the years 1999-2006 was conducted for individuals aged 14 to 29 years. Individuals were cross-matched to deaths in the 2006 National Violent Death Reporting System and the National Violent Death Reporting System was searched for individuals that may have had another head injury/poisoning during the year prior to death. There was a significantly higher mortality for individuals with head/brain/neck injury than expected. The odds of suicide for this group were 5.1 times higher than for non-injury group, and 2.1 times higher than the non-poison group. The mortality after head/brain/neck injury was greater for males, older ages, white race, and for those from a rural residence, and this may be an indicator of suicidal behavior. This is the first study to suggest a relationship between suicide and head/neck/brain injury. The finding of higher suicide rates suggests that suicide is one possible negative outcome occurring from head/neck/brain injury. Suggestions about mechanisms for these relationships are discussed in the conclusion.

In the following excerpts, Thomas discusses the importance of informed consent, including its relationship with informed refusal.

Thomas J. Auchincloss, M.D.

"The ability of a physician to treat a patient, while preserving his or her health is a significant and fundamental right. For this right to function, a physician must be given the right to make the fundamental and life-and-death decisions entrusted to him or her by the patient. In carrying out this function, the physician must be afforded the latitude, if not the right, to make decisions which will require informed consent in a general sense; that is, he or she must have more information than is ordinarily given to enable him or her to make a decision. Indeed, he or she must know more, in a general sense, about the patient's health and condition than the patient usually chooses to reveal and be informed by. This is true but particularly so at times of great vulnerability--and for women faced with a serious obstetric complication such as pre-eclampsia.

At this point, it is probably important for me to first delineate what it is that the physician can and cannot do. In a general sense, the physician can examine the patient, make a diagnosis, administer pharmacologic, pharmacokinetic, and pharmacodynamic treatments, and use clinical and laboratory data in diagnosis; can examine the patient's family members and consult the family's physician if needed; and can advise the family regarding the nature and likely course of illness, prognosis, and treatment modalities and plan. It should be recognized that, within the realm of reason, the physician can do virtually everything except offer the patient abortion. For this right, a decision to abort must be made by the patient or by family if the patient is incompetent.

It has been my experience that an informed consent is necessary when the patient is an adult because the physician then has the right to administer or perform any treatment not excluded by a patient's physical or mental condition and which could result in or cause death. Because a pregnant woman is, in most cases, a ward of the state and subject to laws regulating a person's consent to a person's treatment or surgery, the nature of informed consent necessarily changes. Informed consent is not merely a check-the-box procedure. Because we must preserve the best interest of the mother and prevent unnecessary harm, the mother's best interest, by definition, must be a part of the consent process.

For this reason, I believe that in determining whether or not informed consent should be obtained within a reasonable period of time, the physician's exercise of professional judgment must be given weight in a large measure. However, because of the potentially high medical risk and the importance of this life choice and the mother's right to make it for herself or to seek consultation with the patient's family. I think that the physician should give the patient as much time as a reasonably prudent patient would have in selecting the course of treatment should the mother or the fetus or both be threatened.

It is also important to note that an abortion is not always an irrevocable choice. In a patient in pre-eclampsia or eclampsia, it is appropriate for the physician to suggest that the decision of the patient to continue or to terminate the pregnancy should be reached within a given time period. I have found this quite effective with patients who appear to be at real risk of irreverence, where we could suggest that it is important for you to make this decision as soon as possible. We have tried to explain to, and educate our patients on this issue in all ways imaginable and, when it seemed to me that the women were genuinely interested in this opportunity, I have asked them to make a very important decision so that they could think about it.

However, I must recognize the rights of the doctor to make a decision in regard to the risks assumed because I have had patients who were so frightened of the risks of pre-eclampsia and eclampsia that it was necessary to terminate the pregnancy to allow them time to adjust to the risks of the alternative of carrying the pregnancy to term. Therefore, if the patient requests a time period of from one to three days in determining the choice of treatment, the patient might be told the decision will be reached by such time, but that the patient could always change the decision at any time. In fact, while the doctor is trying to preserve the patient's life, it is equally important to the physician not to intrude the medical choices on the patient.

I believe, and this seems true to me, at the most critical point for pre-eclampsia, that the patient should know why she is being told

Prompt: Question: Does either obesity or OSA severity influence the response of autotitrating CPAP machines in very obese subjects? Answer:
Response:
No, obesity does not seem to play a role in CPAP response.

Question: Is there a difference in the effectiveness of CPAP in children? Answer: CPAP is a validated and widely used method of treating OSA in adult patients. In children, it has been shown to improve the quality of life and reduce the risk factors of OSA. There is no difference between children and adults with OSA whether the CPAP machine is manual or automatically adjusting based on the patient?s breathing.

Question: What is the effectiveness of CPAP in OSA patients with co-existing OSA and hypertension? Answer: CPAP is as effective in the absence of co-existing OSA as in those with this condition. CPAP treatment improves the cardiovascular condition in this group of patients also, so CPAP should be an integral part of any treatment of severe OSA with hypertension.

Question: Where can one find studies on the efficacy of CPAP in OSA patients on the transplant list? Answer: Studies are scarce of this particular group of patients. We have limited data of the efficacy of CPAP in improving quality of life and reducing the risk factors of complications of OSA.

Question: Would CPAP improve the condition of OSA patients on chemotherapy? Answer: Yes, CPAP has been shown to improve the quality of life of patients with OSA, regardless of the mode of administration.

Questions: Would CPAP improve the condition of OSA patients with co-existing obstructive lung diseases? Answer: If the co-existing obstructive lung disease does not affect respiratory compliance, respiratory muscle strength or the overall respiratory drive and the CPAP works well during the day then CPAP is likely to improve the condition.

Question: Would CPAP improve the condition of OSA patients with co-existing cardiovascular diseases? Answer: If the co-morbid conditions do not disturb cardiovascular function, CPAP should have beneficial effects.

Question: Do OSA patients on non-invasive ventilation (NIV) require CPAP to achieve benefits? Answer: NIV has been shown to be equally effective in decreasing the nocturnal hypoxemia as CPAP. When both are used, CPAP should be the first choice of therapy.

Question: Does CPAP cause or increase gastroesophageal reflux or aspiration? Answer: The most common side-effect of CPAP is hiccups. Hiccups have been observed in 1 - 5% of patients on CPAP. Occasionally this resolves spontaneously, so no specific intervention is usually required. If CPAP is associated with reflux symptoms then oral hygiene and the use of antacids should be improved. In chronic users aspiration pneumonia could result.

Question: Are there any complications in patients receiving CPAP for OSA during pregnancy? Answer: CPAP is a safe and beneficial therapy in pregnancy. There are no specific complications specific to CPAP. However, the risk of falling and the risk of aspiration in pregnancy are increased with CPAP. Thus regular assessment of the risks and benefits of CPAP should be done.

Questions: Is CPAP the only way to detect SDB in patients with an unstable airway? Answer: CPAP is the only method which can detect SDB in patients with an unstable airway and the majority of such patients are not able to tolerate an arterial blood gas. However, in these patients, in most instances the underlying condition warrants other investigations such as an exercise test, bronchoscopy, CT scan of chest or a sleep study.

Question: Can CPAP be used in patients with snoring without SDB? Answer: CPAP can be used in patients who are snoring, but have no sleep apnea and no significant airway resistance. Snoring does not, by itself, necessarily mean SDB.

Question: Can obese patients be treated effectively with CPAP? Answer: Obesity does not appear to be a contraindication to CPAP, but patients have to be informed of the CPAP technique and compliance in this group of patients may be difficult.

Question: Will the use of CPAP increase the risk of developing arrhythmias? Answer: During treatment, an EKG should be performed to detect any arrhythmias, and if any abnormalities are detected treatment should be modified. CPAP can cause an arrhythmia known as a URTI. However, if the patient is on a rate controlled pacemaker this arrhythmia is less likely to occur.

Question: Is there a limit to the duration of CPAP, when should treatment be considered a complete failure? Answer: Most studies have shown a median duration of CPAP treatment of at least one year. In case of treatment failure a trial of nasal expiratory positive airway pressure may be attempted.

Prompt: Question: Does the clinical presentation of a prior preterm birth predict risk in a subsequent pregnancy? Answer:
Response:
This is a question that is debated in the literature with a lack of consensus. However, a prior preterm birth increases the rates of prematurity (before 37 weeks) and the rate of early- and late-onset spontaneous preterm birth.[@bib1]^,^[@bib2] Although there is considerable evidence to suggest a decreased but still high rate of preterm birth, it is still unclear if that risk is different among prior preterm birth.[@bib1]^,^[@bib2] There is also an established association between prior preterm low birth weight and future low birth weight.[@bib3] However, the effect size in relation to low birth weight delivery is small.[@bib3] For instance, the risk for low birth weight prior to 37 weeks' gestation is approximately 5% vs 1% in a term birth.[@bib4] Another important factor to consider is the risk of neonatal death prior to 37 weeks' gestation, being 1.5% vs 0.6% in a term birth.[@bib4] The reason for this lower rate is that preterm neonatal death in an earlier gestation reduces the likelihood of an earlier (but not necessarily earlier) full term birth, which is associated with an increased risk of neonatal death. Other obstetric risk factors, such as chorioamnionitis and maternal hypertension, are also associated with an increased rate of preterm low birth weight in subsequent pregnancy.[@bib3] The risk of low birth weight beyond 37 weeks, as well as early neonatal death, is also higher in relation to prior singleton preterm low birth weight.[@bib5] The risk of spontaneous preterm labor after 34 weeks of gestation is 1.4% to 2%, which is not significantly different from that of term gestation.[@bib4]^,^[@bib5] Preterm labor following a prior preterm birth is largely a result of uterine activity and does not suggest placental insufficiency by itself.[@bib3] It is well established that prior pregnancy loss is a key risk factor for subsequent pregnancies among as well as among patients without a prior history of pregnancy loss. Previous studies in pregnant patients with uterine anomalies, such as unicornuate uterus, have found an increased risk of preterm birth and pregnancy loss.[@bib6]

Case Report {#sec1}
===========

A previously healthy, multiparous 32-year-old Gravida 3, Para 0 was cared for by me with a chief complaint of irregularly bleeding for 9 days. She reported 1 previous uterine evacuation at 9 weeks' gestation after a second-trimester suction curettage and cervical cerclage done for spontaneous preterm labor at 26 weeks' gestation. Her delivery was complicated by a breech presentation, which was spontaneously converted to a vertex posterior view. Her delivery course was unremarkable except for episiotomy done for perineal laceration repair. Her cervical suture did not prevent posterior labor and delivery at 37 weeks and 6 days' gestation after active pushing efforts of her caregiver, a family member.

On physical examination, she had a soft, non-tender cervix, and a well-healed episiotomy. I was asked to perform a curettage for placenta previa, which was normal. Subsequently, she had intermittent uterine bleeding, which was associated with abdominal cramps and nausea and was relieved with 1-nitro-2-phenyl-3-indole-sodium (Nortriptyline HCl \[Cesamet\]) at 50 mg.

Given her risk of subsequent preterm labor, my clinical suspicion was that she might have a history of preterm birth before the current pregnancy. I performed a chorionic villus sampling (CVS), and the result showed a normal amniocentesis. However, there were no signs of placental pathology, such as increased fibrosis, vascular sclerosis, and decidual arteriolar thrombi.

Given her prior obstetric history, I wanted to offer fetal surveillance and a repeat amniocentesis to rule out preterm labor. The obstetrician was consulted, and she decided to perform a repeat amniocentesis for fetal Down syndrome screening.

On the ultrasound examination, there was no fetal cardiac activity but there were 3 fetal movements with a crown-rump length of 20 mm. The fetal heart rate amplitude was normal. In comparison, the ultrasound examination in our previous CVS report showed 4 fetal heart rate accelerations, the largest peak of 8 mm/s, a cardiac activity, and a normal fetal movement index.

I explained the risks, benefits, and alternatives to her. She opted for a repeat amniocentesis

Since 1988 only three teams have won the AL-wildcard,

Prompt: Question: Aripiprazole: a new risk factor for pathological gambling? Answer:
Response:
no, it’s not.

As reported in the journal Addiction, people who self-medicated before they went to an emergency department (ED) were more likely to report that their ED visit followed an episode of problem alcohol use – or that they drank alcohol prior to the ED visit – relative to people who were not seeking treatment.1 Those more likely to drink in emergency situations are also more likely to have other substance use problems, which in turn can lead to greater health risks. What this study didn’t show was that this pattern of drinking before an ED visit was actually related to developing a new, more severe gambling problem.

This small study was part of a larger clinical trial involving people who had a previous diagnosis of substance use disorder, and were trying to stop their substance use. Researchers followed them for 18 months, and used a series of questionnaires to track the substance use patterns of almost 400 participants.

The researchers used these scores to identify people whose risk of addiction declined after they stopped engaging in their past drinking behavior (ie, people who had a period during which their risk of addiction was decreased), as well as those whose risk of addiction increased after they stopped that drinking behavior (ie, people whose risk of addiction increased during this time). The study did not examine the potential contribution of a new or more severe gambling problem to this behavior, and we do not know why any particular individual in the study might have one outcome relative to the other.

These are important issues to consider for several reasons. First, understanding if one’s substance use before an ED visit might have contributed to a new problem, even if indirectly, does not mean that substance use or other unhealthy behaviors have contributed to one’s gambling disorder. Second, the question of whether someone has a new, more severe gambling problem might be hard to answer. Third, any new gambling problem might have led to different substance use problems down the road.

I found the study informative from the following points of view:

Many people who are seeking treatment for their substance use problems have also been diagnosed with someone else’s: this was shown by this research, as well as by a large number of studies that have demonstrated that people with gambling disorder are also more likely to have another substance use problem. This is not surprising: both substance use and gambling can cause people to engage in unhealthy behaviors. I wonder if this is another example of the compulsive behaviors of addiction (ie, engaging in one behavior to control another) often occurring simultaneously. For example, people who develop substance use problems and those who develop gambling problems may have an increased risk of developing other compulsive behaviors like eating problems or sexual addictions. These people are at even greater risk for a whole array of other health risks, which could explain why this combination is associated with so many of the health, criminal/delinquency, and legal problems that people with gambling disorder and substance use problems so often experience. We know that people with substance use problems that aren’t severe enough to be diagnosed with substance use disorder are also at greater risk for other, more serious health problems. They’re also more likely to develop anxiety disorders, depression, and sleep disorders. I’ve seen many clinical reports that demonstrate that people who are able to engage in “substance use disorder recovery” (that is, reduced use of a substance) usually have reduced physical/mental health problems. For example, one study found that people with cocaine use disorder who are in long-term residential treatment are only 1.7 times more likely than people who use other drugs to develop anxiety or depression. Another study found that individuals with alcohol use disorder who are abstinent are only 10.3 percent more likely to develop major depressive syndrome than people in the general population. More clinical reports documenting the success of treatment for these problematic substances are sure to be forthcoming, and the findings from this study are likely to be replicated.

Some people who use substances as a form of self-medication develop a more persistent substance use problem, and it would be reasonable to postulate that some of these people will develop a gambling disorder. However, we don’t know if this is what happened in any participant in this study.

In the discussion of the authors, a statement said:

The relative increases in the relative risk of developing an alcohol problem among those who used substances before visiting the ED also remained significant after adjustment for potential confounders. The association between ED visiting with a substance problem and the subsequent development of an addiction to that drug was only moderately attenuated by our inclusion of a variable for baseline past substance use intensity.

What this means is that the substance use problems before the ED visit (self-medication) accounted for a small part of this relationship that is “moderately attenuated by our inclusion of a variable for baseline past substance use intensity.”

Prompt: Question: Immune suppression by lysosomotropic amines and cyclosporine on T-cell responses to minor and major histocompatibility antigens: does synergy exist? Answer:
Response:
Probably not.
The present article reviews a hypothesis that has dominated the last few years of research on immunosuppression in rheumatic diseases. The hypothesis is based on the premise that lysosomotropic amines (which act by increasing intra-lysosomal pH) have little activity against human peripheral blood T-cells, yet they are effective in animal models of immunity. It is proposed that only cyclosporine (which acts by inhibiting a key component of T-cell activation) interferes with lymphocyte maturation, because it can enter lysosomes. This implies that in vivo use of lysosomotropic amines may exert additive or antagonistic effects on cell-mediated immune responses. In the present article, however, this hypothesis is questioned. On the basis of the evidence available, it is concluded that (a) cyclosporine at low nanomolar concentrations can depress peripheral blood and bone marrow T-cell function; (b) lysosomotropic amines and cyclosporine can act simultaneously; (c) lysosomotropic amides can act synergistically with cyclosporine; (d) the therapeutic effectiveness of lysosomotropic amines at clinical dosages may only reflect their ability to block lymphocyte maturation, leaving immunosuppressive activity by cyclosporine unchanged; and (e) cyclosporine does not prevent the immunosuppressive effects of lysosomotropic amines. Although cyclosporine and lysosomotropic amines alone and combination of several pharmacologic agents can depress cellular immune function, this does not mean that they exert a synergistic immunosuppressive effect. The final word on this matter is perhaps more complex than many in the field would have us believe. The results of this study show that cyclosporine can depress T-cell function when used at nanomolar concentrations, while doses that have been associated with clinical efficacy inhibit antibody responses to certain antigens. The therapeutic effects of lysosomotropic amines and cyclosporine alone reflect their capacity to influence lymphocyte maturation, rather than exerting additive or synergistic immunosuppressive effects in vivo. The data presented here suggest that the ability of cyclosporine to suppress humoral immune responses may be, at least in part, independent of its immunosuppressive properties against T-cells. This suggests that clinical situations requiring the combination of immunosuppressive and immunostimulatory agents should be approached with caution, if possible, and with great care.

Prompt: Question: Does induction chemotherapy have a role in the management of nasopharyngeal carcinoma? Answer:
Response:
The evidence of this question for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is based on case series and meta-analysis reports. The current evidence supports combining induction chemotherapy (IC) and concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) but no consensus has yet been reached on which IC regimen would be best. Conventional chemotherapy is not considered a standard of care for NPC.

Introduction

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is an epithelial cancer of the upper aerodigestive tract whose incidence in most countries is between 10 and 20 per 100,000 per year. It is the commonest cancer of the nasopharynx accounting for more than 40% of all neoplasms of the pharynx. The etiology is uncertain, but Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in association with genetics has been implicated.[1,2]

Tumour pathology is characterized by epithelial type II carcinoma arising within the nasopharyngeal polyps and areas of squamous metaplasia or hyperplasia, and lymphoepithelioma-like type I tumours arising in the adjacent lymphoid tissue.[3] The International Society of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma has defined the TNM staging of NPC as follows: T0, no tumour; TN1, tumour restricted to nasopharynx[3,4]; T2, local tumour with extension into one of the paranasal sinuses[5]; T3, local tumour which has extended into the neighboring structures (pharynx, skull, hard palate, temporal bone, sphenoid sinus, orbit, pterygopalatine fossae)[5]; T4, local tumour which has extended into the clivus and/or cavernous sinus[2] or intracranially. N0, no nodal involvement.

There can also be a locally recurrent disease following primary treatment (T4 N0 and some patients with T4 N+). A sub-group of patients (2-5% of all patients) present with regional or distant metastases (M1) at diagnosis, termed non-keratinizing undifferentiated, EBV-positive NPC. Tumor cell type and pattern of invasion, as well as the status of EBV, influence the risk of metastases in undifferentiated NPC.[6]

The recommended therapeutic approach is primary radiotherapy as reported by the International Society of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma.[7] However, this approach is now being challenged by the incorporation of more active systemic agents and the use of adjuvant chemotherapy with or without concurrent radiotherapy.

This review outlines the current evidence relating to the treatment of NPC.

Prevalence of Lymph Node Involvement in Stage III

Lymph node involvement in stage III was reported in approximately 25% of patients (15-40%) treated at radiotherapy centres in North America, Japan and Taiwan (see Table 1).[8] However, when it was investigated in patients treated in a single South Korean institution, it was reported to be higher (45%).[9] In a large study that used endoscopy to detect sentinel lymph node (SLN), the SLN-positive rate was 35% even among patients with stage III disease. However, nodal metastasis did not seem to influence survival in this group of patients.[10] There could be a difference in the rate of nodal metastases among centers based on practice pattern and experience with lymphadenectomy, and a further difference in the quality of the pathologists at different centers where the sentinel nodes were harvested and processed. As a result, nodal involvement may be more common in certain centers.[11]

Studies on the efficacy of IC

A review of 37 series with a total of 3,824 patients reported an overall response rate of 76% in stage I-III disease (see Table 2 & Table 3).[12] The addition of cisplatin led to a significantly better overall response (85% vs 70%). As discussed in the questions section, there are a number of regimens available for the induction of chemotherapy.

The combination of cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without an additional agent such as docetaxel (TPF) has been most commonly used. The addition of cisplatin for IC was associated with significant improvements in overall response rates and disease-free survival (DFS) but not overall survival (OS) or cancer-related mortality over TPF.

The results of meta-analysis of 13 trials that compared cisplatin-based chemotherapy for IC compared to TPF demonstrated a trend toward improved response rates and DFS, and better overall survival [hazard ratio (HR) 0.76, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.

Prompt: Question: Treatment of contralateral hydrocele in neonatal testicular torsion: Is less more? Answer:
Response:
It depends on you

by

Dino Kuzmanovic FRCPE, FRCS (Gen Sur), FRCS (Edin)

Question: Treatment of contralateral hydrocele in neonatal testicular torsion: Is less more? Answer: It depends on you

Introduction {#s001}
============

Testicular torsion is the most common cause of acute scrotum in adolescence, which has a high incidence during the neonatal period.^[@B1]^ Although it is known that the testicle is the only scrotal organ that is dependent on blood supply from the epididymis, the mechanism responsible for development of a contralateral hydrocele after torsion in the neonatal period is unknown. Contralateral hydrocele in neonates is a benign process, which may be associated with intrascrotal tumors, such as epidermoid cysts, teratoma, lipoma, dermoid cyst, and even vascular tumors.^[@B2],[@B3]^ A small size contralateral scrotal varicocele is another cause of a contralateral hydrocele in fetuses.^[@B4]^ We encountered one rare case of a contralateral hydrocele in a neonate with acute testicular torsion. A surgical excision of the scrotal varicocele was performed and no other tumor occurred during a 3-year follow-up period.

Case Presentation {#s002}
=================

The patient was a neonate delivered from a healthy nonwhite mother (G2P1). Apgar scores were 8 for 8 and 10 for 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. At birth, the baby had a large mass of his left testis that was palpable in his left inguinal canal. The mass started to enlarge gradually and became hard on examination later on. On the day of birth, the mass was removed laparoscopically, and no tumor was found inside the testes. Because of the absence of palpable tumors, at age 3 weeks, the neonate underwent an open orchidopexy for a normal contralateral testis, under general anesthesia. We had planned an orchidopexy within 2 weeks after birth because initial scrotal examination suggested that the enlarged left testis was a tumor ([Table 1](#T1){ref-type="table"}). At age 10 days, the patient presented at our emergency room, complaining that the left testicle was swollen gradually and that he was painless to touch. On physical examination, the left testis had increased in size, was hard, and was fixed in the left inguinal canal with a nontender axillosubclavian mass. He was examined under general anesthesia in the supine position, and the left testis was removed by an inguinal approach. No testicular torsion was detected. There was a scrotal varicocele on the ipsilateral side, and the right testicle and epididymis were normal, as confirmed by surgery ([Fig. 1](#f1){ref-type="fig"}). The histologic examination of the left testis showed no evidence of tumor. In the immediate postoperative period, the patient had a scrotal swelling, with a right-to-left difference of 15%--20%, and ultrasound tests of the left testis showed an enlarged testis in agreement with the above findings. Surgery was performed at age 10 days under general anesthesia again by an inguinal approach via an incision along the medial surface of the left testis. The findings were similar to those of the first operation. No abnormality was found in the right testis and epididymis. The left side had a scrotal varicocele that was excised, and there was no torsion or abnormality of the testes, epididymis, blood vessels, or other structures. No hydrocele was observed during postoperative follow-up.

Torsion of the Testicles

Prompt: Question: Is it Crohn's disease? Answer:
Response:
We don't know.

Question: What is the best treatment for Crohn's disease? Answer: There is no one "best" treatment for Crohn's disease. Some treatments work for some people and not for others. Some treatments work for your pain, some for your inflammation, and some for your depression.

People with Crohn's disease, also called inflammatory bowel disease, also sometimes called IBD, have pain, swelling, redness, blood, diarrhea, fatigue, loss of appetite or weight, and abnormal results on blood and urine tests. Symptoms are not seen in everyone with Crohn's. Most people with the disease have pain, but about half have only pain, with no other symptoms, or have non-pain symptoms, such as fever or swollen glands.

Tests and Tests

Doctors take a lot of tests to try to find out what is causing the disease and what kind of treatment works best. Some tests or tests are good to diagnose inflammation in the bowel, determine how far the disease is spread, and help plan a treatment. Some tests or lab tests help doctors decide the best treatment for your symptoms.

Labs

Doctors often call these blood and urine tests labs. Blood tests look for signs of infection and help find out if your organs are working well. The other common test or lab test is called CRP or C-reactive protein, which is an inflammation marker.

Tests in the intestines are called endoscopic exams. This test takes about 30 minutes and is done in a hospital or a research facility, or in an endoscopy center, to look at the inflamed intestines and the lining of the intestines. With this test, doctors look at the inside of the intestine to see what you have.

The intestine is normally lined with different kinds of cells that allow water to leave the body and food to go in. In Crohn's the lining is thin and has lots of pockets that trap bacteria and other harmful agents, such as food or other things, such as medications. The lining can also look like a sponge with lots of small holes instead of having a smooth surface. Small holes let harmful digestive fluids and bacteria out of the body. Doctors usually remove a section of intestine for doctors to look at under a microscope (called tissue biopsy) to see how the inside lining looks.

Laparoscopy is a surgical procedure in which doctors can see inside a person's abdominal cavity through small laparoscope tubes. The procedure is usually done to find out how the lining is looking, to help stop the bleeding in a patient, to remove the lining in a patient to try to treat the disease, or to see what is going on inside, such as gallstones or a tumor. Laparoscopy is done in an outpatient surgery or hospital setting and takes about 20 to 60 minutes.

Abdominal X-ray is a simple, quick test. The doctor inserts a thin tube with an X-ray machine inside the person's abdomen. The X-ray machine looks at the tubes and bones in the abdomen, which can help find out what is wrong causing the disease. The results are viewed on an X-ray viewer. The results can't be saved and can't be seen without a machine. The tests to check the bones and digestive tract can't help a doctor decide the best treatment or work best to heal your disease. For example, doctors may take a colonoscopy to look at both the large intestines and small intestines to look for signs of disease.

Abdominal ultrasound is another test that doctors use to look for signs of Crohn's disease. It takes about 20 minutes and uses a small machine to look at the intestines.

Tests that measure chemicals in the body in response to a treatment or condition are called bioassays, or biologics. Doctors usually use biologics to see what your body thinks about a specific drug or therapy, to find out why your disease or pain is happening, and to help make a treatment plan for you. Examples of biologics are:

Disease markers

Disease markers include tests or markers that can be looked at to see if your disease is getting worse or better. Doctors use disease markers sometimes to make sure your disease is healing properly.

For example, when someone with Crohn's has a blood transfusion, doctors put tests in their blood to see if they make the proper blood group, or if they have the anti-Rh factor. To make sure the transfusion is working right, doctors monitor the patient for side effects, such as allergic reactions to the drugs.

Disease course markers

When someone has Crohn's disease, the condition can get better and worse, and some symptoms may be severe. Doctors use disease course markers to try to find and predict the disease's course. Disease course markers are tests or markers

Prompt: Question: Does multi-modal cervical physical therapy improve tinnitus in patients with cervicogenic somatic tinnitus? Answer:
Response:
It does not appear that there is effective evidence for treatment for tinnitus with multi-modal cervical physical therapy.

Tinnitus is a common type of disorder associated with somatic diseases that can often be difficult to manage \[[@CR1]\]. Tinnitus can also be caused by hearing loss, which in many cases, is the result of a somatic disorder \[[@CR2], [@CR3]\].

A large part of tinnitus patients present with cervical symptoms such as neck pain, limited motion, stiffness, and/or headache. Cervicogenic somatic tinnitus is defined as a combination of somatic factors of the head, neck, shoulders or back, either directly or indirectly, causing auditory disorder, usually a perception of noise in the ear (\[[@CR4]\] and reviewed in \[[@CR5]\]). Despite the common complaint of tinnitus in patients with neck pain, there is a paucity of evidence concerning the treatment of such patients. In a review of 12 articles, Güler and colleagues stated that tinnitus is associated with cervical spine pathology and that cervical pain induces tinnitus in many of the patients, especially at night. The results indicated that chronic pain patients are likely to have sleep disorders and to experience tinnitus (1). However, with respect to treatment, they concluded that the only evidence-based intervention that has been found to improve tinnitus is cognitive behaviour therapy. These researchers also stated that further investigation and clinical trials were warranted \[[@CR6]\].

In a recent published literature review, we found that none of the articles reported results consistent with the hypothesis that multi-modal cervical physical therapy might improve tinnitus \[[@CR7]\]. These findings were obtained after searching PubMed with the following search-terms alone or in combination: (tinnitus) AND (neck pain OR muscle OR joint OR spine OR joints) AND (therapy OR manipulation OR manipulation and exercise OR exercise OR manual OR manipulation and exercise OR manipulation exercise OR manipulation exercises OR motion OR mobilization OR exercise OR exercises OR manipulation physical therapy OR physical therapy OR cervical OR cervical movements OR stretching OR active OR active exercise OR active movement) limited to English and humans. We decided to perform another search update to identify new papers that might be eligible for inclusion in this meta-analysis and review.

This updated literature search was performed using the same search terms. The results are shown in an additional file (see Additional file [1](#MOESM1){ref-type="media"}: Appendix S1). We used the exact search strategy from the previously published paper that did not find any convincing evidence \[[@CR7]\]. The updated literature search also resulted in 11 articles, that are discussed in detail in a separate publication (\[[@CR5]\], Güler H, Gökçen S, Sümer N. Evidence-based approaches for patients reporting of cervical pain, fatigue, vertigo, and tinnitus. Manuscript submitted for publication in October 2016).

Treatment of cervical somatic tinnitus with a multimodal cervical PT program {#Sec1}
============================================================================

With an open, observational cohort and RCT study design, Oerlemans et al. \[[@CR5]\] first treated 26 somatically ill tinnitus patients with multi-modal cervical physical therapy by comparing a group of patients who completed the multimodal cervical PT program with a group of patients treated with sham (placebo) manipulation to determine the effects of the cervical PT program on tinnitus. To assess the effectiveness of the PT interventions, the authors examined changes over time with respect to tinnitus intensity, and patients' self-rating of perceived relief related to tinnitus. The multimodal cervical PT intervention consisted of 10 sessions over 1 week over a period of 6 weeks. The authors reported a statistically significant improvement in tinnitus on the tinnitus questionnaire (TQ) \[[@CR8]\]. The sham manipulation consisted of four sessions, two to three times a week. The sham treatments consisted of active joint mobilizations with the purpose of stimulating the local tissue, combined with stretching of the soft tissues. The authors further claimed that the multi-modal cervical PT program was able to improve tinnitus by normalizing the cervical muscles.

One limitation of the Oerlemans et al. study was that the authors did not evaluate the effect of the applied treatment on clinical measures other than tinnitus. In addition, they limited the study to patients with cervical somatic tinnitus, a condition that should be further investigated.

In a randomised, placebo-controlled clinical trial, Zierler et al. \[[

Prompt: Question: Detailed analysis of sputum and systemic inflammation in asthma phenotypes: are paucigranulocytic asthmatics really non-inflammatory? Answer:
Response:
Inflammatory subphenotypes
The asthmatic airway has distinct structural and physiological features leading to increased airway and system responsiveness and hyperresponsiveness to a broad range of stimuli. Several clinical and laboratory parameters have been described to characterize distinct subsets of asthma with varying levels of airways and systemic inflammation, referred to as subphenotypes of asthma. Several sputum and systemic inflammatory indices have been used to describe distinct subphenotypes of asthma, yet the reproducibility and predictive validity of these various approaches has been questioned. Recent clinical trials have shown that the addition of novel systemic inflammatory indices to classic markers such as fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) may improve our ability to predict asthma disease outcome, but this approach has not been directly tested in the non-steroidal, inhaled, controller-treated, mild-to-moderate, adult asthmatic patient population. In the absence of high-quality evidence of their predictive validity, we will demonstrate herein that subphenotype definition needs to be carefully considered and that additional studies on the use pf novel inflammatory indices for outcome prediction in asthma are necessary. These considerations are particularly pertinent to paucigranulocytic asthmatics, which we hypothesize are not truly non-inflammatory.

Prompt: Question: Is HIV/STD control in Jamaica making a difference? Answer:
Response:
Maybe, but not enough!

This question relates to the HIV/AIDS situation in Jamaica, which the World Health Organization says is a major public health issue, especially in the inner city. Jamaica's status as an island has given it an important role in addressing both HIV/AIDS and other health issues, but also makes it more difficult to address directly and immediately, but is it the only country in which this affects a large segment of the population?

Is Your Relationship Really A “Gay”Relationship?

Jamaica — a hot country with an almost unbelievably sexy climate; a gorgeous countryside where I was living and working in one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world; the island of my birth — in my heart and soul, Jamaica means Gay. After I moved there to work, my Gayness was challenged when we moved in with the woman (Jamaica’s cultural customs are different for Gay and straights alike) who has been my companion since we married almost three years ago, a friend I’ve known since she moved there to study and become a teacher.

I have lived in Jamaica for fourteen years now, and to use my Jamaican friends’ word, all of us Gay people who live in Jamaica are either “chocolate” or “chilli” — the latter being those who come from the mainland (and many Jamaicans are from the island of Antigua, which is like the Caribbean version of Massachusetts). But I did not call my long-time lover and we lived with for so many years “chocolate,” partly because it has no meaning in Jamaican English (it would have to be “carrot”), but mostly because we are not “gay friends.”

We love each other as we do all gay couples but that’s all that was, until recently – especially for her since she has been married for twenty-five years and has children. Even though I have been Gay since I was two years old, she started teaching and she was not ready to talk about it back then or to think about where I might live once I left her parents’ house because her children are already married, and her parents who are very religious were not in favor of my bringing a “strange” young man into the house and her life, so I stayed in the United States.

When I moved in with her, she knew that I was a Gay man, and she is a person of deep spiritual values. But in her life, God and His Word only came to mind when addressing her children’s well-being or when having an argument against or with her children’s father who divorced them and also left her with six children (for those of you who may be keeping track, that is six more children to raise by herself, by that I mean no “help” from anyone!), which is why God came, and was her first resort, even to the point that our relationship has been strained after I discovered that she had not been truthful to me as she thought she was and as she had been in the past.

A Gay Relationship Or A Lesbian Relationship?

As she started telling me her story and even when I heard some of the names being said out loud, my first reaction was one of surprise because it was not the first time that I had heard a “mixed marriage” term. The first time I heard it was from friends of my parents’ and I thought, what kind of people speak such vulgar and un-Gay words? Since, I was very young.

We used the terms “lesbian” and “gay”, even though they had not yet been invented. When we hear “lesbian” or “gay” in reference to people (mostly straight people), we all think that the person’s sexual preference is only for members of the same sex even though there are also straight couples who are “lesbians” and “gay” couples, but because we’re Gay, we know the difference — and that term was never a term that we ever addressed people in any way.

I don’t know how this came about, but when I met my wife in the United States while I was studying to become a teacher, it took me some months to accept that she was a lesbian because before meeting her in the United States, I never knew women to be “lesbians”… and so to accept it, I had to keep telling myself that the reasons why, she had had a male roommate while at the college and the only time she has seen another woman was when she was working at the beauty shop and had met a woman who told her that she was “gay” and had just found her way to

Prompt: Question: Is Panton-Valentine leucocidin associated with the pathogenesis of Staphylococcus aureus bacteraemia in the UK? Answer:
Response: We analysed national UK data since the introduction of phage therapy in 1958 to find a possible explanation of the high (5.5%) rate of Panton-Valentine leucocidin in S. aureus bloodstream isolates in the UK from 2010 to 2014. Panton-Valentine leucocidin was associated with meticillin resistance (OR 3.5, 95% CI 1.6-7.6) and with all comorbidities except for cardiac complications. Panton-Valentine leucocidin was particularly high (15.2%) in the young (age 0-4 years) with septic arthritis. The high Panton-Valentine leucocidin in septic arthritis might indicate the role of Panton-Valentine leucocidin in sepsis pathogenesis. The high rate of Panton-Valentine leucocidin together with the high prevalence of this bacteriophage in strains of Staphylococcus aureus from carriage in the UK population indicates a role for Panton-Valentine leucocidin in maintaining a reservoir of human staphylococcal strains that have the capacity to invade, destroy and cause sepsis. Further research, though, would need to address the potential role of Panton-Valentine leucocidin in sepsis and sepsis prophylaxis. Clinicians should be aware of this strain of Staphylococcus aureus in their practice.
