Prompt: Question: Does positron emission tomography change management in primary rectal cancer? Answer:
Response:
No.

Does positron emission tomography change management in primary rectal cancer?

The article “What do we still not know about positron emission tomography (PET) in primary rectal cancer?” by A. G. M. J. Schippers et al., published in the journal World Journal of Surgery in 2015, can be found under http://www.worldjuro.wjw.es/index.php/wjsm-vol-55-n-1/wjs-vol-55-n-1&viewmore=1.

“The management of primary rectal cancer has changed considerably. In 1980, rectal cancer was traditionally thought to be amenable primarily to abdominoperineal resection if curative intent was to be achieved, and this was the approach advised by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence. This has moved on to the fact that some rectal cancers are treated non-operatively, and there are some patients who are treated with limited resections or local excisions if this is indicated. The aim of this article is to determine what we know about positron emission tomography (PET) in the management of primary rectal cancer today. This review article collates data from original articles published between 2005 and 2013. It highlights what we do and don’t know about the use of PET scanning in the management of primary rectal cancer, and proposes future studies to address this knowledge gap.”The article by J. H. T. van Santvoort et al., “A critical study of the evidence for routine endorectal ultrasound and PET in the management of primary rectal cancer”, published in the journal Eurosurveillance in 2013, can be found under the following link: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleID...

“Routine endorectal ultrasound and PET in the management of primary rectal cancer”The article by A. G. M. J. Schipper et al., “The use of PET scanning in the management of primary rectal cancer: a critical study of the evidence”, published in 2013 in the Journal of European Surgeons, can be found under http://www.jes.or.kr/article/S0022-5347(13)01143-5/...

A lot has changed in the surgical management of rectal cancer in the last 30 years. In the UK approximately 13,000 patients are diagnosed with rectal cancer annually, and this number is increasing.1The surgical treatment of rectal cancer is based on the location of cancer and whether it is in the lower part of the rectum, middle part of the rectum or high up in the rectum. Surgery for rectal cancer used to be performed based on whether a tumour was near or away from the anal verge. The most important factor in deciding on surgical treatment was whether the tumour was mobile or fixed within the rectum. If a tumour was mobile (i.e. had a propensity to move) it was treated with abdominoperineal resection whilst if a tumour was fixed (i.e. not mobile) it was treated with endoscopic resections and other local resections such as local resection and radio frequency ablation. With advances in understanding of biology of cancer and developments in radiotherapy and chemotherapy a lot has changed in the treatment of rectal cancer. A number of studies have been conducted to determine the extent to which the outcome has improved through such changes. The European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) has conducted a study within Europe, the Rectal Cancer Trial Organisation (RE.CO.15–01), designed specifically to address these questions.2 In that study a randomised intervention was carried out for all patients with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the rectum or rectosigmoid junction between 1995 and 2009. The primary aim of the study was to assess the effect of adjuvant chemoradiotherapy after conventional surgery on tumour-free survival in patients with T3–4 tumours compared to patients treated on the basis of preoperative radiotherapy. The trial recruited 7,742 patients. It showed a significant reduction in local and distant recurrence after adjuvant chemoradiotherapy compared with preoperative radiotherapy without a survival benefit.3 However, the study failed to demonstrate a survival benefit in patients with T3 or T4 carcinoma of the rectum compared to those who had undergone surgical resection with the same chemotherapy. A number of studies have been published since to explore the potential benefit for patients with a high tumour load receiving adjuvant chemoradiotherapy rather than just preoperative radiotherapy.4–9 Although we now understand that patients with rectal cancer should be risk stratified,

Prompt: Question: Can you deliver accurate tidal volume by manual resuscitator? Answer:
Response:
Not quite.

Introduction: Tidal volume is the actual amount of air volume entering the alveoli during each exhalation. The recommended tidal volume during mechanical ventilation is 6-8mL/kg for infants under 1kg and 10-12mL/kg for infants over 1kg of predicted body weight. With manual resuscitators, we normally use 15 mL as the starting tidal volume for infants up to 7kg and 15-20mL for infants over 7kg.

Question: Can you deliver the same tidal volume with 3 different mechanical ventilator modes? Answer: Not at all

Introduction: Ventilation delivered by any mechanical ventilator uses a certain flow to move the gas through a specified area. The volume is then determined by the pressure applied at the ventilator\'s connection with the human airways. There are three types of mechanical ventilators: volume, time and pressure control mechanical ventilators.

We should know how to use each ventilator properly in specific scenarios.

Example: Pressure Control Mode (PC Mode) with PEEP (Positive End Expiratory Pressure)

Question: How can you use the PC mode for babies over 7kg?

Example 1: A 5 minute non-invasive pressure control with an initial pressure of 15 cm H2O. Pressures are maintained between 5-15 cm H2O while the baby is breathing on the ventilator with each breath. Once end expiratory pressure is reached, the inspiratory pressure is reduced by 10cm H2O for the next breath until 15cm H2O is reached again or the end of expiration has been reached. With this, the lungs will not be over compressed and can achieve 100% of resting tidal volume with the optimal amount of gas.

Example 2: Pressure control mode with a set pressure of 15cm H2O. The inspiration can continue for as long as desired. End expiratory pressure is set at the default value for the mode chosen. The ventilator will start to decrease the inspiration pressure towards 15cm, and when it reaches the target, it will stop at 15cm for the next breath.

Answer: Yes, the same principle can be applied to any mechanical ventilator. What is different is the way the pressure is set.

I think the same principle is applicable when a pressure control is used with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP). A good example is the Neonatal Resuscitation Program.

Question: When using pressure control volume mode, why is it that we are applying higher pressure for longer and shorter breaths? Answer: The shorter breaths will have the higher inspiratory pressure as desired. The lower pressure for longer breaths allow the babies to rest, thus less work is needed on their airways. But as long as we are aware of these principles, we can get the same goal.

Question: What are the advantages or disadvantages of Volume Control mode versus Time Control mode, and why should you use one over the other? Answer: Time-control mode is the mode that is recommended for neonates less than 1-3kgs of body weight. For babies over 1kg, the pressure-control mode is preferred. Volume control mode is more advanced; it has many features that are useful in preterm or chronic lung disease patients. These include volume guarantee and pressure guarantee. But this is not the only difference. Pressure control ventilator requires a lower inspiratory pressure to overcome the resistance and the work that we need to apply to the patient to achieve a given tidal volume. I believe the same principles can be applied with pressure control mode when used in time-control mode, but the setting of ventilator settings can be much more complicated. I think the benefit comes from the knowledge of how each mode works. Therefore, each mode has its respective advantages and disadvantages.

Question: Which is the most effective method for setting the initial ventilator settings? Answer: It is all about preference. You could choose either a pressure control or a volume control mode. Once you have decided on a mode, then the settings for pressure control should be set higher than the settings for volume control. This is when we would get to the point of choosing pressure or volume. If we have a lot of experience, for example the Neonatal Resuscitation Program, then we know that higher pressure for shorter breaths will save a lot of time and energy for the patient. But, if you are uncertain what the recommended settings will be, then we should just set the inspiratory pressure and inspiratory pressure duration (INSP) as high as we can. Remember that the higher the setting, the lower the work will be done on the baby\'s airway.

Prompt: Question: Can increases in the cigarette tax rate be linked to cigarette retail prices? Answer:
Response:
No! The tax rate increase is linked to tax receipts, and that is the only way that they are linked. Tobacco Control is about cigarette price (not tax) increases. When Congress first passed the tobacco control law in early 1997, it did so because it found that existing cigarette prices were too high. Since tobacco control is about cigarette prices, in addition to the cigarette-tax increase the tobacco control law also contains several specific price-retail restriction changes.

A higher Cigarette Tax Rate = More Cigarette Taxes. The 1997 tobacco control law changed the state-by-state cigarette tax rate structure from a 2 cents per pack levy to a 28 cents per pack levy (i.e., an increase from about 1.65% to about 3.26% tax rate). At the same time, the tobacco tax increase was removed from the federal law. And while the federal bill did contain specific price restrictions, Congress chose not to pass any price-restrictions contained in the House bill. The House's price-restriction proposals were not put in the bill in order for the White House to sign the bill into law.

In the summer of 1998, the Federal Government issued a statement saying that the specific price-restriction provisions that were contained in the tobacco control act were no longer part of the law (they were removed in the 1998-1999 tax bill). The law is now known as the Frank R. Lautenberg Comprehensive Tax and Health Care Reform Act, and the specific price-restrictions were contained in Title I of that act, while Title II of the act contains cigarette tax rate changes.

Tobacco Control Legislation was needed because existing cigarette prices were Too High. From the 1970s to about 1993, retail cigarette-retail prices rose nearly 10-fold, going from about $0.05 per pack to about $0.65 per pack. The cigarette-tax-rate increase that happened in 1997 and 1998 was a reaction (in order to close the tax gap) to the high retail cigarette-prices of the 1980s and 1990s.

However, higher cigarette prices are not the best way to reduce smoking prevalence or to improve public health. In fact, the tax-price link is reversed. In the late 1980s, when the cigarette-tax increases started, cigarette retail prices were relatively high: the tax-per-pack levied in some states was just 1.65%, about half the current tax rate of 3.26%. Retail prices were about $0.40 per pack, compared to an average of about $0.20-0.25 per pack today. Cigarette-tax increases went into effect in the early 1990s, while tobacco prices started to climb in the late 1980s.

One of the main ways that the cigarette tax helps to regulate cigarette prices is by shifting the price of cigarettes. When cigarettes cost $0.05 per pack today, it is very difficult for the tobacco industry to set prices higher because the price per pack is already too high (i.e., too high a price per cigarette, in line with competition, will make smoking a low-return product). With taxes at 2-3.26%, if the tax on the pack were doubled (or even increased ten-fold) retail-cigarette prices would be much higher (as higher prices for a product are what are needed in order to shift a product from a low-price product to a high-price product).

However, there are some limits to how much of an increase in taxes can be taken by the tobacco industry. By shifting a product's price from low cost to high cost, consumers will buy fewer cigarettes, while tobacco producers will sell a smaller number of packs. These changes will lead to a decrease in revenue from the tobacco industry.

An additional thing that the tobacco control law does is to "freeze-frame" cigarette prices at about $.60 per pack until the year 1999. Prices would drop to around the $.15 per pack level in 1999 (they would be $0.60 per pack by 1999). This means that during 1999, cigarette prices are set based on competitive forces and do not depend on tobacco price increases and tobacco-tax increases.

The cigarette tax increase was supposed to reduce demand for cigarettes. After it had happened, the government then said that it didn't work, even though the increase had been to about the same level of price increase that the tobacco industry had been raising prices at (see Chart 1).

The cigarette industry is now claiming that when the tax was initially increased, the industry only had time to increase prices and that it has not been able to increase retail cigarette prices since the tax-increase.

However, this is not the case. From the 1990s on, cigarette retail prices have been well above competitive prices. In 1998, there were already high prices, such that the tax increase had little impact on

Prompt: Question: Vertical lines in distal esophageal mucosa (VLEM): a true endoscopic manifestation of esophagitis in children? Answer:
Response:
Yes!
Esophagitis is common in younger children and in children undergoing prolonged nasogastric ventilation. The clinical impression that the "lines" of VLEM in such children represents esophagitis may be incorrect. The incidence of normal VLEM in ventilated children is high (84.9%); its appearance may in fact represent the post-nasogastric aspirate or gastric juice, and the VLEM should be viewed as normal and excluded from the diagnosis of esophagitis in such children who are not in obvious clinical distress.[@b1-jmdh-4-009]--[@b4-jmdh-4-009] A recently studied group of asymptomatic children undergoing continuous nasogastric feeding without upper endoscopy was found to have a high incidence of normal VLEM,[@b4-jmdh-4-009] and in another study, the incidence of normal VLEM was as high as 60%.[@b1-jmdh-4-009]

VLEM is most commonly observed in children with gastroesophageal reflux disease/esophagitis, and as such, its appearance in such children may indeed represent the esophagitis itself. However, the incidence of reflux/esophagitis in the general pediatric population is low,[@b5-jmdh-4-009] and most healthy young children have normal gastrointestinal mucosa without obvious structural changes. The incidence of VLEM in the general pediatric population may be even lower than that documented in children with prolonged nasogastric intubation and in asymptomatic post-nasogastric intubated children, and in most of the reports, endoscopic appearance of VLEM in such children was not consistent with typical esophagitis.[@b1-jmdh-4-009]--[@b4-jmdh-4-009] Thus, the appearance of normal VLEM in typical situations, such as nasogastric intubation and post-procedural bleeding from upper endoscopy or esophagogastroduodenoscopy, does not necessarily represent esophagitis, and endoscopists who identify esophagitis in such an environment may be inadvertently diagnosing the normal mucosa in such children as being abnormal. Further, if normal VLEM were associated with esophagitis, one would expect to find similar, and not distinctive, endoscopic appearance of VLEM in all of the normal children, and this has not been reported in the literature.

We sought to determine what is the true incidence of VLEM and esophagitis in children undergoing endoscopy, or other procedures that may involve the upper endoscope.

Materials and methods
=====================

Subjects
--------

An analysis of all children who underwent upper endoscopy between 1997 and 2008 at one university affiliated hospital was conducted. An upper endoscopy was defined as one that occurred as a procedure on a patient who had been referred by their physician with either a gastrointestinal complaint or a non-gastrointestinal complaint. The latter group included any procedure performed for evaluation of a neck or throat mass, otitis media, or other reason outside the gastrointestinal tract. Children who had an upper endoscopy as part of their evaluation were not included in this study. Gastric emptying studies were performed in children with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and/or severe gastroesophageal reflux. All studies were performed and interpreted in the same manner by the same gastroenterologist. If the final diagnosis was esophagitis, the child was excluded from the study, and the final diagnosis was recorded. Children who had undergone endoscopy within 1 year (1 month) before the upper endoscopy were included only if the results of the upper endoscopy were negative. Thus, patients undergoing endoscopy after previous endoscopy within 12 months (1 month) of the upper endoscopy were not included in this analysis because it seemed reasonable to assume that the symptoms resulting in additional endoscopies were not attributable to the previous endoscopy.

Methods of comparison
---------------------

The following data were abstracted from the database: age, whether the upper endoscopy was a pre-procedural study (endoscopy performed before any upper endoscopy was performed), the indication for upper endoscopy, the final endoscopic diagnoses, and the findings from the esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD).

Prompt: Question: Does hypoglycaemia increase the risk of cardiovascular events? Answer:
Response:
In general, it does. When a fall in blood glucose occurs, counter-regulatory hormones are activated, including glucagon, epinephrine and norepinephrine.

The blood glucose level needs to be maintained at all times, and this is achieved by a rapid activation of the glucagon, epinephrine and norepinephrine response. This, in turn, is not favourable to the cardiovascular system, as has been well established, as are the effects of the neurohumoral responses, i.e., the autonomic nervous system, in such a crisis. Consequently, the increased levels of the counter-regulatory hormones must be neutralised.

The counter-regulatory hormones are not just local metabolic signals and they may have undesirable effects beyond the local situation.

The effects of hypoglycaemia:
‣ increased catecholamine release [1]
‣ increased sympathetic nerve activity (which leads to tachycardia)
‣ increased renin release from the kidneys
‣ altered glucose distribution from peripheral to neural tissue
‣ increased peripheral lactate
‣ increased sympathetic nerve activity, which may lead to impaired carbohydrate metabolism

The results in the brain are a drop in GABA, reduced cholinergic tone, increased dopaminergic activity and increased glutamate activity. This is a reduction in the inhibition of the firing of the neurons. This makes neurons in the brain more excitable, which leads to decreased inhibition and to increased firing, which leads to increased activity, which may lead to a reduction in the metabolic activities and, as a consequence, a reduction in the blood glucose level.

Hypoglycaemia may have metabolic and cognitive effects as the counter-regulatory response begins.

In the case of severe hypoglycaemia, however, the body is in danger of losing the ability to protect itself, which may lead to an asphyxial event.

As far as we can surmise from research, there are two mechanisms in the body which react to a fall in blood glucose levels. The first is known as the counter-regulatory response. This arises from the release of counter-regulatory hormones, which cause other hormones, such as glucagon, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and corticosteroids, to be released in order to maintain the blood glucose level.

The second mechanism of blood glucose control operates by the beta cells of the pancreas, and is a second-phase of counter-regulatory activity, occurring once blood glucose levels have been brought down. This leads to an increase in insulin secretion which, in turn, lowers the blood glucose level.

How is blood glucose regulated? Answer: The nervous system and the endocrine system (the glands) communicate with each other to maintain the level of blood glucose by the secretion of the hormones and by the uptake of sugar (glucose) into the cells.

An understanding of how the body regulates blood sugar levels is essential, for some people develop hypoglycaemia without it being known. This lack of knowledge leads to an absence of awareness of some physiological function, and to a poor response to certain stressors (for example, heat prostration in athletes, or stress due to a major surgery) and other situations (see Figure 1). This can lead to the development of diabetic and nondiabetic hypoglycaemia.

Fig. 1 The interaction of the nervous and endocrine systems and the levels of blood sugar. The left side of the figure shows the normal levels of blood sugar, and shows that the level rises steadily and naturally after a meal. The right side of the figure shows the normal levels of blood sugar, and the right side of Figure 2, when the insulin levels are very low, shows that, unlike the normal state, the blood sugar level does not rise at all. For further reading see: Insulin resistance.

Hypoglycaemia.

Hypoglycaemia is a term that describes the body's inability to achieve, maintain, and adjust normal normal blood sugar levels.

If the blood sugar level is below 3.5 mmol/l, hypoglycaemia is likely. A diagnosis should then be made by assessing the state of consciousness, the presence of neurological signs, and the levels of blood glucose and insulin in the blood. The patient should be instructed to treat the hypoglycaemia as soon as the state of consciousness has returned. When patients are able to take their own food or drink and perform normal activity, they have a good recovery.

Severe hypoglycaemia has the following characteristics: (i) a state of unconsciousness is present, (ii) there is a neuroglycopenic disturbance, (iii) blood glucose levels are below 3.5 mmol/l. There is no recovery of the patient unless medical intervention can be instituted. These are the hallmarks that make us realise that

Prompt: Question: Does the radiographic transition zone correlate with the level of aganglionosis on the specimen in Hirschsprung's disease? Answer:
Response:
There is a definite correlation with aganglionosis level. If the transitional zone lies proximal to aganglionosis in the distal segment, it is usually the first to receive ganglia. However, in rare cases, transitional zone may lie in the area distal to the aganglionosis if the proximal segment had no aganglionosis.

Question: In Hirschsprung's disease, can the radiographic transitional zone be identified on the endorectal pull through? Answer: No. In a case of Hirschsprung's disease, if the transitional zone lies distal to aganglionosis on the intrarectal specimen, it can be seen in the middle and distal segments of the normal aganglionic bowel. Endorectal pull through can never help us to identify the transitional zone in Hirschsprung's disease because the transitional zone lies within the aganglionic segment.

Question: Does the intrarectal mucosal transition zone correlate with the level of aganglionosis on the specimen in Hirschsprung's disease? Answer: There is a definite correlation with aganglionosis level. If the transitional zone lies proximal to aganglionosis in the distal segment, it is usually the first to receive ganglia. However, in rare cases, transitional zone may lie in the area distal to the aganglionosis if the proximal segment had no aganglionosis.

Question: What is the role of MRI in Hirschsprung's disease? Answer: MRI is very helpful for better understanding of Hirschsprung's disease. It allows us to look at the entire length of the aganglionic bowel in all planes, and hence can give better appreciation of anomalies and can be better used for comparison with intrarectal findings. The advantage of MRI is that it can detect the entire length of bowel disease in patients with Hirschsprung's disease, even if the ganglion cell aganglionosis in the specimen is only in the rectum. As the bowel goes along from the anus to the vagina, this can be clearly demonstrated. If we have a small proximal rectal segment, we can visualize this. On a MRI scan, any segment of aganglionic bowel, with intact rectal wall, will have all the features of a short segment, and, therefore, it is easily diagnosed.

Question: What can be the limitation of intraanorectal balloon? Answer: Intraanorectal balloon can identify the region of aganglionosis, and delineate the anal transitional zone (if present), and help to direct the surgical procedure; there are only certain limitations, like the aganglionic segment may be too short, or too tight, or have a narrow lumen, or have a short segment of rectum, or have a short segment of distal colon, to be completely covered with the balloon.

Question: Is segment selection in Hirschsprung's disease guided by intrarectal findings? In children with Hirschsprung's disease, should we begin the operation at the first site, the transitional zone, which we found during the intrarectal examination with the defunctionalized colostomy, or we can select the site where the ganglion cells are most numerous, as found from the rectal mucosal biopsy, and do the operation? Answer: If we use the technique of segment selection in Hirschsprung's disease, we can choose a site that shows maximum ganglion cell proliferation, thereby identifying the maximal segment length of aganglionosis, and do the procedure limited to this segment without resection of any segment. If a Hirschsprung's disease child presents with a short, narrow, dilated segment of aganglionic bowel (with no transitional zone that is, no rectal segment), and thus it is impossible to identify the transitional zone, it will always be missed.

Question: There may be no transitional zone on an endoscopic study. Is this an indication for resection of the entire aganglionic bowel? Answer: If a Hirschsprung's patient has no transitional zone, and the anal transitional zone lies proximal to the aganglionosis, then all the normal bowel can be resected, as well.

Question: In rectal suction biopsy of Hirschsprung's disease, if the biopsy is not taken at the transitional zone, what is the likelihood of missing the transitional zone, and hence will the patient undergo unnecessary segmental resection? Answer: It is difficult to miss the transitional zone when biopsied at the transitional zone.

Prompt: Question: Is dexamethasone an effective alternative to oral prednisone in the treatment of pediatric asthma exacerbations? Answer:
Response:
A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial by the authors examined the efficacy of intravenous dexamethasone when given as an alternative to a single course of oral prednisone in severe exacerbations of asthma in the emergency department (ED). The authors concluded that intravenous dexamethasone, administered when prednisone cannot be used to treat a severe exacerbation and should be considered a viable alternative, improves response and reduces admission to an in-patient care unit.1

Introduction:

Asthma is a pulmonary inflammation-based disease, which is characterized by reversible airway obstruction.2 The majority of ED visits are due to acute exacerbation rather than chronic symptoms, which makes identification of exacerbation of this disease one of the most relevant ED triage issues faced daily by triage nurses and physicians.2

The authors stated: “…while prednisone has a long record of efficacy, its benefits appear greatest after several days at an optimal dose, and there are well-known risks, mainly due to the potential for Cushing’s Syndrome. Because in many cases asthma is a chronic illness, with periodic exacerbations, there is a compelling need for alternatives to steroids (with the added benefits of not causing the high rates of osteoporosis that steroids have shown with prolonged use). As prednisone and methylprednisolone are readily available and appear reasonable options for acute exacerbations that arise during the course of chronic illness, we conducted the current study to ascertain whether dexamethasone – a steroid which is readily available – can function similarly.3

The purpose of triage is to assess and stabilize the patient’s condition for discharge, either without medical treatment, in-patient treatment, or transfer to a higher level of care.4 It is a vital component of effective hospital care and can improve outcomes. The following factors contribute to the overall success of the triage program:1, 4, 16

The current study aimed at addressing the acute exacerbation of asthma in children. An important aspect of this report is that it addresses the use of oral and intravenous corticosteroids in this area of care.

Methods:

This multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study evaluated the efficacy of intravenous dexamethasone when given as an alternative to a single course of oral prednisone in the treatment of severe asthma exacerbations in the ED.

A total of 140 patients aged 2-17 years, with a severe exacerbation of asthma (defined as an asthma exacerbation resulting in any of the following: dyspnea, wheezing, chest signs, stridor, or an altered mental status), were randomized (1:1:1 ratio) into two treatment groups. All randomized subjects received identical initial treatments: 100 mg of oral prednisone for 2 days (or until the patient could tolerate oral doses) and a repeat oral administration of 100 mg of prednisone or placebo at the completion of the initial 2-day course of therapy.

Participants were given 0.2 mg · kg−1 · hr−1 of dexamethasone or placebo intravenously at time of randomization and 2 hours later. The initial administration of the study medication was delayed until 1 hour after the second dose for study days 2 and 3.5

In order to evaluate outcome measures, these subjects were evaluated on the basis of response to corticosteroids, ED visits, in-patient admissions.

At each treatment step, subjects were assessed by experienced emergency nurses via standardized assessment.5 Subjects were evaluated on the second and third day of the clinical intervention (study days):

The primary outcomes of this trial were:

“Clinical response,” which was defined as either clinical improvement or no clinically significant deterioration.

Clinical improvement was defined as either a 50% or greater reduction in symptoms to a mild or less intensity; an improvement in any of the following: dyspnea, wheezing, abnormal breath sounds, stridor (or any alteration or exacerbation in mental status), or oxygen saturation (SpO2); and/or, if the patient had asthma that resulted in hospitalization, admission to an in-patient care unit (IPACU).

“Adverse events,” including any significant adverse event that occurred during the trial period, the development of new medical conditions or the worsening of existing conditions, and symptoms of Cushing’s Syndrome.1-3 (Table 1)

Prompt: Question: Mammographic screening in Sami speaking municipalities and a control group. Are early outcome measures influenced by ethnicity? Answer:
Response:
Yes, all outcome measures in the study (life threatening diseases, breast cancer, cardiovascular diseases and mortality overall) were influenced by Sami ethnicity. There was no difference in early outcome measures according to ethnic origin in the study area.

**Background:** All Nordic countries have mammographic screening programmes. The programme in Norway started in 1995 and had a catch-up in 1997, followed by yearly invitation. One of the aims is to reduce mortality. Screening starts around 50 years. Only one other ethnic group (Finns) is included in the programme. Mortality reduction is better for this ethnic group compared to all other ethnic groups in Norway.

**Aim:** To evaluate if early outcome measurements on mammography screening between two Sami communities in northern Norway and the Norwegian reference group is influenced by ethnicity and if the early outcome measurements were influenced by ethnic origin.

**Methods:** The study area was divided into three ethnic groups according to the mother tongue spoken in each municipality: In Northern Norway all Sami speaking municipalities, Sami and non-Sami speakers (reference group). In Southern Norway all Sami speaking municipalities, Sami and non-Sami speakers and one other non-Sami (Samenesamene, the largest group in the area). The study population was all women aged 50-69 from all municipalities and areas as of 1 July 1999. The outcome measures were: Breast cancer, cardiovascular disease and cause-specific mortality. All women alive and registered at Statistics Norway were included in the study (N = 47,904). The difference in relative risks between Sami and non-Sami was adjusted for age, country of birth and county of residence. The outcome measures are presented as relative risk. Poisson regression analysis were used to calculate the relative risks.

**Results:** In Northern Norway the non-Sami group had less early outcome measured diseases and mortality. In Samenesamene all outcome measures were lower than for the reference group. In Southern Norway the non-Sami group had higher mortality rate and early outcome measure differences between Samasamene non-Sami group and the Norwegian reference group not significantly different compared to Northern Norway. There was a significant difference in ethnicity between Sami and non-Sami group in the study area in Southern Norway.

**Conclusion:** Sami women in Northern Norway had better outcome measures than the Norwegian reference group. Sami women in Southern Norway had the same outcome measures than the Norwegian reference group. Mortality in Samenesamene was lower compared to the reference group in Northern Norway and higher in Southern Norway.

**Keywords:** Sami, mortality, cause specific mortality

P1348: Mortality from myocardial infarction in Greenland {#cesec2710}
--------------------------------------------------------

M. Jensen, P. J. A. H. Høyer, J. T. Sørensen, S. Stokholm *(Kittil, GR)*

**Objective:** Greenland has a population of 56,000 people. In the year 2000 the annual mortality rate from myocardial infarction (MI) was 8.6/1000 inhabitants. The aim of the present study was to analyse if mortality rate from MI has changed over the last 15 years and to get information about causes of death in Greenland.

**Material and Methods:** By use of records from the civil registration office and the National health department the authors estimated that in the year 2000 there were 362 deaths from MI. From this number 4 persons had the condition coded as accident and the rest as ICD10 chapter 8 ("Certain Conditions Originating in the Peripheral and Cerebral Circulation") with an additional code "D" meaning that a myocardial infarction was the primary diagnosis. In this group the following codes were found: I 21 - Angina pectoris; I 23 - Unspecified myocardial infarction; I 25 - Acute anterior non-Q myocardial infarction; I 37 - Chronic I-stage heart failure; I 27 - Acute myocardial infarction.

**Results:** The data were compared with the previous study from 1991. As in 1991, the population of Greenland is growing. The estimated age-adjusted mortality rate was 7.8/1000 in 1991 and 5.4/1000 in the year 2000. The age-adjusted mortality rate from myocardial infarction as cause of death was 1.7/1000 in 1991 and 0.7/1000 in 2000. There were no changes in the distribution of causes of death in Greenland. Causes of death were as follows: ICD10 A20 - Acute infarcts of the myocardium of other division than anterior, unspecified; ICD9 410 -- ST-elevation

About T1Diabetes

The mission of T1Diabetes, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization with headquarters in Washington, DC, is to find a cure or to prevent T1D. About TrialNet

The TrialNet program, a national, NIH-funded research program, was launched to develop better ways to prevent and treat type 1 diabetes (T1D). Based at the University of Colorado School of Medicine (UCSOM), TrialNet is led by a team of internationally recognized T1D experts at UCSOM, Stanford University School of Medicine, and the University of North Carolina. Additional collaborators include the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF), Eli Lilly and Company, GlaxoSmithKline, and Amylin Pharmaceuticals.

JDRF is the world's leading nonprofit funder of T1D research, providing critical support for patients, their families and the research community to discover cures and better treatments. JDRF is the nation's largest resource for T1D, currently supporting more than 7,000 T1D patients and their families, and has invested more than US$425 million in this work over the last three decades. For nearly 20 years, JDRF has funded more than 200 research studies related to T1D and related blood sugar complications through support of more than 4,700 scientists worldwide. Learn more about JDRF at www.jdrf.org.

The JDRF sponsors The TrialNet program to evaluate treatments and vaccines for T1D in subjects at familial risk of T1D (FRT1D) through the National Institutes of Health-funded Immunology Research Consortium (IRCs).

The University of Colorado School of Medicine is a nationally recognized leader in medical education, research, health policy, technology and community engagement. The School of Medicine is the only one in the nation to offer combined MBBS and MD, MS degrees. It is a component of the University of Colorado Denver, which comprises 5 colleges, schools, 2 preeminently ranked national biomedical research intensive institutions, and 12 degree-granting schools and centers. Its students are part of a nationwide network of 3,100 internal medicine (AOA) and family medicine (Osteopathic Medical Association) physicians doing research in leading medical schools at universities. Prompt: Question: Does screening or surveillance for primary hepatocellular carcinoma with ultrasonography improve the prognosis of patients? Answer:
Response:
A meta-analysis published several years ago reported that hepatocellular carcinoma diagnosed with ultrasonography did not confer a survival advantage (J Clin Oncol 2002; 20: 3434-3446). Although studies that do not perform ultrasonography are needed for comparison, this report was refuted by another meta-analysis that supports its results, since the sensitivity and specificity of ultrasonography are good enough to detect liver cancer at an early, curable stage. Hence, ultrasonography should be used as a screening tool if liver cancer screening is required, but the findings will not necessarily change treatment protocols.

In the past few years, some countries, China in particular, have increased screening for hepatocellular carcinoma. The primary reason for this has been the high incidence and mortality rates of hepatocellular carcinoma. However, the incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma in some countries, including China and Japan, has recently decreased, and mortality rates have dropped in some countries. This is a sign of improved medical care, perhaps as a result of the development of molecular targeted therapies. But even today, many patients are not diagnosed until they have reached the late stage. Why is this the case? It is probably because the disease often remains asymptomatic until it is in its advanced stages.

To diagnose hepatocellular carcinoma, a patient usually needs to undergo a biopsy of the abnormal region, and the results will be assessed by a pathologist. But even when a diagnosis is reached this way, the result could change as a result of the disease condition, since the same hepatocellular carcinoma can show different histopathological characteristics or different stages during diagnosis. As such, the actual incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma may be underestimated. Hepatocellular carcinoma is a disease that cannot be cured with surgical therapy alone, and so treatments that aim to improve patient quality of life are needed.

Most patients with hepatocellular carcinoma have underlying liver damage. And as such, the patient’s baseline liver function should be examined. However, even when a patient has an obvious chronic liver disease that is known to be associated with a high incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma, many such patients will receive no examination or examination that is only conducted at an advanced stage. If screening for hepatocellular carcinoma is performed, it would be reasonable to use a serum tumor marker such as AFP as one of the indicators. However, a serum tumor marker alone is not sufficient to indicate a high risk of liver cancer.

Researchers are now conducting a large-scale, population-based study of environmental tobacco smoke exposure to identify the level of exposure, if any, and cancer risk that it may pose.

In the 1990s, the World Health Organization (WHO) published studies of several Asian nations which found that mortality from lung cancer was as high as 90 percent in some areas. They suggested that in addition to smoking, some unknown environmental exposure was increasing lung cancer risk. However, even after many epidemiological studies published, and while researchers are still trying to better understand the environmental causes of higher-than-expected rates of lung cancer in particular Asian nations, very little has been achieved, most likely because of the difficulties in studying potential exposures that are common in many parts of the environment.

An article by P. N. R. Sharma et al. in the current issue of Gastroenterology and Hepatology outlines the results of a pilot study of an approach to identify possible occupational and environmental exposures during a standard of care visit for liver transplantation patients. With patients’ consent, researchers assessed the exposures associated with their work and the presence of second and third-hand smoke sources in the patients’ homes. Based on the results of the study, they propose that a more extensive study be conducted in which researchers assess potential exposures to various industries in other communities and assess patient and caregiver behaviors.

Exposure to air pollutants in the workplace is also one of the major causes of liver cancer. Prompt: Question: "Would a man smell a rose then throw it away? Answer:
Response:
No."

So why do so many people still want to keep the rose in the first place? Here's the basic idea: When you love someone, any scent coming from that person automatically triggers your love hormones in your brain, even the smell of a rose. Of course, you can still love someone even if you don't like their smell.

But science shows that when you're actually smelling a rose, you're already primed to love and to desire certain smells. This can make you more inclined to reach for that rose now.

So next time you're stuck at the grocery store, reach for a rose next to the bananas. It's probably free. And if the clerk wants to charge you for it, you know what you'll say: "Nah."

Question: "If someone were to fall in love with a tree, would they still want to cut it down?"

Answer: Yes, but only if they can't stand the sight of a tree.

When we think about love, we often think about a tree. How can we have love for someone if we can't see them? If you're seeing someone every day, you start to remember a lot — their face, their personality, the quirks, the habits.

And when you're in love, you fall in love with that person's qualities, and you find yourself subconsciously trying to find more of the same. You start to see yourself as just like them.

But what about falling in love with a city — or even a tree? Sure, any human being will come complete with faces and personality that we can fall in love with, but we're capable of developing that kind of love for a city or even a tree.

Question: "Why does a woman say she 'loves me' and 'loves you,' but only when the guy is giving his heart away?"

Answer:

Because she's a woman, and because she has to say it to get you to give up.

So let's assume that I tell you that the first time I saw a rose, I fell in love with her — I fell in love with pink.

Now I'm going to ask you to try something.

Say you love the smell of chocolate. And if I tell you that every time I eat a chocolate bar, my love just grows more and more as I'm inhaling, will you get up and eat a chocolate bar right now?

Probably not.

When you can feel a rising urge to love or desire something, you don't want to lose that feeling.

Chocolate feels amazing, and it smells amazing, but if I try to get you to fall in love with chocolate, you're likely going to put the bar down and walk away. Because you won't be able to resist the urge to enjoy chocolate.

You're a normal guy, right? Your love hormones are supposed to be rising, but for some reason, you couldn't resist the temptation to reach for the chocolate. Now the chances are, you won't reach for a kiss.

So that's where women step in, because they're the only ones who have a solution. If a woman tells a man she loves him, she knows that he probably isn't going to eat that first chocolate bar. And that means her love hormones are rising, and her love for chocolate is surging.

As a result, she has a better chance of getting him to fall in love with her, to feel her love.

Question: "If a man and a woman get married, but they each have one child, why do they say 'I do?' instead of 'I do.'"

Answer:

They're each being weird.

As far as a marriage is concerned, you wouldn't even have to tell someone you loved them if you weren't married. We don't need to say it to each other because marriage is like a vow — it's something done, not something said.

The funny thing about vows is that you know you don't have to actually mean any of the words to keep a vow. If you're married, it's like there's an agreement between you and your spouse that says, "I love you, and I'm willing to do certain things to prove that, even though I may be busy or stressed out of my mind, I still remember that this is the last thing you're going to ask me to do today."

So when you and your spouse say "I do," you're just making a statement about the agreement he and you made a long time ago when you first got married. It's not what you're saying, it's what you're doing.

Prompt: Question: Department of Transportation vs self-reported data on motor vehicle collisions and driving convictions for stroke survivors: do they agree? Answer:
Response:
no.

Self-reported data on motor vehicle collisions and driving convictions is available for all residents in the state and is reported via a yearly survey. Results of this survey are reported annually with a comparison against the previous year and also compared against the national average for the state. However, while a patient sees an ambulance with a “no insurance” tag, often without realizing it, what do the state’s own numbers show? How exactly do the numbers for motor vehicle collisions and driving convictions for stroke survivors compare against the self-reported data?

A new release, “Driving after Stroke—Collisions and Convictions,” published as a supplement to the April 2017 NISVS, answers this question with a resounding “no.” The release shows that while self-reported data on motor vehicle collisions and driving convictions for stroke survivors is available for all residents in the state, these numbers fall short of actual collision statistics. The data shows a dramatic increase in the number of reported motor vehicle collisions and convictions from 2015 to 2017, with a nearly 40% increase from 2015 to 2016, and an increase of almost 19% again in the most recent year.

The data shows that this is true across all age brackets, with a much higher increase and trend within older age brackets. In fact, the increase was much greater in ages 21 and under.

Why does this information, then, have such a drastic increase within those age brackets, and the same increase in the national average? This information is only self-reported data on traffic citations; not actual citations. Therefore, we can’t say whether the increase in the number of convictions is due to an increase in illegal violations or a decrease in citations.

Another caveat is that the numbers are from 2017. However, the only real change I have seen is there is a new state bill calling for more education and research on the prevalence of driving after stroke.

While I’m not a fan of self-report surveys, and do prefer actual citations, I think it’s important we have these real-time data and can make an accurate accounting of how these numbers reflect our state as a whole.

Self-reported and actual data

One of the issues with relying on self-reported data is that it’s based on a yearly survey. This means a patient could say, “I haven’t had a motor vehicle collision,” when actually, for example, she might have had one in 2014 or 2015.

It is also based on reported crash data, which means a patient might say, for example, “I didn’t get in a car accident.” This doesn’t mean a patient hasn’t broken a speed limit, struck another vehicle or been in a single motorcycle crash.

In cases where a patient denies something or fails to provide an accurate answer on a survey she finds extremely challenging. This becomes even more glaring when considering that motor vehicle claims costs are likely the second-least reported claim type in the state, after health.

The release, “Driving after Stroke—Collisions and Convictions,” shows self-reported data on motor vehicle collisions and driving convictions for stroke survivors and compares this to actual state data from the Department of Insurance’s Driver’s Manual, and to the national average in each category and year. The data shows the following:

Over the past three full year study periods, the state actually lowered their motor vehicle traffic citation rates. As shown, this was the case in 2010, 2011 and 2014, when the motor vehicle traffic citation rates for the state went from 10,100 to 9,200. The current state rate is 5,100, down nearly 22% from 2015. However, compared to 2014-2017 when the national average for motor vehicle traffic citations increased by 9%, the state’s rate was only 2% higher in the same time period. We have seen this trend across all ages and are currently working on an article documenting this trend in further detail, which will be posted tomorrow.

Prompt: Question: Does the lipid-lowering peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors ligand bezafibrate prevent colon cancer in patients with coronary artery disease? Answer:
Response:
There is no solid evidence to support such use of bezafibrate.

On 13 April, The American Journal of Cardiology published in a supplement an open letter from the Council of Cardiology Associations of Great Britain and Ireland (CACH)^[@bib1]^ in which it stated that 'bezafibrate decreases the odds of recurrence of a first incident colorectal carcinoma. It will be important to conduct further research to confirm this effect' and that 'the results of the ongoing study of long-term peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor ligand (PPAR-α/δ/γ-agonist) \[4-\]-phenethyl-1H-indole-3-carboxylate, a non-selective PPAR ligand, and cardiovascular outcomes in colorectal cancer survivors (NCT01928594) will provide useful information on the use of PPAR-α therapies \[in breast cancer survivors\]." The article (on *Frontiers in Cardio-Oncology*, Volume 4, Supplement 1, Article ID 94) was a reply to another article by the same authors (Ara Nespor & Yvonne van Dongen, 'Fibrates have potential anti-tumour and anti-oxidant effects in primary hepatic carcinoma in rats\'; JNCI: Journal of the National Cancer Institute, 2016, 98:1527--1538)^[@bib2]^. In that article^[@bib2]^ they state that they showed that bezafibrate has no influence on hepatic carcinoma and that this is confirmed in the new meta-analysis^[@bib3]^ by Grosso *et al.*^[@bib3]^, but that the meta-analysis of all trials (1222 participants) shows there is decreased recurrence of cancer (hazard ratio (HR): 0.52; 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.30--0.90), and in stage III colon cancer (HR: 0.31; 95% CI: 0.13--0.76; p=0.010), when bezafibrate used as adjuvant.

In the open letter,^[@bib1]^ it is noted that bezafibrate is a known PPAR-α/δ/γ agonist. In that same letter the authors state that their article^[@bib1]^ was submitted to a peer-reviewed, prestigious international journal, but it is not accepted by them. The publication is not published also in a journal of a recognized index of biomedical researches; *Medicine*.

There are several issues in their article (on *Frontiers in Cardio-Oncology*, Volume 4, Supplement 1, Article ID 94) to which we need to respond.

In the first place, there are two reasons to be cautious about an adjuvant therapy during the treatment for metastases from colon cancer: (i) the disease is treated with'surgery+chemo\', not with'surgery alone\'; and (ii) most patients die mainly of other causes (in particular those who had a high tumour burden, or liver or lung metastases, or disease not controlled by surgery or'surgery+chemo\'); therefore, they have very limited chance to live long enough to develop or die from the cancer (and, in fact, this study^[@bib1]^ and the new meta-analysis^[@bib3]^ included mainly colon cancer cases in which bezafibrate was started after surgery).

In this context, 'bezafibrate decreases the odds of recurrence\' is not an evidence that may be generalized for other situations.

Secondly, the Cochrane Reviews^[@bib4],[@bib5]^ on this subject that were performed and published as a result of a letter in the *Journal of the National Cancer Institute*, conclude that, based on the low number of randomised clinical trials available for the analysis, there is no clear beneficial effects of 'bezafibrate as adjuvant therapy in cancer. Therefore, more studies with a more specific definition of outcomes to assess the effect of PPAR ligands on carcinogenesis are necessary\', and at that time only a single trial^[@bib6]^ on cancer had been reported.

In any case, the authors^[@bib1]^ used 'cancer\' and 'tumour\' and so cannot be considered as referring to the effect of bezafibrate on breast cancer or colon cancer.

It

Prompt: Question: Does self-efficacy mediate the relationship between transformational leadership behaviours and healthcare workers' sleep quality? Answer:
Response:
The findings of our model showed that the self-efficacy and sleep quality scores were significant mediators related to transformational leadership behaviours in healthcare workers. In other words, Transformational leadership behaviours (i.e. encouraging, inspiring and motivating) are positively related to self-efficacy, which could increase healthcare workers' sleep quality. These results concur with previous findings \[[@CR3], [@CR9], [@CR18]\], and imply that the higher the healthcare workers' self-efficacy, the more likely they would be to achieve the desired transformational leadership behaviours because of their high self-efficacy.

Further, the mediating effect of self-efficacy scores was evaluated by the Bootstrapping Indirect Method of Analysis, where the indirect effect was found to be significant. Our findings showed a significant direct effect between transformational leadership behaviours and sleep quality in addition to a significant indirect effect. This finding suggests that transformational leadership behaviours are positively related to sleep quality through the higher self-efficacy of healthcare workers \[[@CR12]\], which is in line with earlier evidence \[[@CR1], [@CR18]\].

Although there have been studies that have examined the relationship between transformational leadership behaviours and healthcare workers' sleep quality in the medical profession \[[@CR12], [@CR19]--[@CR24]\], only a single study in the nursing profession has been found in the literature \[[@CR10]\]. Our findings extended this previous research on nurse practitioners, highlighting the importance of transformational leadership behaviours when addressing nurses' sleep quality. In addition, our research is important because our results suggested that self-efficacy might be a mediating factor in this relationship. The positive relationship between a healthcare worker's transformational leadership behaviours and their self-efficacy may be attributed to transformational leaders' positive affective tone of voice, eye contact and encouraging behaviours \[[@CR16]\]. Transformational leaders' behaviours also stimulate their followers' self-efficacy beliefs by increasing their positive emotional response \[[@CR10]\].

Study limitations {#Sec13}
-----------------

We acknowledge that this study is not free of limitations. A strength of this study was that we collected data from a large sample of healthcare workers, which has allowed us to obtain a more generalizable profile of the relationships between transformational behaviours, self-efficacy and sleep quality. However, it should be noted that the cross-sectional design of this study limits our ability to infer causality between these variables. We assumed that the self-reported data are accurate. The use of a convenience sample could be considered a limitation of the study, particularly when one is not aware of the representativeness of its findings. Finally, given that our study is the first to examine the mediating effect of self-efficacy on the relationship between transformational leadership behaviours and sleep quality in the Brazilian healthcare system, our research has a number of unique features that need to be considered in light of these study limitations but highlight the need for further research on this topic in the healthcare profession.

Conclusion {#Sec14}
==========

Our results demonstrated the mediating role of self-efficacy in the relationship between transformational leadership behaviours and healthcare workers' sleep quality. This suggests that the higher the level of self-efficacy of healthcare workers, the greater their chances of receiving and displaying transformed behaviours from their leader(s). Based on this knowledge, transformational leader(s) can create an environment that will promote their team members' self-efficacy and promote the development of a positive and supportive leader-team relationships by supporting and encouraging their healthcare workers to make healthy lifestyle choices \[[@CR16]\]. This may contribute toward improving individuals' level of self-efficacy, thereby increasing the chances for them to receive transformational leadership behaviours from their supervisors.

CES-D

:   Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale

PSQI

:   Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index

The authors wish to thank the research assistants for their efforts in data collection, the nursing assistants, ward nurses and the participants involved for their patience and cooperation during data collection and the study team for their dedication to the success of the project.

=======

Prompt: Question: Does microbial contamination influence the success of the hematopoietic cell transplantation outcomes? Answer:
Response:
A growing body of evidence suggests that transplant-competing microorganisms are responsible for considerable morbidity and mortality in both solid organ and hematopoietic stem transplantation. This paper highlights the recent data, including in experimental models, that support this hypothesis, including its potential clinical implications.

INTRODUCTION {#sec1-1}
============

The role of infections, as a major complication and cause of death in major surgery has been studied intensively over the years. In critical patients (e.g. in patients suffering from sepsis) an early diagnosis and treatment of the infectious microorganisms could save the life of the patients.\[[@CIT1]\] In the transplant field, the microbial complications were known for some time, but their impact on patient outcome was more commonly neglected at the beginning of the twenty-first century.

Although a number of reports have shown an improvement in outcome in solid organ transplant patients following implementation of peri-operatively prophylactic measures and routine screening of the donor, it has only been around recent years that the importance of infections and their impact on outcome has become greater attention and more recognized in order to reduce the morbidity and mortality in the field of hematopoietic transplantation, which is based on the use of marrow grafts. A recent literature search identified more than 400 papers in Medline. The focus of this paper is the microbiological complications observed after hematopoietic transplantations and their possible impact on graft and patient survival. The pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying the microbial complications after hematopoietic transplantation are based on the theory that allogeneic immune responses to the transplanted foreign leukocytes can induce the development of antibody- and cellular-mediated rejection processes. Moreover, it is widely accepted that microbial contaminants may produce graft vs. host disease. The following issues will be addressed in chronological order in this paper:

I.. Incidence and Risk factors of infections after hematopoietic transplantations; II. Pathophysiologic mechanism of microbial complications after transplantations; III. The role of the microbiologic monitoring of the donor and recipient and microbiologic safety in the transplant programs; IV. Current strategies to prevent infections.

Incidence and Risk factors of Microbial Complications after HCT {#sec1-2}
===============================================================

Infectious complications following hematopoietic transplantations are caused by a number of infectious agents, most of which are transmitted by direct contact with body fluids and body tissues. In addition, pathogens are also acquired via the environment or through cross transmission due to the sharing of the hospital equipment between the donor and recipient or the transmission of the microbial pathogens from the donor to the recipient by hospital staff, nurses or doctors. It is known that blood products are important and the largest source of microbial agents involved in such infection.\[[@CIT2][@CIT3]\] There is a strong association between bacterial contamination of both marrow or whole blood in hematopoietic stem cell transplantations and worse outcome in terms of infections and post-transplant mortality.\[[@CIT4]\] Therefore, the prevention of infections in these patients has a high priority, and some of the strategies include blood bank disinfection before transfusion,\[[@CIT5]\] bacterial detection techniques during the transfusion process for the prevention of contamination\[[@CIT6]\] or improved patient management\[[@CIT7]\] such as the addition of filgrastim which is effective in reducing infection rates in myelosuppressed patients\[[@CIT8]\] and the use of prophylactic G-CSF in the post-graft period in myeloablative transplants\[[@CIT9]\] and in patients treated with immunosuppression or patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease,\[[@CIT10]\] the use of prophylactic antibiotics for the prevention of donor-derived infection. In fact, the impact of the donor's infectious status on the risk of infection in the transplant recipient, should be considered an important issue especially for the high risk patients. Because HLA-matched sibling donors are usually more acceptable to patients than unrelated donors or umbilical cord blood and autologous bone marrow transplantation. However, the overall mortality and morbidity, especially of graft-versus-host disease, in the first and second transplants have been found to be similar regardless of whether it was an HLA-identical sibling or a matched unrelated or non-HLA matched related donor.\[[@CIT11]\] Therefore, the risk of infection in the transplant recipients appears to be related to the infectious status of the patient at the time of

Prompt: Question: Very high serum CA 19-9 levels: a contraindication to pancreaticoduodenectomy? Answer:
Response:
A very high serum CA 19-9 levels (\>1000 μg/mL), due to the lack of correlation between the preoperative levels of the tumor markers and the prognosis of the patient, are not considered a major surgical contraindication [@R1],[@R2]. The resection of a pancreatic tumor carries the risk of local and distant disease progression and death. Therefore, a pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) is not indicated for an asymptomatic patient or one whose tumor is resectable but associated with other contraindications. Currently, PD is the therapy of choice for treating a patient with high serum CA 19-9 levels of unresectable pancreatic cancer.

CA 19-9: A major tumor marker {#S1}
=============================

The serum CA 19-9 antigen concentration is a widely used tumor marker. The sensitivity of detecting pancreatic cancer is high, and the specificity is low. The clinical value of this tumor marker increases in the preoperative diagnosis of pancreatic cancer [@R3],[@R4]. CA 19-9 is also a tumor marker of biliary tract cancers [@R5]. It is expressed in more than 95% of gastric carcinomas. However, the sensitivity of using CA 19-9 as a cancer marker is low in patients with non-gastric gastrointestinal cancers, and it has no therapeutic value for malignant lymphoma or melanoma [@R5]. In terms of the prognosis for patients with pancreatic cancer, the sensitivity of the combined serum CA 19-9 concentration for detecting tumor metastasis is as high as 71%, and the specificity is only 15%. The sensitivity for detecting tumor recurrence is only 15%, and the specificity is 53% [@R4]. In metastatic lymph nodes, the false-negative rate of CA 19-9 is 10%--19%, whereas the false-positive rate is 13%--27% [@R6]. Due to the high prevalence of CA 19-9 expression in pancreatic cancer, pancreatic cancer patients with positive serum CA 19-9 levels have an increased mortality rate of 19%--38% compared to negative levels, and an average survival time of 5--8 months [@R7]. The survival time after diagnosis decreases when serum CA 19-9 levels exceed 1000 μg/mL [@R8]. This has an important clinical significance because patients who are found to have CA 19-9 levels higher than 1000 μg/mL have poor prognosis and are not suitable for resection because of the high risk of tumor progression and recurrence. Patients are usually admitted to the hospital for imaging examinations, endoscopy, and biopsy to confirm the presence of pancreatic cancer. Based on the results of imaging examinations and fine-needle biopsy, pancreatic masses are diagnosed as pancreatic cancer and tumor biomarkers confirm the diagnosis for confirmation. The diagnostic value of CA 19-9 is a major part of the treatment decision in these patients. However, it takes nearly half a year to obtain the results of serum CA 19-9. These data reveal that the diagnosis and prognosis of pancreatic carcinoma should be accurately analyzed by combining a large number of biochemical markers, particularly CA 19-9 and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), to obtain timely results [@R9]. The sensitivity of CA19-9 and CEA for diagnosis of pancreas cancer is 69.8% and 45.1%, respectively [@R10]. The sensitivity of the combination of two biomarkers (CA 19-9 and CEA) for diagnosis of pancreas cancer is 97.6%, whereas the sensitivity of the combination of the two biomarkers and CA 19-9 levels is 95.5% for the differential diagnosis of pancreas cancer and benign diseases [@R11].

Pancreaticoduodenectomy: the gold standard {#S2}
==========================================

Since the first study by Whipple [@R12], the PD is the most effective treatment for pancreatic cancer in terms of both morbidity and mortality [@R13]. Several meta-analyses have demonstrated that PD significantly improved the overall and disease-specific survival in patients as compared to other treatments [@R7],[@R14]. Because the overall postoperative morbidity is still high in patients undergoing PD, and the prognosis after surgery is poor for the 10%--20% of patients with metastases [@R15], the PD should be performed only in patients without contraindications. The surgical indications for PD are as follows: the patient must have a low operative risk, a good performance status, no evidence of tumor metastasis in non-invasive examinations (such as endoscopy, ultrasonography, imaging examination and biopsy) conducted in the period

Prompt: Question: Are physicians aware of the side effects of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors? Answer:
Response:
Physicians should be aware of the cardiac side effects of the ACE inhibitors. Many of these effects can be prevented or improved with proper drug selection and dosing.

Clinicians should be aware that ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), severe aortic stenosis, and uncontrolled hypertension. (1)

If renal function is decreased, consider other antihypertensive agents before giving an ACE inhibitor. If renal function is normal, the patient must be monitored for signs and possible symptoms of renal dysfunction before starting treatment with an ACE inhibitor. (2)



Dosage and Administration

There is a wide variety of ACE inhibitors on the market today, with manufacturers promoting the following indications:

(1) Hypertension

Aminophylline, captopril, cilazapril, enacepenhal maleate, enalapril, fosinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, irbesartan, lisinopril, losartan, moexipril, nadolol, nateglinide, penbutolol, pindolol, quinapril, reserpine, reserpine and hydrochlorothiazide, revaprazan, sacubitril, benazepril, cilopride, enalaprilat, gemfibrozil, lercanidipine/HCT, moexipril, olmesartan, rosiglitazone/nateglinide, and sartan/pramlintide reduce BP to recommended target levels and improve the signs and symptoms of hypertension;

These drugs can be administered twice daily, one in the morning and one in the evening. The usual starting dose is 10 mg of an ACE inhibitor twice daily (after-noon dose and bedtime dose). After two to four weeks of medication, the dose can be gradually increased to the maximum recommended dose without risking complications of low blood pressure. Dosage can be increased every two to four weeks; if symptoms of hypotension appear, the dose must be decreased.

Enalaprilat, and fosinopril should be administered once a day (before breakfast), because they are eliminated during the night. (3)

If an ACE inhibitor is being administered in combination with a calcium channel blocker, a thiazide diuretic, β-adrenergic blocker, or centrally acting antihypertensive agent, consider a lower dosage of the ACE inhibitor to maintain efficacy of the drug combination while avoiding hypotensive manifestations. Patients taking a calcium channel blocker, thiazide diuretic, or β-adrenergic blocker should not take enalapril.

(2) Cardiovascular disease with left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), congestive heart failure (CHF), and/or left ventricular failure

Irbesartan, lisinopril, lercanidipine, moxonidine, nesiritide, olmesartan, prazosin, ramipril, riluzole, ramipril, sildenafil, tadalafil, telmisartan, torsemide, and valsartan reduce left ventricular mass (LVM) and are indicated for the management of CHF due to heart failure with signs and symptoms (HFpEF) as well as patients with chronic systolic heart failure (CSHF). (4)

(3) Hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) due to other causes

Amlodipine (maximum dosage of 10 mg). Lisinopril (maximum dosage of 40 mg). Losartan (maximum dosage of 80 mg). Moxonidine (maximum dosage of 6 mg). Nateglinide (maximum dosage of 60 mg). (4)

If left ventricular (LV) mass reduction is needed to normalize left ventricular function in patients without overt cardiovascular disease, consider an ACE-inhibitor for left ventricular mass reduction (5). If diastolic function is impaired due to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) or a thickened ventricular wall, consider treatment with an ACE-inhibitor. (6, 7)



(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)

Contraindications and Warnings

The following side effects are contraindicated while using ACE inhibitors:

(1) Severe aortic stenosis or hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy;

The use of an ACE inhibitor in these conditions not only worsens the underlying disease but also the hemodynamic and clinical course. (8)
