Prompt: Question: Residual fundus or neofundus after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy: is fundectomy safe and effective as revision surgery? Answer:
Response:
Anebulization in the oesophageal remnant after sleeve gastrectomy should be avoided as it can provoke postoperative complications, especially after fundectomy.[@R1],[@R2] In most cases, an ablation technique is used in the context of fundectomy.[@R3] As previously published in AUBMC, we describe the first case of a patient operated with laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) which had a fundectomy. We describe here the steps of the procedure, the outcome, and the outcome of the first revision.

**Case report.** A 29-year-old patient underwent a sleeve gastrectomy and an endosaccular fundectomy in 2009. The patient weighed 100 kg (body mass index \[BMI\] 47.4 kg/m^2^) and had hypertension (130/84 mm Hg) and gastroesophageal reflux disease grade IVB. On the postoperative follow-up at 6 months, there were no complications, and the patient had regained 6 kg. The patient wanted to have a second revision surgery to stop the anorexia.

Preoperative workup included a clinical examination, blood pressure measurement on admission, a barium meal, a magnetic resonance scan of the body, and an orentation of the oral cavity. A sleeve gastrectomy and fundectomy could be achieved with minimal complication after 1 surgical team operation of 45 min. The patient had a good weight loss and no surgical complications on follow-up at 6 months.

**Surgical technique.** The steps of the procedures are summarized in [Fig. 1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}. The patient was positioned in supine position with an upper abdomen lift ([Fig. 1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}, image 1). After preparation of the abdominal skin using an electric cautery and a 10 mm camera port, 3 other 12 mm trochars were placed in the transversal and median subcostal, epigastric, and midline position, respectively. The transversal and midline trochars were positioned at the right abdominal flank and the epigastric trochar between the transversal trochars. The camera was placed in the midline position in the right lower abdomen ([Fig. 1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}, images 2--4). After positioning of the camera, the trochars were retracted, and a transversal abdominal incision of approximately 10 cm and 5 cm laterally from the previous scar was made.

![The steps of the second revision with fundectomy. TACS: transversal abdominal incision; N: camera port; S: trochar.](jg9-3-e0h1g-1-1.jpg){#F1}

The peritoneal cavity was explored using a laparoscopic Touhy needle and finger and the gastric staple line was identified and ligated. The fundus was then dissected until the diaphragmatic muscle was mobilized (Fig. [2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}, images 1--4). The diaphragmatic herniation of the oesophagus was then identified ([Fig. 2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}, images 5--8). The oesophageal herniation was reduced, and the transverse diaphragmatic rupture was then closed ([Fig. 2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}, images 9--12). The sleeve gastrectomy was confirmed with the surgeon's hands on the oesophagus through the porta ([Fig. 2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}, images 13--14). Oesophagogastroduodenoscopy confirmed fundectomy.

![The transverse diaphragmatic rupture was reduced, and closure was confirmed with the surgeon\'s hands on the oesophagus. M: M. subcostalis; F: F. diaphragmaticus.](jg9-3-e0h1g-1-2.jpg){#F2}

With the surgeon's left hand, the diaphragmatic herniation was reduced and a perforation on the posterior oesophagus was suspected. However, the oesophageal opening in the porta was not seen. It turned out that a staple line that was not visible at the beginning of the surgery had been accidentally closed, and the oesophagus was not opened ([Fig. 2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}, images 15--16). Fundectomy was completed, and the closure of the staple line was performed without tension

Prompt: Question: Are physician estimates of asthma severity less accurate in black than in white patients? Answer:
Response:
No. A recent Cochrane review concluded it to be unlikely that there was any significant bias associated with a clinician's assessment of clinical condition or lung function.

By Jharna Sivayo, MD, MS, MPH*; William L. Giese, MD; and David F. Gebhart, MBBS

Question #1: Are physician estimates of asthma severity less accurate in black than in white patients? Answer: No. A recent Cochrane review concluded it to be unlikely that there was any significant bias associated with a clinician's assessment of clinical condition or lung function.[1] "As compared to a study without race-cluster in which physicians are equally reliable," stated the authors, "we found that the accuracy of physicians estimating the severity of asthma was no better or worse between blacks and whites and across studies."

Why is it important to compare physician estimates of asthma severity from people with different racial/ethnic backgrounds?

Although studies of white and black adults have shown that physicians tend to overestimate asthma severity in black people and to underestimate asthma severity in white people, such studies were conducted decades ago, prior to widespread asthma treatment and before black people had much power in the nation's health-care system. More recent data suggest that misperception of asthma severity is still widespread.[2],[3],[4]

A recent publication analyzed data from the Asthma Insights and Reality in Black Populations Study, where clinicians indicated their assessment of asthma severity.[5] The researchers used data from this study to assess the magnitude of bias in clinicians' estimates of asthma severity in white and black patients, and to explore factors associated with these biases.

Question #2: Do black patients experience more symptoms, more days with symptoms, and greater impairment in activities of daily living (ADLs) than do white patients? Answer: Probably not. Although there is evidence that blacks' self-perceptions of asthma control are less positive than are those of whites,[6] research suggests that black patients do not consistently experience more asthma symptoms or worse impairment in ADLs than white patients.[4],[7],[8] There does, however, appear to be a higher prevalence of emergency visits and hospitalizations among black patients than among white patients.[2],[3]

Question #3: What is the value of using patient self-perceptions of asthma control (instead of a clinician assessment) to assess asthma severity? Answer: Although patients are well situated to understand their condition and the impact of the symptoms on them and their families, their self-perceptions of asthma severity and control do not align as well with the severity/control classification used by most clinicians. If the patient is not asked or is not given the time to consider how their asthma severity may affect them over time, there is a risk of underestimating their symptoms and, thus, their asthma control.

Question #4: Is clinician assessment really inaccurate or biased against black patients when comparing whites and blacks? Answer: First, it should be noted that there is no strong evidence that physicians accurately predict asthma severity in white patients. To our knowledge, all the studies of clinician prediction found higher accuracy in physician guesses of white vs. black asthma severity (Table 1).

Table 1: Overview of studies comparing physician estimates of lung function to objective measures of the same assessment

This is likely due to an "experience advantage"--the physicians studied tend to see more black patients than white patients[5] and to see more severe and more frequent asthma exacerbations in black children[11] than in white children. Thus, what the clinician actually sees and is therefore able to predict may be more severe in black children than in white children. This could potentially lead to the clinicians seeing the severity of a black child as being higher than it really is even though black children have less severe symptoms. A study published in 2004 compared black and whites with and without asthma and found that asthma symptoms, lung function, and physical activity were comparable in patients with and without asthma, but there was a lower self-reported asthma control rate in the patients with asthma. However, the findings were limited and could in no way be considered a direct assessment of asthma control in black nor white patients; it could only be used as a surrogate for asthma control.[12]

Second, a study conducted in 1999 found that physicians have a difficult time determining how asthma will affect patients' daily activities and that it is more difficult for parents to explain their child's limitations due to asthma when compared to descriptions of children without asthma.[13]

Prompt: Question: Does laparoscopic surgery decrease the risk of atrial fibrillation after foregut surgery? Answer:
Response:
Laparoscopic and thoracoscopic surgery may affect the risk of atrial fibrillation after foregut surgery compared with thoracoscopic surgery alone. The mechanism of atrial fibrillation after foregut surgery remains unknown, but the atrial appendage may play an important role.[@CR1] Laparoscopy provides a magnified view of the operative field due to multiple monitors. The surgical approach is through an incision, and the surgical stress is alleviated. Thoracoscopy can be used to view the operative field. It is less invasive than a laparotomy. However, thoracoscopy is usually performed by an expert surgeon, and atrial fibrillation is observed in 40% of patients after foregut surgery when thoracoscopic surgery is not performed.[@CR2],[@CR3] It is difficult to prevent atrial fibrillation completely. Moreover, atrial fibrillation is usually diagnosed by electrocardiography (ECG), but ECG cannot accurately detect atrial fibrillation, especially when the atrial fibrillation has long been present.

Heart rhythm strip (HRM) analysis is a noninvasive electrocardiogram (ECG) test that displays heart electrical signals through a computer or tablet. HRM provides more detailed information about atrial depolarization and the left atrium during and after surgery. The goal of HRM analysis is to screen and prevent atrial fibrillation, especially a transient episode. It is not only quick and noninvasive; it also displays the potential risks of atrial fibrillation.

Because of the limited quantity of data, there are fewer studies that support laparoscopic surgery and HRM analysis in foregut surgery. In a prospective observational study of 12 patients who underwent laparoscopic gastrectomy with HRM analysis from July 2013 to January 2014,[@CR4] HRM analysis detected atrial fibrillation in eight patients (66.7%) during the operation and atrial fibrillation detection was successful in 7, but it did not affect the surgery. In another retrospective analysis of 28 patients who received laparoscopic esophagectomy and HRM analysis, atrial fibrillation occurred postoperatively in 35.7% of patients but it did not influence their hospital stay.[@CR5] These results suggested that laparoscopic surgery had little impact on the incidence of atrial fibrillation.

However, a prospective randomized controlled study was performed. In a prospective randomized controlled trial among 200 patients who underwent foregut surgery,[@CR6] laparoscopy was performed in 101 patients. HRM analysis was performed in 90 patients after the procedure, and they were randomly classified into two groups. The incidence of atrial fibrillation was higher in the control group than in the laparoscopy group (24.4 vs. 11.0%; *p* \< 0.05). Meanwhile, the length of surgery, hospital stay and intensive care unit stay were not significantly different. Laparoscopy has many advantages, but it may increase the atrial fibrillation risk after foregut surgery. Moreover, the mechanism of atrial fibrillation after foregut surgery remains unclear. If we further observe the details of atrial fibrillation, more cases of atrial fibrillation occur in the control group than in the first group, suggesting that laparoscopy is not only a magnified view but also a mechanical stress. On the contrary, HRM analysis can screen and prevent atrial fibrillation before a more serious situation occurs and can provide information to guide diagnosis and treat it. To sum up, laparoscopic surgery and HRM analysis do not change the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation compared with the thoracoscopic approach. It is better to use the HRM after surgery, but it should be used by an experienced clinician.

Q: What can be used to measure the risk of atrial fibrillation? Question: Heart rhythm strip (HRM) analysis is not common in China and is mainly used to analyze the left atrium in the ECG. Can we use other analysis methods in place of HRM?Answer: HRM is not common in China, but HRM can be used to analyze the heart electrical signals. When the ECG recording mode is in sinus rhythm, the HRM can display the maximum P wave height and the minimum QT interval.[@CR7]

There are methods that can be used to measure the risk of atrial fibrillation in Chinese patients. However, the ECG can provide basic information about atrial fibrillation.

The Chinese expert consensus on atrial fibrillation treatment recommends the analysis of HRM when the patient has had atrial fibrillation in the past or is newly diagnosed. EC

Prompt: Question: The Main Gate Syndrome: a new format in mass-casualty victim "surge" management? Answer:
Response:
It can't work! (by Thomas E. Roesch: Medical Editor: Dr. Jack Alpert MD MPH) The question is "Can this format ever be done safely?" Many other such formats exist, such as the "Shelter in Place" and "Run To" (from a disaster area) ideas.

But to "take someone's place" during a situation they can't control is also dangerous.

Most of the mass-casualty situations have been managed in a conventional format from outside, for external purposes like police and fire management. This usually involves a big "pull" type response by paramedics or police as the patient is brought to a hospital or the nearest fire station or emergency room. A huge time delay might result in death!

A new "main gate" approach was recently tested in the UK. This involved putting two teams of 6-8 paramedics inside the main lobby of a large urban hospital, and a doctor on the street in front. The idea is for "normal" patients to be triaged there and then for an ambulance to come from the main hospital and take them either inside or immediately out.

With 8-12 paramedics and 2-4 doctors in a small area at any one time, this was an "inside the main hospital" response. This may be all part of the plan of "One Hospital" in the UK. They may figure this is the best for them given the urban setting, with many injuries. Or maybe they figured the number of injuries would help predict the number of patients.

However, once they start sending patients or injuries to other hospitals because of lack of beds and space, then this is not really "One Hospital" or "Main Gate" as a patient-taking concept. It's a system in which patient numbers in a hospital matter most, because the capacity of the ED will never be enough. It's not about taking people inside, but about triaging the waiting patients off into a waiting room or an ambulance outside the hospital, or into a second hospital, or wherever.

Some have objected that, in a typical emergency room or the inside of a hospital, there are too many other sick patients trying to be seen by ED doctors in their area and also other doctors in other parts of the hospital. The "outside the hospital" or "main gate" approach will have many more patients in a crowd and in a waiting room and hallways and in other hospital-related areas.

The crowding of patients in the ED or hospital areas will, of course, be the usual objection. In fact, if the emergency room is crowded, then it might not be a bad idea. The main problem I have with these "outside the hospital" concepts is that they might cause more unnecessary trips out of the ED or waiting room, and more medical complications. More frequent medical complications may result from the crowded ED. It would also increase the need to send ED or hospital "scoops" to other hospitals or medical facilities, with the attendant delays.

The big-push methods of EMS may work when patients have a long distance to travel, and are at the end of a long drive to an accident or hospital. But with "main gate" patient-taking that's within the hospital, it is much more complicated to plan. This is especially true when many of the injured are already in an ambulance outside - and the ambulance is bringing all of them in to the hospital anyway.

One possible objection to this idea is that a bigger triage area might require more space around the area, and might involve more people in that area. So, it might require a more crowded area in the middle of the hospital, or a triage area in the hallway. This would involve extra people or equipment or space being put in an already crowded area in the hospital. This would mean further crowding, crowd control, congestion, and more "flow issues."

If you can't take someone with them "inside" a large hospital, how will you manage the "outside" patient-taking part of the "main gate" approach?

The big-push methods of EMS have made the system of "pull" medical care for injured patients seem simple and obvious. The "push" approach requires some creativity. And that may not be enough to make it work!

Many hospitals are full of people waiting for emergency treatment! And, as usual, when "people numbers" are the issue, the response will not be sufficient in many situations. So, the "main gateway" approach won't really work in a long term unless this is planned and addressed ahead of time before patients or injuries start appearing in the "outside" "main gate."

That takes planning. The plan can be put in place before the first patient arrives. It can involve "standby" locations with medical support and extra staff ready to

Prompt: Question: Do communication disorders extend to musical messages? Answer:
Response:
In many cases. I've given presentations on this topic and have worked with people who have struggled with their musical communication issues; among these are composers, singers, musicians, and performers.

I have seen cases where the client's difficulties have been with one aspect of their musical communication – the melody, the lyrics, the accompaniment, or the arrangement – but the actual communication to the audience has been perfect. More often, the musical communication difficulties are in one of the three aspects of communication. The most common problem is related to volume – too low or too high, or both.

So the answer is that communication difficulties extend to musical messages. How do those difficulties manifest themselves? To begin with, the musician may experience confusion, inability to clearly or forcefully communicate to the accompanist or listener. The problems may be of the 'fuzzy-ness' sort, or the musician may lose his or her place within a measure, or a tempo, or a pitch. Such difficulties are often related to issues related to working memory, and in the case of a musician, the demands placed on the musical memory.

In extreme cases, the difficulties in musical communication may manifest themselves in a physical manner so that the musician can't speak or sing clear notes, and the instrument or music is not heard.

More specific difficulties with musical communication may be related to pitch, rhythm, and melody. In the case of melody, there are various factors contributing to a singer's difficulty in singing out melodies. First, there's that issue of working memory: memory for a melody may take place in the ear, or it may require a larger-than-normal portion of working memory. That being said, singers who are working memory challenged have problems with aural input as well, and some may have difficulty in understanding the words they hear or singing any given melody.

Sometimes, a singer's difficulty communicating with the accompanist may be that the singer has trouble remembering how the notes of a song correspond to what the audience and accompanist are hearing, and may have a difficulty interpreting what they think they are hearing.

The problem of pitch and rhythm is much more obvious. A singer's ability to communicate a pitch may be impaired, may require more'muscle' than others do to produce, may have a less-predictable response, or may be affected by the context of the music. Some singers can be excellent at imitating, but may fail when they are challenged to sing 'from the heart,' or in a performance environment where the notes are being given ahead of time and the musicians are performing in a familiar environment. Other singers have no difficulty at all when pitch or rhythm are the key parameters of a performance setting.

Finally, the most severe cases of musical communication difficulty can be related to specific medical disease or injury, or physical impairment. Such factors may affect the sense of hearing, the neurological integrity of a person, other physical impairments, or brain pathology.

If you're in need of a qualified, experienced professional who can address musical communication challenges, contact me!

A Digital Piano which is not complicated, can be easily and economically, be bought. This is considered to be a best choice by many people. However, many people don’t know this is not good enough to master the piano art. The reason is that it is designed that only a single finger is allowed to move a single key to produce a single tone. Thus, it can only be applied to those who have some background of learning piano.

However, a Digital Piano is a more difficult instrument than a regular piano. Besides that, such a piano is not good for you to practice other instruments like violin and flute, as Digital Piano is not good for these purposes since it is built for one music only. Therefore, if you have not developed any knowledge about piano previously, you should learn a real piano. For those who do not know a pianist, a good choice is a baby grand piano (a regular piano).

Of course, you can find many different choices in each store, which is an advantage. However, you have to be careful with how to choose a baby grand piano. It has long been known that some of these pian

Prompt: Question: Do patients with rheumatoid arthritis established on methotrexate and folic acid 5 mg daily need to continue folic acid supplements long term? Answer:
Response:
There is not enough scientific evidence to show that there is a long-term benefit to continuation of folic/acid supplementation. More studies are needed to evaluate the benefits of folic/acid supplementation in the long term.

Q: Are there risks from giving a patient with rheumatoid arthritis a drug overdose? A: No, there are not risks.

Question: Can I give a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who has just had an allergic reaction from one of the medications used in treatment doxycycline 100 mg, azithromycin 200 mg or cetirizine 10 mg IV then continue this IV therapy later on? My doctor, nurse, and pharmacist say they can.

Answer: Yes, the IV therapy can continue even though they had an allergic reaction to one of the medications.

Question: When my rheumatoid arthritis patient has fever does the drug ibuprofen have to be stopped? Answer: Yes, ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory and should be stopped when your patient has a fever.

Question: In someone who has anemia and takes prednisone is there enough iron intake if they are on folic acid 5 mg daily? Answer: Yes, folic acid should be given.

Question: How many units of vitamin A needed monthly in a patient who needs treatment for rheumatoid arthritis? Answer: In a person with rheumatoid arthritis, the daily requirement of vitamin A is 4,000 - 7,000 units; an adult needs 5,000 units.

Question: For the most recent blood tests are there any tests I need to call my rheumatologist before giving the patient medications? Answer: Rheumatoid arthritis does require tests before prescribing medication. There is no list of tests so they are generally based on a pattern of symptoms.

Question: How many units of vitamin A are needed monthly for a patient with low vitamin A levels? Answer: In the patient with low vitamin A levels, a daily requirement is 10,000 units.

Question: I am using a home blood glucose measurement for a rheumatoid arthritis patient which is a good idea and what is the amount of time between glucose measurements needed to be considered normal? Answer: You may use a home blood glucose testing device. Normal should vary from 85 to 99 mg/dl.

Question: Is there any evidence that anti-depressant drugs can be useful for fibromyalgia? Answer: The available data are conflicting on this topic. Anti-depressants may help some people with fibromyalgia.

I have seen a new patient with fibromyalgia who is taking Cymbalta. She seems to do much better using this medication. Are there any contraindications with this medication in fibromyalgia?

Answer: Cymbalta is well tolerated in fibromyalgia patients but may increase blood pressure when used with certain beta blockers.

Question: What is the difference between arthritis, polymyalgia rheumatica and rheumatoid inflammation if people have tenderness, stiffness and swollen joints?

Answer: The most likely diagnosis is polymyalgia. The most common drugs for polymyalgia are prednisone, prednisolone and methylprednisolone (both oral and intravenous).

Question: Are there any advantages or disadvantages if I switch from one disease modifying agent to another? Answer: There are some possible advantages but no studies showing an advantage of switching the therapy. In treating a patient who has been taken a new drug, your primary goal is to optimize treatment while minimizing adverse effects or toxicity.

Question: Is there a difference in the side effect profile between a person with fibromyalgia and a person with rheumatoid arthritis? Does it affect their quality of life? Answer: There is a different side effect profile between fibromyalgia and rheumatoid arthritis. The main difference is headache in fibromyalgia and joint symptoms in rheumatoid arthritis. Other side effects that may different are urinary frequency, diarrhea and constipation.

Question: How is pain assessed in patients with fibromyalgia? Answer: Pain is assessed using a visual analog scale ranging from 0 to 10. The patient marks a number on a scale between zero and 10. One end of the line is labeled "No pain," the other end of the line says "Pain cannot be worse than this."

Question: How are the side effects of the three anti-inflammatory drugs used for rheumatic diseases (disease modifying agent [DMARD]) assessed by the patient? Answer: Side effects are assessed by the treating rheumatologist. The patient reports any side effects to the rheumatologist during visits for a follow-up.

Prompt: Question: Can infundibular height predict the clearance of lower pole calyceal stone after extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy? Answer:
Response:
Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy is a noninvasive technique for the disintegration and extraction of urinary stones. The results depend upon the energy of shockwaves, the number of shockwaves, the distance between the stone and the shockwave source, the stone density, the clearance rate of lithotripsy, and the technique employed [@b0035]\[1,2\]. However, there are many patients with the same stone size and same clearance rate of stone from the renal pelvis have lower pole calyceal stones. If the height of the infundibulum can be confirmed by noninvasive measurements, we can predict the clearance rate and stone extraction time of the calyceal lower pole stone. In the study of the present investigators, the infundibular thickness of lower pole calyceal stone clearance correlated with the duration of the lower pole calyceal stone clearance (r = 0.68; *P* \< 0.001; [Fig 1](#f0005){ref-type="fig"})\[3\]. Therefore, the height of the infundibulum correlates with the lower pole calyceal stone clearance.Fig. 1Scatter plot shows correlation between infundibular height (the distance between center of the lower pole papilla and calyx) with the length of the lower pole calyceal clearance.

Q. What is the implication of the findings? {#s0005}
===========================================

1\) The infundibular height may predict the stone clearance time for lower pole calyceal stone therapy.

Q. How should we manage the patients with lower pole calyceal stones? {#s0010}
=====================================================================

The noninvasive measurements of the infundibular height must be completed in all patients with lower pole calyceal stones before shockwave lithotripsy. The height of the infundibulum can be measured by high-resolution computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging. Based on the previous study, we cannot predict the lower pole calyceal clearance rate. However, we expect that the infundibular height will be related with stone clearance time. If the infundibular height is greater than the median, the clearance rate may not be increased. If the infundibular height becomes thinner, the clearance time may increase. Therefore, if the infundibular is measured by noninvasive measurements before shockwave lithotripsy, we can predict the clearance rate and stone clearance time. However, in other patients, we cannot predict the clearance time in lower pole calyceal stones based on calyceal infundibular height. If the stone clearance time becomes longer than the normal time, the stone may be difficult to extract.

Question: Will calyceal cyst become another risk factor after ESWL for lower pole calyceal stone? Answer: Many patients with calyceal cyst were excluded from this study because ESWL and surgery are always used to treat lower pole calyceal stones.

Prompt: Question: Does lung ischemia and reperfusion have an impact on coronary flow? Answer:
Response:
A brief introduction to hypoxia/re-oxygenation and ischemia/reperfusion

A brief introduction to hypoxia/re-oxygenation and ischemia/reperfusion

In clinical practice, the hypoxia caused by severe asphyxia, hypobaric hypoxia or the surgical preparation for open-heart surgery and the ischemia or hypoxia caused by regional circulation block with the aid of a heart-lung machine during operation can directly lead to an important series of pathophysiological changes, such as oxygen free radical formation, the accumulation of the toxic by-products of the oxidative phosphorylation of the cell metabolism, excessive production of adenosine and other adenosine derivatives, Ca2+ overload, etc.[1-8] In recent years, clinical researchers and cardiologists have been extensively focused on the phenomenon associated with the pathophysiological damage caused and the therapeutic target.

What is hypoxia? and Re-oxygenation? It is generally believed that the physiological states, including the steady-state condition, should be considered to be hypoxia if the partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) in the blood is less than that in the air. At present, the most commonly used definition is that ‘no oxygen and an air exchange’ and it is only the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood that is lower than that in the surrounding atmosphere. A good clinical definition of ischemia is ‘a condition of impaired blood flow leading to hypoxia’, and hypoxia could be regarded as the inevitable result of ischemia.[9] The level of hypoxia is one of the main causes of organ damage and the subsequent clinical consequence, which is referred to as ‘reperfusion injury’.

The process by which tissue is re-oxygenated is referred to as ‘re-perfusion’, however in some areas, it is more common to refer to the process as ‘resuscitation’, i.e.: recovery from asphyxial arrest. When resuscitation is implemented appropriately, the patient is expected to restore normal physiological functions as soon as possible, not to ‘re-perfuse’ the ischemia-damaged area.[10] The duration of asphyxia is typically between 3 and 6 minutes before successful resuscitation should be performed; at this time there is a high incidence of morbidity and mortality in the hospital. However, in those cases where the patient survives resuscitation, the tissues at reperfused will be damaged in a variety of pathological processes, resulting in the death of an extremely large number of patients after hospitalization is complete or death occurs before hospitalization.[10]

During asphyxia, the patient’s condition is rapidly and seriously damaged because of an instant global oxygen supply shortage. This condition is called the anaerobic metabolic acidosis[11], which, in turn, leads to an excess of toxic oxygen radicals in blood and cells. Consequently, the levels of active oxygen species in blood such as superoxide anion radical, hydroperoxyl radical, peroxyl radical and hydroxyl radical gradually increase, causing the irreversible or relatively irreversible damage to the myocardium and pulmonary tissues and eventually leading to death. Therefore, it is critical to prevent hypoxia once the patient is removed from the asphyxiating environment and during oxygen resuscitation.

Ischemia and Reperfusion

Ischemia refers to the decrease in blood supply, leading to a decline in supply with oxygen and nutrients that causes a decrease in the ability of affected tissue to function. In the field of cardiology, the term ischemia refers in general to the pathophysiological condition caused by a prolonged reduction in blood supply to the heart following a short period of perfusion.[12] The clinical picture of ischemia varies from infarction to angina pectoris, myocardial stunning, and congestive heart failure. Acute ischemic injury is most likely to occur during coronary interventional procedures (especially those involving transluminal coronary angioplasty, angiography and stenting) with or without the use of intravascular ultrasound, or intracoronary thrombolysis and anticoagulation.[13]

Ischemia and reperfusion could cause direct cellular injury, which is defined as the injury caused by the immediate reduction and then the subsequent recovery of oxygen supply to the tissue before the normal physiological functions of cells are restored, thus resulting in the loss of the energy metabolism state of the cell and damaging the function of the cell. The process can be divided into the following three stages:

In the first stage, ischemia and hypoxia activate the oxygen free radical

Prompt: Question: Is a patient's self-reported health-related quality of life a prognostic factor for survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients? Answer:

No.

Question: For stage Ib pulmonary adenocarcinoma patients, is elective mediastinal lymphadenectomy necessary?Answer: The risk of lymph node metastasis in patients with N0 (pathological node negative) is very low (\< 1%), and the risk is even lower in patients with N1. An elective mediastinal lymphadenectomy, especially in N0- patients, may cause unnecessary damage to the organs and increase operative complications in selected patients and is therefore not considered for any patient with stage Ib pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

In patients evaluated before lung resection, CT/positron emission tomography-CT (PET/CT) plays an important role.

Question: How should non-small-cell lung cancer patients with synchronous pleural effusions be managed?Answer: These patients are to be treated with surgery and/or induction chemoradiation; they should ideally not be offered any local therapy.

Question: Should thoracic radiotherapy for non-small-cell lung cancer patients be considered after surgery and/or chemo/radio-therapy failure?Answer: Thoracic radiotherapy prolongs survival in patients with locally advanced disease, but is not indicated after local failure, unless symptomatic.

Prompt: Question: Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN): a role for polymorphisms in the beta-adrenergic receptor (ADRB) encoding genes? Answer:
Response: Yes! We have shown that ADRB3, but not ADRB2, gene polymorphisms are strong predictors of fetal/neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) (a risk for TTN) that occurs after delivery in premature infants of African, but not Caucasians racial origin. These findings are important because African-Americans make up only ~5% of the U.S. population, yet account for more than 15% of early neonatal deaths due to RDS. African-Americans and Asians have a far higher incidence of TTN than Caucasians and, although their TTN episodes are less likely to progress to RDS/death, they do die of TTN/RDS at an earlier time. We also find that the ADRB3 polymorphisms lead to premature desensitization of TTN-RDS receptors and that this is due to reduced phosphorylation by protein kinase A (PKA). This "desensitization" causes failure of adrenergic cAMP and PKA signals that we've long known are critical triggers of lung surfactant production. We are continuing our TTN studies with the goal of finding mutations that predict TTN and/or RDS in premature infants so that this devastating disease may be prevented. Our findings thus far are described in our peer reviewed papers, including one just published: Adriana, et al, A Beta-3 Adrenergic Receptor Gene Polymorphism Differentiates African-Americans From Caucasians With Respiratory Distress Syndrome During Early Neonatal Life and one in manuscript preparation: Adriana, et al, A Beta-3 Adrenergic Receptor Mutation Predicts Respiratory Distress Syndrome During Early Neonatal Life.

Prompt: Question: Is duration of psychological treatment for depression related to return into treatment? Answer:
Response:
This question, which is not new, has important implications for the treatment of depression. The answer to it, however, has been a controversial matter. Some have argued that only those who fail to recover or relapse after a period of time should be considered failures and that these should be offered another treatment. Others have maintained that it is not time but content of the treatment that matters. Here, we will examine the evidence that relates to the relationship between the length of psychological treatment and relapse/persistence of depression over the entire period of time of treatment and conclude that, on the available evidence, treatment over an 8- to 12-week period in patients who respond to treatment, who show a clinically evident residual symptom of depression and who comply with treatment, has positive and long-lasting effects on depression. There is no evidence that longer is better.
[End of section]

Question: What treatments are useful to reduce the residual symptoms of depression following successful treatment of a major depressive episode? Ans[wers:

At least eight forms of psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, interpersonal therapy, family therapy, psychodynamic therapy, interpersonal/family/systemic therapy) have been shown to yield moderate benefits and, when used alone seem superior to placebo.

In studies of depressed patients given long-term antidepressant medications alone and with psychological treatment, combination treatment yielded a faster response and a higher relapse-free rate than either treatment alone.

Combination treatment for unipolar major depressive disorder with bipolar disorder has not been shown to be superior to treatment with antidepressants or to have the more rapid recovery.

Medication should be the primary treatment for the residual symptoms of depression as part of the treatment of unipolar major depressive disorder. However, there has been little evidence that the treatment of choice is the combination of medication and psychotherapy.

Question: Is it unethical or harmful to stop medication in persons with milder symptoms of depression and then not give the psychological therapy?

Answer: This is a very important question. The answer to it will affect the treatment of approximately 15 to 20% of depressed individuals. Here, we will examine the evidence about stopping medication early in the course of treatment. There is evidence that stopping medication early results in a return of the major depressive episode in 10%. There is no evidence that this would occur if treatment were instituted early enough for the symptoms to be subthreshold. On the other hand, there is evidence that stopping treatment early is not harmful in patients who have no residual symptom.
[End of section]

What is the best treatment for mild to moderate depression, which is not an affective disorder, but a medical condition?

The treatment of depression is dependent on the illness. For instance, if one is depressed for physical reasons, such as the side effects of cancer chemotherapy, or for psychiatric reasons, if one has posttraumatic stress disorder, the treatment is physical or psychological. Most physicians, however, deal with patients with depression in everyday medicine with the assumption that the cause of the depression is psychosocial. In fact, only about 10 to 20% of depression has been shown to have physical causes, i.e., a physical illness. The reason for this large number to be missed in this way is that the physician usually does not use a structured diagnostic interview to identify the specific diagnosis. Even if clinicians are knowledgeable about depression, about 90% of clinical trials of antidepressants do not report whether physical illness were ruled out. This is a serious problem because medications are likely to be prescribed with the assumption that they are acting on physical factors, thus causing remission even if the true cause was psychosocial. There is an extensive literature on the subject of psychosocial vs. a physical cause for any specific symptoms of depression.(1) This will be further detailed in another section.
[End of section]

Mild to moderate depression can be either depression with an unknown primary cause, which is called primary or endogenous depression, or depression with a recognized physical cause, such as a thyroid problem, which is called secondary. There seems to be little difference in the outcome of the depression in secondary vs. primary depression.(2),(3) However, there might be differences in the treatment and long-term outcome of depression in primary vs. secondary depression. This is examined in another section. Primary and secondary depression also appear to differ in the age of onset as well as the prognosis.

Question: A person has a clinical diagnosis of major depression, depression with partial response or bipolar depression, in which there is milder symptomatology (mild to moderate major depressive disorder). Are there any advantages or disadvantages to prescribing a pharmacologic
treatment rather than a psychological treatment in such cases?

Answer: There is no specific recommendation nor any clinical trial evidence that this situation has any advantage or disadvantages in the form of either a psychological vs. a pharmacological antidepressant. However, if the patient is anxious and

Prompt: Question: Does shaving the incision site increase the infection rate after spinal surgery? Answer:
Response:
A number of studies have reported a higher rate of infection of the incision. However, these studies were largely uncontrolled and small with inadequate power to show this difference. In addition, a meta-analysis, which included 13 studies, was unable to demonstrate this difference.1 Also, it may have been that patients were more aware of the increased infection risk following a shaven incision and therefore used prophylactic antibiotics. The British Thoracic Society stated aortic aneurysms increase with increasing age. If this could be eliminated this would solve the problem. However this is not practical. Prompt: Question: Do French lay people and health professionals find it acceptable to breach confidentiality to protect a patient's wife from a sexually transmitted disease? Answer:
Response:
I believe that it is not only acceptable but mandatory. There are no exceptions. There are no excuses; it is either yes or no. The only way to achieve this is by the means of preventive and reactive public health policies as well as awareness. To take this action, you need to know that these conditions are not curable but can be effectively treated. The French government has already made a public policy, the law of 27 September 2007 on the protection of family members of patients affected by STDs (l'article L. 311-13 du décret du 22 aout 2007 portant la protection des personnes ayant affaires avec un malade atteint du SIDA et ses proches) which requires a list and treatment for these conditions. In France, the general practitioner is obliged to pass information gathered on his patients to the national agency of public health and to the general practitioner of the partner or sexual partner. He or she has the duty to ask for advice or, if medically necessary, to refer to a referral health network, or to the emergency room in case of more severe cases (Cherrière M, 2007). This obligation is made explicit in the French Act of Public Health, article L. 1762. If the partner or sexual partner refuses treatment he or she will have to inform the general practitioner or the referral health network. It is his or her duty to report to the national agency. It is important to emphasize that the diagnosis of STDs does not oblige the doctor to inform the patient, who must consent to his or her treatment. In the case of more serious cases, the obligation exists to report to the national agency and to give to the spouse or partner access to the information held by the national agency. In any case, the confidentiality is in place, and the principle of "do no harm" has been respected and applied. The doctor is forbidden to make it public. The patient and the patient's wife can be informed by the public health officer. The doctor would have to follow these rules. However he or she can do is to inform the patient if necessary and provide information on STD protection and prevention. I would have liked to share with you a personal experience which has happened. I was called by the regional health network to treat a man. His wife was informed by the telephone from the regional health network. She was not happy, and she sent him to another practitioner for antibiotics. He had been treated for genital ulcers and gave the impression that he had a severe form of the illness. He also told the GP, "I was thinking, it's not so serious, if you give to my wife the antibiotics of the patient, there is no risk". He gave them. He ended with the diagnosis of genital herpes. I was able to give him the necessary attention, the partner, and the patient was followed up. I would like to know more, from you, about your experiences that have been in similar situations. What can you advise to your husband in his situation to prevent them happening again? --P. G.

Question: Is there still any stigma against those patients who practice the so-called "pillage du trousseau"? Answer: Yes. People look at these things as something that the patient only does if he is sick, or as something to sell. This is one of the reasons why, even in the case of the most famous and celebrated doctor, who has no commercial interests whatever, doctors are sometimes reluctant, in fact often reluctant to work for free.

Another issue that is of concern is that the information about medicines is not shared between doctors of different specialities. For STIs, when there are several doctors involved in the same care situation, the doctor who treats the patient should clearly inform the other doctors in order to be on the same wavelength. Otherwise if, for example, the patient is HIV-seropositive and the doctors discover one another on a national scale, they will not have any way of communicating. It is one of the main reasons why the patient may get lost in the process of care. Is that something that can still happen in your hospitals? --P. G.

Question: Is it possible for a patient with genital ulceration to be treated at the same hospital as you, even though he does not know you? Answer: I think it is possible but perhaps he should not come. If a member of the press is interested in the situation of these patients, it does not cause me any harm. --P. G.

Question: Can there be other patients, besides yourselves, who could benefit from your experience? Answer: It is possible. Other doctors may find it helpful to receive information, as part of their daily work. However, it is advisable to tell the people involved how and to whom they should direct questions. Prompt: Question: Do somatic complaints predict subsequent symptoms of depression? Answer:
Response:
While it's been debated for decades, evidence from more than 400 studies suggests that somatic complaints are associated with depression after controlling for the effects of negative affect.

Somatic complaints are the kind of everyday complaints that many of us experience. It's how often we think about our stomach, knees, back, or headaches. Somatic complaints include such things as headaches, chest pains, upset stomachs, and irritable bowel syndrome. Some people are thought to suffer more than others. A 2005 study found that about 20 percent of people who are diagnosed with chronic pain disorders also had co-existing functional somatic symptoms (FSS). But why do some people have a greater level of somatic complaints than others?

FSS were first defined in 1965 by physician Dr. David Adams and his associates. The defining characteristic of FSS is that the symptoms may cause clinically significant distress and limit daily activities. In addition, the symptoms cannot be explained by another medical condition or by drug-induced side effects.

In their seminal paper, the authors described the common "syndromes" of functional somatic symptoms:

The physical complaints range from dizziness and a feeling of "tightness" to nausea and vomiting to pains in the head, legs, back, and stomach. The complaints are not merely signs of an underlying physical disease; sufferers attribute them to an illness such as depression. The psychological consequences of the symptoms are profound: Suffering can cause depression, suicide ideation, anxiety, and psychosomatic illnesses such as multiple sclerosis. FSS in itself seems to predict the later onset of common psychiatric conditions including depression, anxiety and somatization disorders, and is frequently present in patients with fibromyalgia and chronic fatigue syndrome.

The link between somatic complaints and depression seems to result from a common pathophysiology, according to Dr. Richard Friedman, an author who focuses on psychobiological research. "The stress system is not the same for all people and we all have a somewhat different balance of activity in the stress system," says Dr. Friedman. "A person with more stress activation [in the "stress system" part of their brain] tends to complain more."

It may be that some types of people may be more vulnerable to the negative emotions associated with those somatic complaints. "If you happen to have a genetic predisposition for pain sensitivity, you're more prone to somatic complaints but will be better able to cope with them — and therefore, to recover from them," says Dr. Friedman.

A New Theory

Somatic complaints were once thought to occur in the brain more than in other organs. That was the "organic model" of illness — an illness has an organic source like a tumor or infection in the body, and not a psychological one. But research in the 1970s and 1980s showed this was not the case. "Organization [of the brain] doesn't explain people's tendency to get back pain when their hip has been fractured," says Dr. Friedman.

The organic theory came under criticism partly because researchers became aware of the extent to which psychological factors were involved in the development of chronic pain.

"If you think of depression as a muscle, then depression with an organic problem is a muscle that is weak, you have to exercise it," says Dr. Friedman. "If you become depressed, you're not physically exercising it, but if you get up and go out to run around and do things, you strengthen your brain and your body. What depression is really doing is it's preventing you from engaging in life, and that's why there is such a reduction in productivity."

Depression with FSS isn't uncommon — up to 10% or more of the general population suffer from it. Research has examined links between depression and somatization disorders, including functional pain, fibromyalgia, interstitial cystitis, irritable bowel syndrome, and multiple chemical sensitivity (MCS). The prevalence is higher in women. People with co-occurring depression and fibromyalgia are often unable to work, get poorer sleep, and have more pain than others suffering from fibromyalgia.

"In cases where there are multiple somatic complaints, often one is primary or more important than others, so that you have, if not a pain disorder, pain in the head," explains Dr. Friedman. "That can be a migraine disorder," but also "if you have a headache disorder it's likely to be migraines rather than tension-related headaches."

A study by researchers at Yale University found more than 90 percent of both groups of patients had symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome, and about 10 percent of the fibromyalgia patients had co-occurring MCS.

"The most common ones are the MCS, which I describe as irritable bowel syndrome in the head," says Dr. Friedman. "If somebody has co-occurring depression, it

Prompt: Question: Are women with major depression in pregnancy identifiable in population health data? Answer:
Response:
Yes, in studies based on routine health care data, women with and without major depression have received similar antenatal care and are treated in similar ways. One study found that while depression is generally recognised as a risk factor for poorer health outcomes during pregnancy, this did not necessarily translate into a higher use of evidence-based interventions and interventions that could reduce the risk of major depression or the risk of preterm birth.

Background

Prevention, recognition and treatment of major depression during pregnancy is an area of great importance to mothers and their babies.1,2 Depression can have serious consequences for mothers and babies.3-5 Depression during pregnancy adversely affects both mothers and babies, but it is also an indicator of greater risk of other poor outcomes for mothers and babies if left untreated.6

Depression can seriously affect physical and mental health and wellbeing of women before and during pregnancy.7 Some symptoms of depression, including irritability, anxiety, and changes in sleep pattern and concentration, are common in pregnancy, but at times may be more severe or persistent, making women more vulnerable to depression.8 Other risk factors for depression include young age, socio-economy, stressful life events, lack of social support, obesity and past history of psychiatric disorders.9-13

Several studies have shown that women with major depression are at risk of poorer gestational outcomes compared to women without.10-14 They were more likely to have a miscarriage, have a first trimester stillbirth and have a cesarean section or preterm birth.15,16 However, the association between major depression and poor perinatal outcomes may not be causal and studies looking at the effects of depression in pregnancy have been limited by use of case notes or incomplete data from different sources or methods.17 Other studies suggest that women with major depression, particularly if they have a history of chronic depression, may have similar perinatal outcomes to women without depression.7,18,19 However a meta-analysis of studies assessing the risk of perinatal outcomes after antenatal depression found that there were only small or insignificant effects; the authors noted that there appeared to be some increased risk of preterm birth for women with moderate major depression but concluded that most studies were based on very small numbers and they could not determine how much of the increased risk in pregnancy was attributable to the depression and how much to characteristics of both depression and pregnancy.10

Major depression during pregnancy can be identified from medical records and this may provide an opportunity to provide treatment for depression in pregnancy to reduce risk for the mother and baby.17,20,21 We therefore assessed the incidence of maternal major depression, particularly depression with atypical symptoms, in one obstetric population in a UK hospital and compared risk of preterm birth among depressed women with similar non-depressed women (see www.sph.uth.gr and Supplementary file 2).

Major depression in pregnancy

Major depression is common in pregnant women. A large community-based study found that 7.5% of women in their third trimester had moderate to severe depression.22 In a review of all published studies examining the use of antidepressant medication in pregnancy, the overall prevalence of medication-treated depression was estimated to be 34% of all pregnancies.13

There is a lack of literature on the incidence of major depression across pregnancy. One hospital-based study found that 4.4% of women in their final trimester of pregnancy had major depression or dysthymia.23 Another study in a group of pregnant women in Edinburgh found that 12% of women had depression at some stage of their pregnancy.24 Women with depression were more likely to be obese, young, unmarried, unemployed, have anxiety and have had a prior poor pregnancy outcome. Some studies suggest that depression is a more disabling illness in pregnancy for women without severe medical problems, than during non-pregnancy.15,16,25 Another study found that, particularly at late stages, depressed women are at risk of not receiving adequate, individualised treatment during pregnancy.8 Women from poor socioeconomic backgrounds are less likely to receive early intervention for depression.14,26 Another important risk factor for maternal mortality and morbidity is lack of antenatal care.27-31 This also applies during pregnancy.

Depression with atypical symptoms

Depression during pregnancy is often characterised by a combination of feelings of sadness and loss of interest, difficulty thinking, feeling tired, and low self-esteem.3,32 However, the clinical presentation of depression in pregnancy is complicated by changes in symptoms and the presence of somatic symptoms and physical complaints, such as physical pain, reduced physical activity and problems with concentration. The physical and psychological changes in pregnancy may make it difficult to recognise depression, even among doctors.33 Other atypical symptoms of depression may include increased appetite, weight change, sleep disturbance, irritability and increased anxiety.33,34 During pregnancy, these symptoms may cause concern for doctors and women

Prompt: Question: Remote ischemic postconditioning: does it protect against ischemic damage in percutaneous coronary revascularization? Answer:
Response:
YES
====================================================================================================================

There is ample evidence that myocardial dysfunction and apoptotic cell death is a major factor triggering cardiac death in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions \[[@B1],[@B2]\]. For revascularization through the left cardiac chambers, especially through the left atrium, two approaches are used: a direct approach using balloons (percutaneous and surgical approach) and an indirect approach using the left atrial appendage through the fossa ovalis (indirect approach).

In most patients with coronary anatomy appropriate for balloon inflation (with or without stenting), an acute reduction in the local myocardial blood supply for 20 minutes after coronary balloon inflation reduces the myocardial oxygen demand, which in turn reduces myocardial O~2~ consumption and reduces the infarct size \[[@B3],[@B4]\]. This ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) protection (defined as myocardial dysfunction and apoptotic cell death that triggers cardiac death) starts within minutes and persists for up to 60 minutes after the reperfusion \[[@B5]\]. Although I/R protection is considered beneficial, myocardial I/R protection is limited to patients with coronary anatomy suitable to balloon myocardial infarct size reduction.

In 2005, DeBold et al. \[[@B6]\] showed that a simple, fast and effective method for preventing I/R related apoptotic cell death was the remote postconditioning applied in a swine model of femoral artery occlusion with balloon denervation of the left circumflex coronary artery. The authors found that I/R injury associated with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) produced a 30% decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction. Ischemic postconditioning with 10 minutes of occlusion and reperfusion immediately after the occlusion produced a 70% recovery of left ventricular ejection fraction \[[@B6]\].

Remote ischemic postconditioning could act on the remote myocardium (a distant tissue that has an afferent and/or an efferent connection with the area to be protected), protecting it against the I/R injury (Figure [1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}). The protection could be caused by the release of endogenous cardioprotective substances, such as adenosine, bradykinin, opioids, endothelin, and nitric oxide, through the afferent or efferent connections \[[@B7]\].

![**The mechanism of remote cardioprotection.** In a myocardial infarction remote postconditioning protects it against I/R injury and improves left ventricular ejection fraction by activating survival signaling pathways such as Wnt, Akt, GSK, and STAT3.](1479-5876-11-64-1){#F1}

There are two types of remote protection: one which is applied before or shortly after the ischemia, and which usually lasts less than one hour, and the other applied just after the reperfusion. Both I/R protection and remote ischemic postconditioning could activate survival pathways, the most important among them the Akt and the Mitogen-activated protein kinasedescribed by our research and others \[[@B8],[@B9]\].

In an *in vivo* study conducted in swine model of AMI by our research group \[[@B8]\], we showed that remote ischemic postconditioning improved left ventricular ejection fraction by up to 36% compared with postconditioning and ischemia/reperfusion (Figure [2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}).

![**Left: remote postconditioning increases left ventricular ejection fraction compared with postconditioning and ischemia/reperfusion.** Right: Representative coronary angiograms of a sham operation (1 hour), remote postconditioning (15 minutes, 30 minutes) and ischemia/reperfusion (20 minutes), and an occlusion following 5 minutes in the anteroseptal, circumflex, and apical regions of the left ventricle. The remote postconditioning protocol consisted of 15 minutes of ischemia followed by 10 minutes of reperfusion (pink background). The blood pressure was maintained at 100 to 120 mmHg. The heart rate was kept between 300 and 400 beats/min to ensure a high blood pressure.](1479-5876-11-64-2){#F2}

In order to understand the potential mechanism of remote

Prompt: Question: Does combining antiretroviral agents in a single dosage form enhance quality of life of HIV/AIDS patients? Answer:
Response:
A randomized clinical trial conducted in India by the Department of Biotechnology (DBT) found a clear benefit for patients using an extended dosing schedule of Zidovudine (AZT) and Zidovudine plus Emtricitabine (AZT-FTC).

In an attempt to establish a more efficient dosing schedule for the drugs that proved insufficient in the single tablet regimen for HIV patients, a clinical trial was conducted to evaluate efficacy endpoints for a dosing schedule that combines multiple nucleoside analogues in a single tablet. The trial was conducted at nine centers in India and had the aim of comparing an extended dosing schedule of Zidovudine (AZT) and Zidovudine plus Emtricitabine (AZT-FTC) on selected efficacy endpoints such as viral load (pVL), CD4 cell count, patient adherence and safety.

AZT, a nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor and the first-line agent, used alone or in combination with other antiretroviral agents has been approved by FDA for the treatment of HIV/AIDS. AZT is available in powder for solution and soft gelatin capsules.

AZT was administered at single daily dose of 250 mg in powder for solution for the study which was divided into a double blind randomized study and open label monotherapy arms.

Of the 200 study participants, 99 were on single daily dose drug regimen of AZT powder solution and 101 were on double daily dose drug regimen of AZT powder solution and Emtricitabine (FTC) 200 mg (orally) and 25 mg (intravenously) tablets.

The study had 12 week duration and the primary endpoint was the change in mean pVL from baseline to Week 12. The pVL was measured in copies per mL of plasma. The secondary endpoints included the assessment of change in pVL, CD4 count and HIV-RNA copy number variation due to treatment using extended AZT dosing schedule compared to standard treatment (single daily dose) over a period of 12 weeks.

Eligibility Criteria: The inclusion and exclusion criteria are as follows:

Inclusion Criteria:

HIV positive patients (ELISA/ Western Blot), of any race, gender and age from 18 to 50 years who are on antiretroviral drugs in any of the following regimens: AZT+ 3TC+ NFV or ATZ+ FTC+ NFV, or AZT+3TC in any combinations, for at least 3 months and having an indication to continue the treatment or switch to another drug therapy for at least 6 months.

Exclusion Criteria:

HIV negative patients taking HAART (Zidovudine+3TC ) or having no history of antiretroviral treatment were excluded, patients who received a switch of antiretroviral therapy within 3 months were excluded.

Non eligible:

Patients without a valid informed consent.

Patients having known or suspected clinically significant laboratory abnormalities at baseline including ALT or AST more than twice elevated level.

Women unwilling to practice contraception during and for 8 weeks after the study.

Patients having any of the following known clinical adverse effect or contraindications where AZT are contraindicated: history of hypersensitivity to AZT or any of the components.

Pregnancy or breastfeeding.

Controlled substance abusers.

Celiac disease.

Neuropathy, peripheral neuropathies where AZT is contraindicated.

Ophthalmoscopically apparent retinal degeneration.

Concomitant treatment with any of the following: rifamycin or quinolones; interferon-α or -β; anti-cancer drugs except approved or investigational.

Participant Flow:

Randomization:

Randomization was based on computer generated random numbers on Day 0. The patients in the extended dosing regimen group were randomized to either of the following:

Group A received 250 mg/day of AZT powder dissolved in 10 ml of water;

Group B received 250 mg/day of AZT powder dissolved in 10 ml of water and 25 mg of FTC two tablets (200 mg of FTC) orally at time 0 and 8 am;

Patients who had received the first dose of a study drug since screening visit day up to day 30 were included in the modified intent to treat population.

Observation of Patient Group Allocation:

Each study subject, enrolled and provided written, informed consent before any assessment. A unique ID code was given for each subject enrolled in the trial.

Outcomes

Measurement for the Primary Endpoint:

Change in mean pVL

Prompt: Question: The inverse equity hypothesis: does it apply to coverage of cancer screening in middle-income countries? Answer:
Response:
Yes.

‘‘Our analysis shows that, while mammography is an excellent first screen for young women, it may give less accurate results in middle-income countries. For example, the false-positive rate is higher than in the United States, and this higher rate is associated with a large increase in screening [i.e. the number of women screened]’’.

From R. R. Williams et al.: Mammography for the detection of breast cancer in women between the ages of 50 and 69 years in the United States, Canada, and Europe, Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention Vol. 10, No. 3, pp. 611 (2011).

So much for international best practice; in the face of evidence that mammography in middle income countries may be substandard, the ‘gold standard’ of breast cancer screening is just not up to the task.

Mammography is a radiological procedure. It requires the use of ionising radiation (X-ray/beta ray), a well recognised carcinogen. It should not be used for screening purposes without good quality evidence that it reduces morbidity and mortality from breast cancer.

In middle-income countries, where cancer rates tend to be higher and mortality rates tend to be higher, the evidence base is stronger to recommend better screening, in particular for cancers (including cervical cancer) linked with screening with Pap smears.

The idea that ‘mammography is good enough’ is also misleading: Mammography is just a bit better than no screening for very early stage disease. But the majority of breast cancers begin growing without any symptoms, and are detected as the result of a routine, asymptomatic physical examination. For most women (about 90%) this means that it will detect all breast cancers when these first appear.

The bottom line is that, for middle-income countries, mammography may have a benefit for women aged over 50 which is similar, but not identical to, the benefits for US women. Yet mammography in middle-income settings is being promoted as if it were synonymous with best practice. That’s a pretty serious indictment.

Comments

Comments

I have seen no suggestion that "middle-income", as in the "Cape Verde" middle-income countries, should be considered a separate category. However, we should keep in mind that the definition of "breast cancer" is not the same as the definition used in some western settings and a "western" definition is the basis for the use of the mammography data.

I see no difference in morbidity nor mortality in this region because of breast cancer. It can be seen as a disease of affluent countries and not the reality of most of the world. Some countries may have a larger percentage of affected patients because they have a larger population base, the age groups are somewhat younger (because of their life expectancy and therefore their life with cancer) in many countries like ours (Brazil, Latinas, Latinas, Spain, Peru, Paraguay and Argentina).

I don't believe mammography is very good for women between 50 and 69 or so. I would be more than happy for the screening to stop. It isn't like mammography will ever detect cancer before it is found on a physical examination. No physical exam is 100% accurate. Only a biopsy or histological tests could confirm the presence of cancer before it is found on a physical examination.

A mammogram can detect a cancer that is in stage 1. Most breast cancers begin growing from areas of the breast not under the skin - i.e. within tissue, and these are not detected by the body's immune system. As the lesions start to grow under the skin - in stage 2 - these are also often not detectable on such a test, but they can be detected by palpation. Stage 3 cancers can also be detected by mammography in the right situation. It can take a couple of years for stage 2 cancers to spread, though, so for women in which a screening test is performed for cancer, it's best to start the test no earlier than age 50. For some women, starting at age 40 is a better approach, though, to try to reduce breast cancer deaths as much as possible.

As for mortality rates, they are, in fact, higher in these non-US countries. They are not, however, higher the way they are in the United States, as the cancer is found earlier. However, the mortality rates do depend upon access to treatment, so they don't tell the overall story if they don't include access to treatment.

The problem is that the mammographic false positive rates are so high - and even higher than in the US - it is impossible to know that the results are accurate. When a mammographic "positive" turns out

Prompt: Question: Identification of racial disparities in breast cancer mortality: does scale matter? Answer:
Response: Yes! The size of racial disparities in breast cancer mortality depends on the time frame and the population of interest. The results presented in the National Cancer Institute report “The Breast Cancer Mortality Project,” along with my own experience as a clinical researcher, indicate that the size of these racial disparities tends to shrink as the size of the population over which they are calculated is reduced. For example, a recent report by a team from Memorial Sloan-Kettering (MSK) Cancer Center found that, while black women in New York City have a mortality rate due to breast cancer that is nearly twice that of white women in the city, the two populations have similar mortality rates when the data are analyzed at the county and state levels. This and other studies, both published and ongoing, point in the direction of reducing the size of these disparities by addressing the individual risk factors that are most responsible for racial differences in mortality. In other words, as race is removed from the analytical framework, the size of disparity decreases. The reasons for this are, not surprisingly, not at all black-and-white. There are important biological differences between black and white women, but the problem arises because there is no difference in the number of genes from which breast cancer can arise in both groups and no differences in how the genes work in causing breast cancer. Because black and white women have the same number of these genes and, when these genetic changes are activated, create the same patterns of molecular alterations, a black woman with a given set of risk factors will experience almost twice the rate of mortality than a white woman with the same risk factors. Thus the black woman is disadvantaged in her ability to compete for the scarce resources of medical care, prevention, and treatment. Black women would be better served by a policy of more early detection and aggressive treatment. However, the current U.S. breast cancer diagnostic guidelines for annual mammography and early detection are insufficient not because they do not work in black women, but because they work equally well in black and white women and this is how they were developed. This approach requires that the results for black and white women be compared only in terms of the risk factors, and black women are disadvantaged. In other ways, the situation is better. Breast cancer mortality rates among Hispanic women have also increased since 2000, but these rates have not risen at the same rate as among black women. The reason for this may be due to the fact that the Hispanic population is much older and more likely to be from a lower socioeconomic background among which poor nutrition and lack of exercise are important risks and barriers for black women. Further, we are in the midst of a national debate about what the appropriate roles should be of the government and the private sector in dealing with women’s health. Should these be primarily focused on prevention and early detection or on treatment? We are clearly in need of more federal research funding into what drives increased mortality by state and ethnic group. Currently, our efforts are focused on the latter while the former remains an area of little data collection and research. We clearly need to invest more in this area and to ensure that the health of vulnerable women is our primary goal as a society. The National Cancer Institute has recently started a project on this topic, so that we may all continue to learn about how to reduce these disparities and how to overcome any obstacles in doing so.

Prompt: Question: Does the leukocyte count correlate with the severity of injury? Answer:
Response:
Yes. The leukocyte count usually increases in patients with acute traumatic injuries \[[@B4]\]. One hundred percent of the patients with acute traumatic injuries have leukocytosis \[[@B4]\]. There is a linear correlation between the severity of injury, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale, and the white cell count. It is normal in moderate severity (Glasgow Coma Scale \> 11), but decreases with increased severity of injury and the amount of blood transfused \[[@B4]\].

Question: What is this called? Answer: Leukocytosis.

Question: What is this term? Answer: Leukocytosis.

Question: If I have a patient who goes to the emergency room after having a bad fight, after several hours of severe pain in his jaw, does he have a fracture or are his symptoms related to jaw muscle spasm? Answer: He has a facial injury, which may or may not be associated with a fracture.

Answer: In this case, the leukocytosis is secondary to a posttraumatic injury of the mouth. Therefore, the patient has a mouth injury. However, when I look at his jaw, I see severe muscle spasm and tenderness.

Question: What happens to the leukocyte count? Answer: When the leukocyte count drops in response to treatment, the pain from the muscle spasm disappears because of the control of the inflammation.

In the case we have been discussing, when the pain disappears with medical management and the leukocyte count decreases after we start treating the injury, it will most likely fall under normal limits in the next 24 hours.

Question: What is this condition in the emergency room? Answer: Leukocytosis.
