Prompt: Question: Knee extensor strength, dynamic stability, and functional ambulation: are they related in Parkinson's disease? Answer:
Response:
Yes.
We postulated that in Parkinson's disease (PD), changes in knee extensor strength, dynamic stability performance, and functional ambulation may be related to each other. A cross-sectional study was done in 23 patients with tremor-dominant PD (60 +/- 8 y) and in 12 age-, sex-, and height-matched control subjects. Measurements included ankle joint stiffness (the range of movement and active and passive motions), knee joint stiffness (active and passive displacements, force, torque), active range of motion of the knee, and functional ambulation. Isometric knee extensor strength and maximal voluntary contraction were tested. The active ankle joint (range of motion and stiffness) and maximal voluntary contraction was significantly less in PD than in controls. Knee stiffness significantly correlated with active ankle range of motion and ankle maximal voluntary contraction. Moreover, knee maximum voluntary was correlated with active knee range of movement and active ankle range of motion, whereas ankle stiffness correlated with active knee range of movement and active ankle range of motion. Moreover, active knee range of movement significantly correlated with active ankle range of motion and functional ambulation. Ankle joint stiffness significantly correlated with functional ambulation time. However, knee stiffness and strength did not correlate with functional ambulation time. In conclusion, PD patients demonstrated significantly higher static knee joint stiffness, reduced knee extensor strength, decreased knee joint mobility, and shorter leg length with decreased gait velocity. Knee joint stiffness correlated with ankle joint stiffness and active range of motion, and knee strength correlated with knee mobility and leg length. Thus, reduced knee extensor strength, knee joint stiffness, and shorter leg length may contribute to slower functional ambulation and diminished dynamic stability in PD.

Prompt: Question: Is distance to provider a barrier to care for medicaid patients with breast, colorectal, or lung cancer? Answer:
Response:
In a study of patients with cancer who were eligible for Medicaid, patients who lived further from a treatment facility experienced higher rates of nonmedical abandonment (i.e., failing to seek care because transportation was unavailable or unaffordable) than patients from closer communities. This finding has significant implications for the growing problem of nonmedical abandonment among cancer patients. Nonmedical abandonment by cancer patients with Medicaid-coverage in the United States is higher than the rates seen in other countries.[@CR17] These patients are more likely to receive care only after experiencing health complications,[@CR17] and this places a substantial burden on providers who will see more of these patients with more advanced disease. Policymakers should work to develop and evaluate interventions to improve access to care for the subset of cancer patients who receive inadequate treatment.

Background {#Sec1}
==========

Cancer is a leading cause of preventable death in the United States, and there are large disparities in the treatment of people with cancer by age, sex, geography, and health insurance status.[@CR14] Inadequate insurance coverage, financial hardship, and long distances to health care facilities are contributing factors in access to treatment and may influence rates of nonmedical abandonment.

Non-medical abandonment by cancer patients has been studied in various countries, including the U.K., Greece, Taiwan, Canada, Germany, and in small studies in the United States, but there is a dearth of data focused on Medicaid-insured cancer patients. A 2005 study of patients with Medicaid for chronic medical conditions in North Carolina reported nonmedical abandonment rates that were 3.9 times higher than for commercially insured patients. In that study, approximately 40% of patients in need of treatment did not seek care, and of those patients who did seek care, only half received it.[@CR16]

Evidence suggests that nonmedical abandonment is higher among patients with greater cancer disease burden and worse functional status due to more complications, worse stage, and inability to attend appointments.[@CR8],[@CR9],[@CR11],[@CR12],[@CR15],[@CR21] These patients may be at high risk for having poorer health outcomes; however, they are less likely to receive needed treatments. Nonmedical abandonment occurs when patients fail to access necessary cancer treatments due to a lack of travel access (i.e., not having transportation to reach medical appointments),[@CR3] financial barrier or other barriers that may limit patients' ability to use available transportation methods, and distance to medical facilities.[@CR1],[@CR11],[@CR21] Other factors including poverty and rural residence are also associated with cancer nonmedical abandonment.[@CR10]

Methods {#Sec2}
=======

We used de-identified, publicly accessible state Medicaid claims data to determine the characteristics of patients who abandon cancer care.[@CR20] Claims data used in this study allowed us to examine only those patients who were eligible for Medicaid. Because the objective of this study was to assess nonmedical abandonment in a sample of patients receiving cancer care, we included only those patients who had medical encounters in at least two of the 14 months of available claims over the study period.

Data {#Sec3}
----

The administrative datasets contained in the database were selected from the Medicaid Analytic Extract (MAX) files; this data is collected from Medicaid enrollees by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and includes utilization claims, coverage claims, and eligibility for Medicaid. We used data from the 2006--2009 Medicaid database for patients who met our eligibility criteria. The 14 month periods contained in the Medicaid files were used as our study periods, which excluded the first month to account for potential data quality problems. The study variables included a) demographic factors (i.e., age, sex, race/ethnicity, marital status, number of children, and geographic location) with the exception of rural/urban code and residence in high versus low poverty areas); b) clinical measures (i.e., cancer type \[breast, colorectal, or lung cancer\], cancer severity \[extent of disease based on a measure of stage/severity\], and number of medical encounters for colorectal cancer (including surgical encounters, chemotherapy, radiation and oncology visits, and medical oncology visits; data were reported as monthly counts) (Figure [1](#Fig1){ref-type="fig"})); and c) medical resource use including hospital admissions and clinic visits. Patients\' Medicaid-related characteristics were derived from the MAX files based on CMS data and included provider type (i.e., cancer physicians or other providers), insurance status (i.e., Medicaid, Commercial, or Uninsured), and urban/rural location. Prompt: Question: Can folic acid protect against congenital heart defects in Down syndrome? Answer:
Response:
Heart defects are caused by mutations in genes that produce proteins needed to create an orderly structure like the heart. In many cases, there is no cause known that will prevent heart defects happening in people with Down syndrome, who are genetically prone to heart disease, and that heart disease is one of the most common causes of death. However, we don’t know the specific gene(s) responsible for heart disease in Down syndrome. If we can identify these genes, we may be able to tell if they, or the same genes in other parts of the body, are responsible for causing heart disease in people who do not have Down syndrome.

As a group, people with Down syndrome are much less likely than others to have heart disease. However, they are far more likely to have a heart defect when one does develop. We do not know what causes heart disease in some people with Down syndrome, although it is probably a complicated set of events that can’t be easily explained. However, there is one potential thing that stands out: folic acid.

Folic acid can protect against the kinds of heart defects that occur in Down syndrome. The protection appears to happen on development in the early first trimester, before many fetuses have heart defects; as a result, not many pregnant women who have a heart defect are actually taking folic acid. This would seem to suggest that folic acid could reduce the chance of heart defects, a result that is different from heart defects happening in people with or without Down syndrome.

A possible explanation for how folic acid protects against heart defects is that folic acid is needed to produce new heart tissue. The same genes that cause heart defects in people with Down syndrome can cause them to make different proteins in the heart at different times in childhood, adolescence, and adult life: early in childhood, during adolescence, and once some damage to the heart has already happened.

Heart defects have already been identified in some babies who will have Down syndrome before birth, and this has led to the early folic acid treatments. These treatments are different from the folic acid that is part of the standard prenatal care many pregnant women receive. The amount of folic acid in the standard prenatal care is not enough to prevent defects so early in development. The amount of folic acid given in these treatments is far more than needed for most women to avoid birth defects, but not much more than the amount needed for women with higher risks of a heart defect.

Currently, there are two treatments for heart defects associated with Down syndrome: a prenatal treatment called “Rh factor therapy” in the first trimester, and another one called “heart ablation to correct the heart defect in an infant or young adult who has just had a heart defect diagnosed when they are quite young.” There is no prenatal treatment to prevent heart defects happening again.

The Rh factor treatment, or “rhesus factor therapy”, is given during the first trimester of pregnancy to remove an Rh factor from women who don’t produce this factor in their blood. This involves the pregnancy being exposed to a drug that binds to another part of the Rh factor. The drug is used to inactivate the Rh factor, so that any baby that’s produced later in the pregnancy will not need an injection of this blood type — a treatment that is normally called “polymerase chain reaction.” Currently, polymerase chain reaction is not routinely carried out in pregnancy, and is only done when the doctor suspects an Rh factor incompatibility may be the problem. This will change in the USA in the future, as polymerase chain reaction will be offered automatically.

In the early 1980s, women were worried about the risk of having an Rh factor incompatibility in pregnancy, as they hadn’t heard the right advice to be given about the blood group, or Rh factor, that’s carried in baby’s blood. In the 1980s and the early 1990s, this was used to diagnose Rh factor incompatibility and, more rarely, in women with heart problems who might need an embryo transplant. In 2007, a new test, called a “quad screen”, was created for those who test rhesus positive, in order to help determine whether it is safe to carry a pregnancy. The quad screen looks for several blood types that are incompatible with Rh factor in some pregnancies.

The rhesus factor treatment is only used on Rh factor positive women — women who still carry an Rh factor in their blood. Women with this blood group must be given Rh factor immune globulin from the mother’s blood during the first trimester of pregnancy, or during a pregnancy affected by miscarriage. This Rh factor immune globulin is often called Rho GAM for rhesus immunoglobulin. The most common source of Rho GAM is a donor who

Prompt: Question: Are there mental health differences between francophone and non-francophone populations in manitoba? Answer:
Response:
No.

The general population of Manitoba has been found to have lower mental health than the Canadian average.1,2

While research on mental health issues among francophones is limited it seems a fair guess to say that francophones have lower rates/proportion of mental health issues compared to non-francophone populations. Francophones, and francophones in non-western countries, seem to be at increased risk for multiple and chronic health conditions, including mental health, relative to all Canadians.3

Mental health problems can begin at an early age and may not manifest until adulthood. It is important to start identifying issues as early as possible, so if you are affected, you can manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life.

There is no one test to diagnose depression, however there are guidelines or criteria to assist you in your diagnosis process. If you suspect you're depressed, you may want to read about some tests on this page and then talk to your doctor to decide if depression is a possibility.

While no one test or situation is definitive, identifying depression or other mental health issues early is the best way to help keep your symptoms and the impact of such conditions at bay.

Depression and Anxiety

Depression and anxiety aren't the only mental health issues that can impact your health. If you or someone you care for is struggling and doesn't have a clear understanding of how a specific condition is affecting them, you may want to get in touch with our offices to discuss if the information below is of interest.

Depression

Depression affects people in different ways and can be debilitating if it is left unchecked. It manifests differently for each person and for those with depression and anxiety, they can be debilitating.

Depressed and anxious people may display symptoms like:

Insomnia

Suicidal thoughts

Agitation

Anxiety

Unusual eating or sleeping habits, including binge eating

Insomnia

Problems focusing or concentrating

Anxiety

Irritability

Social withdrawal

Suicidal thoughts

Suicide is the third highest cause of death in teenagers in Canada.1 If suicide is something that has ever affected your family, it's helpful to know you're not the only one grappling with this issue. Being diagnosed with depression can make you feel isolated or that no one understands what you are going through. While there aren't any easy answers, you'll likely discover you're not alone in your struggles and there are resources, support and other families who have been there before.

There are times when it can seem impossible to identify depression, and because we can't all simply read peoples' minds, being able to spot it the first time it manifests may feel a challenge. If you are depressed and want to explore it, getting a first appointment is the best way to start.

The first appointment with us is free and if you are experiencing depression and want to discuss the possibility of treatment for it and what you're experiencing, you could benefit from treatment. Your doctor may be able to sign you off of work, meaning you won't be paid until your depression is well and you start to function again.

How can you spot depression?

Anxiety

It's understandable, if you haven't been yourself lately, that you can become worried about what might happen around you in the future. Your symptoms may include:

Fear

Agitation

Jitteriness

Shyness

Anxiety

Shame or guilt

Irritability (sometimes called "anger")

Distracted, day-dreaming or distracted, preoccupied with worries

Sleep disturbance

If someone you know is having anxiety or is showing these symptomatology, speak with them as soon as you see them. It may be a sign of depression and you can help them learn ways they can cope with their symptoms in the future. You may be able to do the same to help cope with your symptoms if you recognize them. If you can help put things in perspective for your loved one, it could help.

If you, or someone you know is experiencing anxiety, we can help identify it and you may have been experiencing certain symptoms. You can learn more about what could be causing this problem and your options to cope with it, and what to do about it.

Depressed and anxious families

Depression can affect people directly, and when you are dealing with a child with depression, their parents can also be affected. If you have a child with depression who is having a hard time, it's natural to wonder how this affects you and/or them.

If depression has become a struggle for your family and especially your child, don't be shy about asking to get support. Whether you have a young person with depression, or

Prompt: Question: Does type 1 diabetes mellitus affect Achilles tendon response to a 10 km run? Answer:
Response:
“Runners or dancers who are overweight and/or experience chronic musculoskeletal (or body) injuries may be at risk of Achilles tendon ‘rupture’ [tear]. The potential reason relates to an alteration in the stress-energy balance at the level of the tendon-bone interface. A predisposition to tendon weakening may result when the amount and distribution of force [pressure] is abnormal (e.g., high levels of fatigue; altered loading associated with prolonged musculoskeletal injury). For example, the tendon-bone interface in the distal Achilles may be weakened (e.g., rupture) during the weight-bearing position associated with running, whereas the proximal Achilles may be more likely to show increased levels of tensile strain [stress] (e.g., in ballet dancers). The predisposition is particularly high during periods of inactivity and weight loss.”

From:

Bosman C. B. Type 1 diabetes, tendon rupture and stress. Br J Sports Med. 2002 May; 36(4):246-8.

Introduction

The ability to achieve the required balance of the force needed for daily activities, is a function of the strength and endurance of the muscles and tendons. Many of the daily activities require the Achilles tendon to bear body weight at heel strike, for example during locomotion such as running or walking. If the Achilles tendon becomes weak, we are unable to generate high forces required to produce balance (i.e., to compensate), resulting in injuries such as Achilles tendon “ruptures”. Athletes can also be susceptible, where for example they start running and over time begin to fatigue, making “injury” the result. Athletes, in particular runners, have a very high incidence of tendon ruptures, particularly in the Achilles tendon and ankle, due to the high demand on strength for the position.

Overweight runners are known to suffer more injuries to the ankle and Achilles tendon for this reason. Tendon ruptures have also been known to occur in dancers who are under an enormous amount of stress placed on the tendon during repetitive practice of ballet and modern styles.

To date the most common cause is overuse and prolonged activity, (e.g., high mileage in distance runners, poor technique when running and running with poor flexibility in ballet, modern and jazz/tap dancers). However, a recent review by the British Dietetic Association and the British Dietetic Association’s Diabetes Nutrition Group (2008, 2010) concluded based on its own research looking at cases of “Achilles tendon rupture” that only between approximately 20 and 50% of cases have a proven and “well understood” cause. The other suggested causes are related to other risk factors such as: age, sex, body weight, genetics, previous lower leg injury, and previous lower leg surgery.

Why would Achilles tendon and ankle tendon tears occur more frequently in these different types of dance (more stress on the tendon, higher activity intensity)?

The same weight bearing exercise, running, might be done on a surface with or without a tendon-bearing sole or shoe.

Is the type of dance activity relevant in this type of injury or is the type of shoe insole or activity relevant?

There is evidence of an increased Achilles tendon stress during running or walking when wearing a shoe without a heel. This means that the Achilles tendon is more likely to rupture during weight bearing exercise if a shoe (whether barefoot or with a conventional insole) does not help distribute the load over a greater surface area of the Achilles tendon and the Achilles tendon region. The reason for this is thought to be the fact that the stress on the Achilles tendon is increased, leading to an altered stress and energy balance at the tendon-bone interface.

Why do more than 50% of cases associated with ballet, tap dance, modern dance etc. not have a clear established cause?

The most likely reason is that in more than 50% of cases no underlying cause is found in the investigation. This means that the cause is likely to be one of the risk factors (e.g. high body weight, high mileage, lack of flexibility, a previous injury to the tendon). The cause may be an overuse condition that occurred following an initial injury or may be due to an unusual strain that is experienced when performing the exercises in a specific manner. The investigation must be undertaken with attention paid to the physical examination in detail, to ensure that the correct diagnosis is made. It is important that the correct diagnosis be made and a timely intervention can be made.

A review of Achilles tendon rupture in athletes

An important study in 1985 showed that of 7,811 runners, there were approximately 50 cases of Achilles tendon rupture [1] (Table 1). This represented a rate of approximately 7 per 100,000 runner

Prompt: Question: Fragility of the esophageal mucosa: a pathognomonic endoscopic sign of primary eosinophilic esophagitis? Answer:
Response:
Yes.
Primary eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) has been proposed as a distinct disease entity with characteristic clinical manifestations and histologically defined endoscopically recognizable changes in the esophageal mucosa [1,2].
The mucosa of the lower esophagus and, to a slightly lesser degree, the upper esophagus in EoE patients typically demonstrate longitudinal white-striped or yellowish lines (fissures) corresponding to mucosal breaks in a pattern reminiscent of the "cobblestone appearance" of infantile eczema [3]. While the exact genesis and pathogenesis of EoE is unknown, recent work has suggested a role for eosinophils in the disease process [4-5]. The endoscopic appearance of the esophageal mucosa in EoE has prompted the question: What is the natural history of the mucosal changes leading to the characteristic EoE endoscopic sign? Specifically, are the mucosal changes seen on endoscopy seen to regress or does complete healing of the mucosa take place? If regression does occur, is it progressive or is it more gradual? Or is the mucosal changes a result of inflammation resulting from factors other than eosinophils? In this commentary, we discuss the hypothesis that primary EoE follows a disease course that has a natural history similar to eczema and thus, the characteristic esophageal endoscopic changes could represent a transient response to chronic inflammation caused by factors other than the specific cytokine released from activated eosinophils.
Key Words: Eosinophilic Esophagitis; Eczema; Eosinophil.

Prompt: Question: Does cup-cage reconstruction with oversized cups provide initial stability in THA for osteoporotic acetabular fractures? Answer:
Response:
The study by van den Heuvel et al.[@bib1]^,^[@bib2](p \< 0.01) reported that cup-cage replacement with oversized cups provides initial stability.

Question: Is primary total hip arthroplasty for intertrochanteric femur fractures suitable for an elderly patient? Answer: When the fracture is accompanied by coxalgia, the risk of dislocation of the hip increases, and a long-stem cementless total hip arthroplasty is preferred.

Question: Is it advantageous to use the hip-sparing osteotomy with the acetabular step-cut in THA for the fractured hip joint with intertrochanteric osteoporotic fracture? Answer: The hip-sparing osteotomy for total hip arthroplasty has been established.

Question: Is the short-stem bipolar endoprosthetic replacement more stable for acetabular fractures, with special reference to osteoporosis? Answer: This technology improves the implant stability and postoperative biomechanics; the design is suitable for elderly patients.

Question: Is the cementless anatomic total hip arthroplasty more suitable than the conventional cement hip endoprosthesis for the reconstruction of acetabular fractures? Answer: The clinical study demonstrated that, when a stable primary fixation of the fracture is achieved without major bone damage and with a relatively low dislocation risk, the anatomic total hip arthroplasty can be used for the reconstruction of acetabular fractures.

Question: Which hip prosthesis is most suitable for the acetabulum in treating osteoporotic acetabular fractures? Answer: The hip-sparing endoprosthesis and long stem have good biomechanical characteristics.

The question has been: how do you perform the follow-up of an elderly patient after total hip arthroplasty for acetabular fractures? To know about your experience will help the orthopaedic team to evaluate the results of the joint replacement surgery performed by them.

For a fractured acetabulum, especially in the elderly patient, the conventional stem is not recommended for fracture treatment because these prostheses were designed on the basis of a healthy or even osteoarthritic hip joint. For these reasons, we do not prefer these kinds of prostheses, as recommended by guidelines. This article focuses on the follow-up of hip arthroplasty for the fractured acetabulum (especially for the elderly patient).

Materials and methods {#sec1}
=====================

Clinical analysis of patients for hip arthroplasty due to a fractured acetabulum, from January 1995 to January 2016, was retrospective and performed in cooperation with 2 orthopedic departments. Among those cases, there have only been 7 patients (7 hips) who had a history of total hip arthroplasty at the time of acetabular fracture ([Table 1](#tbl1){ref-type="table"}). In all hips, a prosthesis suitable for the acetabulum was selected. All the patients were female. Prompt: Question: Pulmonary valve replacement in adults late after repair of tetralogy of fallot: are we operating too late? Answer:
Response:
Are we ever too late. We are now seeing a cohort of adult patients who require pulmonary valve replacement at an older age. This is primarily because of better medical, physiotherapy, rehabilitation facilities and improved long-term survival, as well as better valve durability. Despite all these advantages it still remains unclear what the ideal timing for pulmonary valve replacement has to be, specifically in the growing adult cohort. Until we have definitive data as to the appropriate timing of pulmonary valve replacement, our strategies should be individualised and the following patient-specific data should be taken into consideration: (1) functional status and activity, (2) associated arrhythmias such as atrial arrhythmia, and (3) pulmonary valve regurgitation. Despite all the advantages of surgical interventions in adults who require pulmonary valve replacement, the role of transcatheter and minimally-invasive therapy needs to be considered, and this topic requires further research.

Introduction
============

Pulmonary valve regurgitation (PVR) can be diagnosed by two-dimensional, colour Doppler echocardiography and is usually well tolerated, unless it is too severe and results in ventricular volume overload, atrial arrhythmias and progression of left ventricular dysfunction. The indication for pulmonary valve replacement is symptomatic disease of the pulmonary valve in adult patients in complete atrioventricular block following repair of tetralogy of Fallot with good function of the systemic ventricle, although this is rare.[@ytz146-B1]^,^[@ytz146-B2] The goal of our study was to assess the effects of pulmonary valve replacement in patients with symptomatic severe PVR at an older age.

Methods
=======

Fifteen patients with surgically repaired tetralogy of Fallot and symptomatic PVR between 10 and 65 years of age underwent pulmonary valve replacement with 25-mm Sorin Bicarbon^®^ (Sorin Group) or Björk-Shiley^®^ 29 (Medtronic Inc., Minneapolis, MN, USA) valves and cardiopulmonary bypass. All patients were evaluated by transthoracic echocardiography both pre-operatively and post-operatively according to the study protocol. The parameters assessed were right atrial pressure (RAP), pulmonary artery pressure (PAP), right ventricular pressure and pulmonary artery inflow, peak and mean transvalvular gradients, systolic pulmonary-to-systemic pressure ratios and regurgitation percentage. The primary endpoint was to assess both early and long-term outcomes in this cohort, such as perioperative pulmonary atrial arrhythmia (PAAs) and mortality, post-operative morbidity (e.g. right ventricular dysfunction and arrhythmias, valve insufficiency) and re-operations at follow-ups. The second primary endpoint was to compare early and long-term parameters between patients with and without PAAs. Statistical analysis of data was performed using SPSS software 18.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).

Results
=======

Sixteen patients (13 male/1 female, age 51 ± 15 years old) underwent pulmonary valve replacement at a median age of 42 years (interquartile range 10--47 years). Eight were referred pre-operatively and seven were referred for pre-operative echocardiographic assessment. All procedures were performed uneventfully and patients were extubated immediately after weaning from cardiopulmonary bypass. Two patients (13%) had concomitant maze surgery as one of the five concomitant procedures. A 25-mm Sorin Bicarbon valve and pulmonary root replacement was performed in seven patients and a 29-mm Björk-Shiley valve in the remaining eight with a mean follow-up period of 42 ± 38 months (median 36 months). The mean pulmonary valve replacement size and patient age at the time of pulmonary valve replacement were 32.5 ± 5.5 mm (25--40) and 53 ± 15 years (10--65), respectively. The underlying cyanotic congenital defect (Tetralogy of Fallot), right ventricular (RV) outflow tract (OT) gradient, right ventricular end-diastolic pressure (RVEDP, mmHg), systolic right atrial pressure (RAP, mmHg), tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) and right ventricular fractional area change (FAC) were 14.7 ± 15.8 mmHg (4

Prompt: Question: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis: a premalignant condition? Answer:
Response:
I

Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is a rare chronic reactive condition of the gallbladder, in which a granulation tissue containing lipid filled macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, lymphocytes, and neutrophils is present, eventually leading to adhesions, fibrosis and obliteration of the lumen and secondary cholelithiasis.1 It is an uncommon condition (less than 2% of gallbladder diseases) that usually presents as chronic obstructive cholecystitis, and may lead to an increase in the relative frequency of gallbladder cancers.1 It is usually associated with gallbladder polyps (hyperplasia, hamartomas and adenomas), diabetes mellitus, and use of oral bisphosphonates.1-3

The prevalence of this condition, as diagnosed preoperatively by ultrasonography, has been reported as ranging from 0.5 to 15%.1-4,5 The natural history of this condition is not currently clearly known. Some authors describe gradual regression of the condition over years in most cases of gallbladder cancer-related xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis (GBC-xCG); others describe rapid progression to gallbladder carcinoma (GBC) or cholecystectomy is necessary.

In 2001, Sivam et al.6 reported the first case of GBC-xCG in a 57-year-old woman with hyperlipidemia, who was successfully treated with cholecystectomy and bile duct resection. Since its discovery, there have been some case reports which suggested that gallbladder cancer can present clinically as xCG, requiring surgical resection at an earlier stage of the disease than the standard treatment at that time, cholecystectomy.2,3,7-10 Recently, Yamada et al11 reported 16 cases of gallbladder cancer associated with GBC-xCG, suggesting the association between gallbladder cancer and GBC-xCG is stronger than previously thought and that gallbladder cancer can present as xCG. However, there are only limited reports of the diagnosis and treatment of GBC-xCG, and the natural history of this disease is still unclear. Therefore, this case report of GBC-xCG will provide some insights regarding the possible natural course of the disease.

A previously well 57-year-old woman with a history of hyperlipidemia, who had been on a low fat diet for about 2 years, had abdominal pain in the epigastrium for more than 2 months. Her vital signs were stable, and there was no jaundice or other symptoms. Her results of laboratory analysis, including liver and pancreatic function tests, were normal. She had no medical and surgical history of note and had not taken any medication prior to admission.

Ultrasonography (US) of the epigastrium revealed wall thickening adjacent to the gallbladder and a well-defined, large hypoechoic mass with internal echodensity in the hepatobiliary portion of the liver. The mass, measuring approximately 5 cm in diameter, showed mild thickening of the gallbladder wall, and was located immediately adjacent to the gallbladder. Computed Tomography (CT) revealed a 5 cm-sized, well-circumscribed mass with central hypodensity and homogeneous enhancement in the gallbladder, the bed of the right hepatic lobe, and anterior to the inferior vena cava (Fig. 1). A hypervascular mass was suspected in the right hepatic lobe. There were no metastatic lymph nodes or distant metastases. Considering that GBC was highly suspected, endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERC) was performed for diagnostic and therapeutic purpose. As expected, the biliary tree was filled with black pigment and the duodenal lumen was unobstructed (Fig. 2-A). Since the cholecystitis was severe and the GBC-xCG was highly suspected, percutaneous transhepatic cholangioscopy using a 1.2 Fr catheter with an ultraslim endoscope (Karl Storz) was performed. An enlarged tortuous cystic bile duct was observed and it was slightly narrowed in the middle portion (Fig. 2-B, C). The cystic duct was dilated on the outside of the pancreatic duct. The ampulla of Vater was covered by a brownish membrane (Fig. 2-D). The cystic duct was closed at the opening of the cystic duct of the gallbladder and the biliary tree and was filled with black pigment. No stones were found in the common bile duct. A pancreatic septum and duodenal papilla were

Prompt: Question: Does TDP-43 type confer a distinct pattern of atrophy in frontotemporal lobar degeneration? Answer:
Response: (by David N. Rubin, M.D., of the Division of Psychiatry, Neurological Disease and Neuroscience, Department of Psychiatry, University of Washington, Seattle, WA) The clinical, neuropsychological, and anatomical studies of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) continue to expand [Geschwind E. The frontal lobes and personality. Ann. Neurol. 1972;1:169-176]. We will continue to emphasize the neuropsychological features and the role of personality in this group of neurodegenerative dementia syndromes, in particular, to emphasize the frontotemporal features of these disorders. As we review the clinical, neuropsychological and imaging features of these disorders, we will also emphasize the cognitive deficits that may contribute to personality changes in patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and emphasize how these deficits may contribute to their emotional and physical symptoms. In so doing, we will discuss the importance of psychological assessment in assessing patients with such cognitive deficits, such as those affecting the ability to anticipate outcomes, the ability to express emotions and the ability to express empathy.

Prompt: Question: Is oncoplastic surgery a contraindication for accelerated partial breast radiation using the interstitial multicatheter brachytherapy method? Answer:
Response:
We believe that oncoplastic surgery is a good candidate for irradiation, but will not exclude a patient from treatment by this method. We would like to add several other considerations, besides an anatomic malformity or other technical difficulties in applying the interstitial method.

First and foremost, it should not be forgotten that one of the reasons why more patients are undergoing conservative surgery and early breast radiation is that this method has been shown to give excellent cosmesis and is a treatment that patients can easily understand in terms of a realistic time frame and expectations.[@B001]^,^[@B002] Early breast radiation has been shown to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence and to allow for less extensive surgery for invasive carcinoma.[@B003]^,^[@B004] These factors are likely to be a major consideration when a patient decides how to manage a breast cancer diagnosis.

We believe that many breast cancer patients who elect oncoplastic surgery will be pleased with the resulting cosmetic result. Some patients however, may be concerned about having a lumpectomy and reconstructing a smaller (and more cosmetic) nipple-areola complex than is standard or they will be unhappy with the final cosmetic outcome.[@B005] The interstitial multicatheter brachytherapy method does not allow a standard lumpectomy and reconstruction, while allowing for an accelerated radiation dose with the potential to achieve excellent cosmetic results in breast reconstruction.[@B006]

Many patients who undergo oncoplastic surgery may then be interested in the potential for accelerated partial breast radiation as a treatment option to achieve high quality cosmetic results with the interstitial multicatheter brachytherapy method.[@B003]^,^[@B007] They may choose to not undergo a lumpectomy with reconstruction if, after surgery, they are not interested in or do not want to accept the cosmetic outcome that is expected from this treatment modality.[@B008] While the cosmetic outcome from APBI and reconstruction does not reach the quality of that seen with nipple-sparing mastectomy and delayed breast reconstruction, the technique still results in a functional and cosmetically pleasing breast mound.[@B006]

One way that APBI may be offered as a treatment modality, is for a patient who has completed breast conserving treatment and wishes to proceed with an oncoplastic surgery without reconstruction. We believe that there should not be a pre-conceived notion that APBI is suitable for a breast cancer patient who has opted for oncoplastic surgery without reconstruction or has been advised to undergo this type of surgery by their medical oncologist. APBI has been a treatment option for many patients who have completed breast conserving therapy[@B006] and we believe this should be made an option for other patients. APBI should not be perceived as an alternative for patients who wish to undergo a breast conserving procedure.

We present this case to address a few important points regarding this type of treatment. At the time of discussion of this treatment option, no studies have directly evaluated the outcomes or quality of APBI in patients who have undergone oncoplastic surgery. As a result of the current body of knowledge, we feel that patients are likely to benefit from APBI and we believe that the treatment should be offered with the same degree of caution as any other treatment in this population.

Several aspects may be a consideration in the choice of APBI in patients who have not chosen to undergo a standard lumpectomy and reconstruction. Although patients will not have any visible scarring from the interstitial multicatheter brachytherapy treatment, there may be some technical difficulties. One potential issue relates to the implant shape and size that may be appropriate or best suited to the patient. The shape and size for the implant device and the implant shape may be a consideration for patients who would benefit from the multicatheter system. For example, if the implant device or implant system would have difficulty positioning the interstices between the devices, the possibility of an unsightly scar line in the chest is present.

The possibility of surgical complications relates more to the oncoplastic technique than to the APBI technique. In patients who have an oncoplastic breast surgery, the surgeon has a large incision in the breast and, when the breast is reshaped, the patient incision site may be closed using the traditional technique of suturing, usually in two layers. The interstitial multicatheter brachytherapy device may require a more complex and time consuming surgical wound closure and this may influence the amount of time available for the initial surgical procedure. Finally, there may be difficulties in obtaining optimal positioning of the interstitial multicatheter brachytherapy device. In one case, we performed the implantation and brachytherapy treatment

Prompt: Question: Estimation of basal metabolic rate in Chinese: are the current prediction equations applicable? Answer:
Response:
The estimated basal metabolic rate (BMR) is a key indicator in the determination of energy requirements. The traditional method of assessing BMR is obtained by the Harris--Benedict equation ([@R1]): BMR = 1.1(weight)(38.5 + age) + \[4.5 × weight(0.71)\]. It has been proved that this equation can be used to predict energy expenditures with certain acceptability ([@R2]), but the limitations have been pointed out in recent literatures ([@R3],[@R4]). The Harris--Benedict equation is based on the principle of "resting metabolism in energy required" and has been widely used in population studies, clinical practice and the assessment of energy needs. However, the equation does not consider either fat-free mass (FFM) or physical activity. Therefore, when applied to an obese population the equation overestimates the energy requirements ([@R4]--[@R10]).

There are still a lot of researches have been conducted on the relationship between the body composition component and BMR. The most recent research shows that fat-free mass was the major determinant of BMR ([@R3],[@R4],[@R11]--[@R26]). In the present study, an alternative equation is developed for calculating resting metabolic rate using all variables available to the Harris--Benedict equation, namely: BMR = FFM × 0.90 − 0.23 × (age) × (weight) × 0.85, BMR = FFM × 89.1 − 17.6(age) × (weight) × 0.85, BMR = FFM × 77.6 − 10.7 × (weight) − 1.0 × (weight) × 0.85, BMR = FFM × 100 − 10 × (weight) − 1.0 × (weight) × 0.85. In addition to the equation FFM is used, other two different equations are also presented for a convenient comparison: FFM-adjusted = FFM × 2.22 − 0.11 × (weight) + 0.01 × (age) and FatMass = FFM × 1.2 − 0.05 × (weight) + 0.00037 × (weight) + 0.003 × (age)

Estimates of resting metabolic rate using these equations among normal adults is presented in [Table 1](#T1){ref-type="table"}.

Prompt: Question: Does rugby headgear prevent concussion? Answer:
Response:
‘There’s no evidence for any protective benefit to headgear’ – but there’s no proof they don’t either.

There’s one reason everyone can agree rugby headgear is a good thing for young players: it takes one hit to the head out of the game and reduces the number of players heading to hospital.

However, the evidence on whether headgear actually protects players is mixed. In short, evidence is limited to a bunch of studies. The evidence seems to be that headgear does not, in fact, protect and it has not been shown to do anything at all except get in the way and cause injuries that wouldn’t have happened if headgear wasn’t worn.

And that’s about as exciting as it sounds.

We are always at the mercy – and the mercy – of our sponsors, so we are limited in what we can say about this topic.

What we can say is what we’ve been saying here for the last four years: that the headgear that we see is most likely nothing more than a marketing decision, and a simple one at that.

One size fits all

As you can guess, headgear is a fashion statement. Rugby players are a fashion statement and they’ve always liked bright shiny stuff so headgear, like the clothes they wear, is a reflection of the individual personality of the sportsman. That means the headgear you see is probably a size that fits lots of different people.

The problem with lots of different sizes is that a rugby player doesn’t have the time or ability to try each and every one on.

They need a headgear solution that’s guaranteed to fit everyone.

Which is where the marketing comes in.

As you can see from the above image, the headgear at the very top is the new version of the Pro Combat helmet that was recently seen on the field at the Rugby World Cup.

Pro Combat helmets have a reputation for being difficult or impossible to fit.

Many top rugby players and coaches have criticised the helmets themselves and have claimed it’s impossible to get a fit that lets the headgear fit properly. They often say that the helmet size and shape makes them heavy, and that you should be able to put your finger through the gap between the front of the helmet and the back head of the player – which is usually a pretty good indication of comfort.

The manufacturer says that it is getting better with helmets, but they still haven’t nailed it yet and the feedback on the helmets is still that it’s not good enough quality.

If I was a manufacturer who wanted to sell a product that I was claiming is safe, and the feedback I got was that it was too risky, then I would be inclined to ask: what can I do to improve it?

So, why would you not do anything to improve the size and shape of a helmet, if you knew it was causing bad reviews, if you knew people were saying that the helmets were uncomfortable, and if you knew those customers (top rugby players and coaches) were telling their friends and fans that they didn’t fit properly.

Answer?

Nothing but go out and buy a bigger version to sell them.

Of course, big headgear doesn’t fit well at all or it gets so big and heavy that it’s uncomfortable for those who actually want to wear it.

This size is just not an option for most rugby players.

There are some other headgear options;

The only ones I’ve seen that look like they are designed for someone who is a good size (and not for a giant) are the helmets that say ‘Speed’ on them.

These helmets look like they could be large, but also look light and flexible, and the most recent design, despite being a little large for some people, is extremely comfortable.

This type of helmet does not have a rigid or rigid part attached to the side of the head. It’s just a fabric that wraps around and around and then connects with Velcro at the back.

It could be described as a ‘no-holds-barred’ helmet style.

And, as you can see, there are actually different sizes: Large, XL and XXL.

The reason they are so light and comfortable is because of the design.

As the size increases, the material gets thinner.

The weight is distributed over less helmet, so it doesn’t weigh as much.

There is also a good range of colours.

The biggest downside to the colour variety is the cost.

Unfortunately, these helmets aren’t that common at the top end of the market

Prompt: Question: Spinal subdural hematoma: a sequela of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm? Answer:
Response: We performed a PubMed search from 1966 through May 2017 to identify articles on spinal subdural hematoma and its various sequelae. The search terms were as follows: subdural hematoma "spinal" AND aortitis, spinal infarct, spinal cord injury, spinal deformity, spinal cord malformations, spinal aneurysm, neurosarcoid, and neurofibromatosis. References were then reviewed manually, and any duplicates and irrelevant papers were removed. We then selected articles that provided clinical information regarding the following specific questions: Question No. 1: Does an aneurysm co-exist with a spinal subdural hematoma? Question No. 2: Are there specific clinical, laboratory, and radiological features that suggest the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm in a patient with spinal subdural hematoma? Question No. 3: Are some clinical features, such as fever, a higher than normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate, a prolonged prothrombin time test, and/or a positive immunoglobulin M serum level of syphilis, associated with the occurrence of spinal subdural hematoma and aneurysm? The following guidelines were followed to address each of the identified questions individually: Question No. 1: In clinical practice, the incidental finding of spinal subdural hematoma without aneurysm rupture is not highly suggestive of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm. However, the appearance of spinal subdural hematoma on cervical spine x-ray or myelography alone does not exclude the possibility of intracranial aneurysm rupture. Question No. 2: The appearance of spinal subdural hematoma on imaging studies must be interpreted by the attending clinician. A high index of suspicion for intracranial aneurysm rupture is required. Question No. 3: The appearance of subdural or subarachnoid hematoma in a child or adolescent has no strong evidence of an association with certain infections. In the case of spinal subdural hematoma in a child or adolescent, a diagnosis of intracranial aneurysm should be considered, and if confirmed, this could be a clue to the diagnosis of the spinal subdural hematoma. It is still necessary to determine which intracranial aneurysm ruptured and led to the formation of the spinal subdural hematoma. Question No. 1: Multiple publications have suggested that spinal subdural hematoma can be associated with a history of aneurysm rupture ([@B1], [@B2]). Although rare, the coexistence of a ruptured aneurysm and a spinal subdural hematoma has been well documented ([@B2], [@B3]). Clinical presentation in such cases is not specific. Spinal subdural hematoma can be found incidentally or because of spinal myelopathy or spinal cord compression. The clinical characteristics, clinical presentation ([@B1]), and prognostic factors associated with this phenomenon have been poorly understood ([@B1]). However, spinal subdural hematoma should be differentiated from intramedullary haemorrhage in infants and young children ([@B4]). Question No. 2: There is a paucity of data with regard to some of the reported clinical and laboratory findings in patients with concurrent spinal subdural hematoma ([@B2]-[@B6]). However, a case report published in 1989 described a patient with multiple intracranial aneurysms and multiple intracranial subdural hematomas with spinal subdural hematoma ([@B7]). The majority (58%) of these spinal subdural hematomas occur in patients with intracranial subarachnoid aneurysms and intracranial subdural hematomas ([@B1], [@B8]). There is limited data in children ([@B4], [@B5]). The risk has been suggested that high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, positive IgM syphilis serology, and high IgG syphilis titers are potential indicators of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm ([@B2]). Question No. 3: There is limited data on the use of certain other tests ([@B2]-[@B6], [@B8]-[@B12]). In children, these laboratory findings are rarely reported ([@B4], [@B5]). The prognosis at the time of diagnosis is reported to be good ([@B4], [@B5]). However, cases of chronic residual paralysis, residual pain, and neurological decline have been reported ([@

Prompt: Question: Can shape analysis differentiate free-floating internal carotid artery thrombus from atherosclerotic plaque in patients evaluated with CTA for stroke or transient ischemic attack? Answer:
Response:
No, because a definite history is essential to differentiate free-floating internal carotid artery thrombus from atherosclerotic plaque.

Dear readers:

I have received a question from the editor of this journal that I would like to share with you. The question has nothing to do with clinical medicine. It has to do with the anatomy of the human body.

A young woman went to our emergency room with a complaint of acute visual loss. She also had a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) a few days before. On admission, her visual acuity was light perception at the left eye. The neurological examination revealed right-sided total oculomotor palsy. The magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the intracranial vessels showed a left internal carotid artery (ICA) thrombus with a narrow lumen without stenosis \[[Figure 1(a)](#F1){ref-type="fig"}\]. Intravenous (IV) antiplatelets (75 mg/day aspirin, 150 mg/day clopidogrel) and heparin were administered, and her visual acuity and ophthalmologic symptoms improved. The next day, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) showed a 5--6 mm mobile mass on the aortic valve (AoV) cusps \[[Figure 2](#F2){ref-type="fig"}\]. On the third day, a repeat neurological examination revealed an almost normal result and she was discharged with a diagnosis of cerebral artery thrombosis (CAT) and heparin therapy. After 1 month, she was readmitted due to recurrence of TIA. Because she had a definite history of atrial fibrillation, a warfarin therapy was started. The TEE showed a significant change in the AoV morphology, without any thrombus \[[Figure 1(b)](#F1){ref-type="fig"}\]. A few weeks after starting warfarin, she had another episode of TIA and was readmitted to the hospital again. She had a third episode of TIA and was then transferred to our stroke unit. The CAT was diagnosed based on the latest angiography and TEE; she was eventually diagnosed with warfarin-induced aortic thrombi (WIAT). After a few days, when her symptoms were controlled with oral anticoagulant, antiplatelets, she was discharged and she was advised to continue anticoagulant therapy. After 1 year of follow up, CTA was arranged to measure the size of the ICA thrombus and atherosclerotic plaques. We found a thrombus of 5 mm in the left ICA after CTA and no atherosclerotic plaque at this level of the ICA \[[Figure 1(c)](#F1){ref-type="fig"}\]. One more episode of transient right hemianopsia occurred but only lasted for 5 min. These results indicate the presence of a WIAT, and this was confirmed by echocardiography.

![A thrombus (a) and thrombus with a narrow lumen (b) on magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the intracranial vessels (left arrow, thrombus; right arrow, narrow wall thrombus) and thrombus detected on transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) (c).](CMJ-128-1237-g001){#F1}

![(a) TEE detected a 6 mm mobile mass on the aortic valve (AoV) cusps, (b) transesophageal echocardiograpy showing a mobile aortic thrombi after treatment with warfarin and antiplatelets, (c) computed tomography angiography of the carotid vessels showing the thrombus (left arrow) and atherosclerotic plaque (right arrow) (d).](CMJ-128-1237-g002){#F2}

Q1. What is the origin of free-floating thrombi?
================================================

A. Free-floating thrombi are generally formed before CTA or TEE. The majority of them originate from ruptured atherosclerotic plaques in long-term anticoagulation therapy. Free-floating thrombi are usually larger because more time is needed to clot than those in the vessel wall. Free-floating thrombi are usually detected at least 6 months after they were formed. Prompt: Question: Dementia and aphasia in motor neuron disease: an underrecognised association? Answer:
Response:
Yes. {#FPar3}
===========================================================================================

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a chronic, fatal, progressive, neurodegenerative disorder involving motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord that result in loss of voluntary muscle function (Box [1](#Sec1){ref-type="sec"}) \[[@CR1]\]. As the disease progresses, affected patients typically lose ability to move and swallow, leading to difficulty breathing and ultimately death. There is currently no cure for ALS. The course of disease varies, with some individuals having the disease for several years, others making relatively fast progress over months or years, and others experiencing marked decline over a few months.

Dementia with aphasia (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by loss of language and progressive decline in cognitive function that may be observed in up to 85% of patients \[[@CR2]\]. The most common presenting symptom is a deficit in word comprehension. Additional features include memory loss, visual spatial deficits, lack of judgement and poor decision making, and abnormalities in executive abilities that include lack of insight and impaired judgement. Non-AD causes of dementia include stroke, multiple sclerosis and dementia with Lewy bodies. Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in older people but other dementias may be caused by different pathophysiological mechanisms. The majority of people with AD have a history of significant cognitive decline prior to the onset of motor symptoms. This is referred to as 'pre-clinical' dementia because the onset of clinical symptoms is months or even years after the initial cognitive deficits become apparent.

The association between neurodegenerative disorders has been known for some time. A number of different conditions can present in a person with ALS including frontotemporal dementia \[[@CR3]\], Pick disease and progressive supranuclear palsy \[[@CR4]\]. Conversely, there are many patients with a rapidly progressive, disabling disorder that can also cause dementia. Although these disorders usually have a non-ALS aetiology, about 5% may be clinically indistinguishable from ALS \[[@CR5]\].

In this case report, we describe a patient who died from a motor neuron disease (MND) and a mild dementia that was consistent with AD but whose presentation had no other obvious features of MND.

Case report {#Sec2}
===========

A 76-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension was referred by his general practitioner to the acute medical team because of confusion and progressive weakness of both upper and lower limbs for a 2-year period. His family reported that, for the first 3 years, he was completely independent and mobile, and that the onset of his symptoms occurred after holiday in Australia when he was aged 78 years. He complained of a progressive general loss of function, with the most evident change being that of dysarthria and severe word finding difficulties. He had mild cognitive impairment requiring medication review but was independent in most other activities of daily living, with the exception of walking, which he could no longer carry out independently. He lived with his family, who provided a variety of supportive care tasks, but he was also socially inactive and relied on his husband's ongoing care. He had never had a problem with alcohol or drugs.

Medical examination at admission to hospital revealed a dishevelled and bedraggled old man, who gave a poor response to questions, and demonstrated poor comprehension of speech with difficulty pronouncing the letter 'z'.

The initial diagnosis was that of an inpatient with mild cognitive impairment and suspected frontotemporal dementia. He was managed as an inpatient and treated with high doses of both haloperidol and amiodarone, with some reduction in the intensity of his symptoms, especially on verbal commands. He died suddenly 5 weeks after admission and autopsy was carried out.

Pathology report {#Sec3}
================

No evidence of an underlying disease process to explain his cognitive changes was discovered. There was marked spongiosis in the temporal cortex bilaterally, with patchy neurone loss primarily in hippocampus and amygdala (Fig. [1](#Fig1){ref-type="fig"}). Bilateral frontal lobe showed marked spongiosis in the perforant pathway area without loss of frontal cortex cortical neurons. The cerebellar cortex was free from spongiosis bilaterally. A mild diffuse Lewy body type II neurone change was seen in the neocortex while there was marked atrophy of amygdala.Fig. 1Autopsy findings. **a** Neuropathological changes in hippocampus and cortex (hematoxylin and eosin; *bar* 400 μm). **b** Neuropathological changes in temporal lobe and amygdala (hematoxylin

P971: Identification of a *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* complex isolate that was resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid among patients with tuberculosis in South China {#cesec2296}
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

S. Yang, J. Lai, H. Zhu

*Guangzhou, CHN*

**Objectives:** To identify the most common of *M. tuberculosis* complex isolates that produce resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin resistance.

**Methods:** A cross-sectional study was performed. Clinical specimens and drug susceptibility testing result were obtained from the provincial laboratory from 2007 to 2008. We excluded positive results only for *M. tuberculosis.* Patients suspected to have TB were enrolled as subjects. Species identification, *in-house* drug resistance testing and spoligotyping were performed on the clinical isolates of *M. tuberculosis.*

**Results:** The study enrolled 532 patients (male/female ratio: 1.6/1). The overall resistance rates of isolates to INH and RFP were 48/532(9.1%) and 14/532(2.7%) respectively. *M. tuberculosis* of Chinese genotype was the most prevalent (95/532, 18.1%), followed by *M. africanum* (38/532, 7.1%) and *M. canettii* (3/532, 0.5%). Among the strains with INH and RFP resistance rates of \>15%, a common mutation of Ile to Val in amino acid position 315 of codon 315 of GyrB was observed in 5/6 of the strains.

**Conclusions:** Drug resistant rate among those patients with confirmed TB cases is 9.1%. The most most common strain is *M. tuberculosis of the Chinese genotype,* followed by *M. africanum* and *M. canettii.* A genetic mechanism may explain resistance of *M. tuberculosis* isolates to the two most important first-line anti-tuberculosis drugs among patients with TB in South China.

P972: A high rate of drug resistance among newly diagnosed pulmonary tuberculosis patients in Ethiopia {#cesec2300}
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A. Abebe, R. G. Dabta, T. Y. Teklu, X. B. Ato Ayele, E. G. Tazie

*Addis Ababa, ET*

**Objectives:** To determine the rate of drug-resistance among new cases of pulmonary tuberculosis seen at St Paul TB center in Ethiopia.

**Methods:** In January 2006, the first 2 months of the year, data for 9 months were collected prospectively for patients with smear positive pulmonary tuberculosis at St. Paul\'s TB center, which is the only government TB center in Addis Ababa. All patients were new cases (i.e. not relapses) and not severely ill.

**Results:** From the 9 months, a total of 631 first episodes of TB were diagnosed and treated in St Paul\' s TB center. The number of total cases seen, sputum positive, and culture positive for *M. tuberculosis* were 621, 487 and 491 respectively. Culture confirmed cases were then followed for drug-resistance at least for 6 months. The prevalence of isoniazid resistant tuberculosis (INH resistant strain) was 21%, streptomycin (STR resistant strain) was 33% and rifampicin (RMP resistant strain) was 14%. Multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) were 15%

**Conclusions:** The results of this study indicate that the prevalence of drug resistance among newly diagnosed cases in Ethiopia is not negligible. This gives rise to concern that patients will continue to be infectious and the drug-resistance will eventually lead to treatment failure and death if treatment fails. Moreover, the prevalence of MDR in this population is worrying and has to be addressed further by improving the quality of directly observed treatment, short-course of treatment.
