Prompt: Question: Does Residency Selection Criteria Predict Performance in Orthopaedic Surgery Residency? Answer:
Response:
No
=========================================================================================================

After graduating from a non-Orthopaedic surgery residency program, orthopaedic surgery trainees are often considered "finished" and have few avenues for further examination. In fact, a majority of orthopaedic surgery training programs use their trainees' overall performance during their residency for admission to orthopaedic surgery residency, with few exceptions such as the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery (ABOS) Orthopaedic Residency Matching Program (ORMP). The ABOS ORMP utilizes the Orthopaedic Research and Education Foundation (OREF) residency ranking score, calculated using programmatic data, to match applicants. This is in contrast to the Residency Match Service (RMS -- National Resident Matching Program) which utilizes US and Canadian residency program rankings and programmatic data to match applicants. As with the RMS ORMP and the residency programs themselves, residency programs are often reluctant to share their residency selection criteria and, subsequently, trainees may not perform well in orthopaedic surgery residency if their residency program selection criterion was not utilized. Therefore, residency applicants may be performing substandard compared to those who graduated from a residency program with a less comprehensive selection criteria. It is critical for applicants to understand this fact and be prepared to highlight their strengths in a residency application.

QUESTION: What Are the Residency Ranking Criteria Used by Orthopaedic Surgery Residency Programs? Answer: We know that there are many residency programs out there in the United States and Canada and each of these programs has at least 16 applicants (1 from Canada and 15 from the US). This means that 16 × 16 = 256 possible combinations of applicants are competing for one of these orthopaedic surgery residency training slots. Although the ABOS ORMP does not utilize selection criteria such as a personal statement to narrow down the match list, residency programs vary greatly. For example, applicants to residency programs have different minimum required letters of recommendation written in accordance to the program's requirements. Each of the 256 combinations is not an equal possibility for selection into a residency program ([Fig. 1](#FI001055-1){ref-type="fig"}).

![Orthopaedic surgery residency programs often require multiple letters of recommendation. The RMS ORMP ( **A** ) accepts all 16 of these letters of recommendation. The ABOS ORMP ( **B** ) currently accepts 3 letters of recommendation. Each combination of 3 letters of recommendation is an equally likely possibility.](10-1055-s-0040-1713756-i001055-01){#FI001055-1}

Many residency programs also select residents based on objective assessments, such as Orthopaedic Research Evaluation Board (ORIB) or ABOS Orthopaedic Fellowship Selection Program (OFSP) scores (this is the same as the ABOS ORMP ranking score), percentile ranks, as well as their USMLE Step 1 score. USMLE is one of the most important components which includes the core medical schools, the ABOS Step 1 (comprehensive) and the Orthopaedic Surgery Boards. This includes a written examination, followed by 3 to 5 oral questions, followed by a clinical assessment (clinical) which can include skills exercises, a case presentation, and a short case discussion.

When it comes to the selection of applicants into residency, US and Canadian residency programs differ. Some programs require only the OREF ranking score for applicants, others only require the OREF plus one other scoring factor, whereas others may require the OREF ranking score plus 4 to 6 additional selection criteria. Furthermore, residency programs in the ABOS region are divided into three levels: regional (programs that oversee one or more states \[typically 5 to 25 programs\]), regional consortium (programs that oversee several states \[typically more than 25 programs\]) and centralized (programs that oversee multiple states and provinces in North America) [@R001055-2].

We would like to mention that OREF does not rank programs. However, OREF\'s research program (which comprises the Orthopaedic Research and Education Foundation), develops an Orthopaedic Research and Education Score (ORES), which grades each program based on certain factors of their research performance [@R001055-3].

An individual applicant\'s experience during residency will vary greatly based on the orthopaedic residency program that he or she matriculates at. It is important for the applicant to understand that during residency, it is typical that program-based training will include didactic lectures, conferences, seminars and conferences, and resident-driven clinical activities, including, but not limited to, surgeries or procedures, or case conferences.

To review applicants for competitive residency positions, these programs utilize several criteria, including OREF rankings, ORIB

Prompt: Question: Optimism and survival: does an optimistic outlook predict better survival at advanced ages? Answer:
Response:
Some of the early studies in that line indicated that the opposite might be true. A team led by the University of North Carolina’s Paul J. Rowe has now found that optimistic self-views do predict more robust survival in old age. The paper is published in the journal Psychoneuroendocrinology.

While the work was done with men, the findings could be relevant for women as well. That’s because the study involved three cognitive measures that are found to be more prevalent in women than in men. There has been some speculation that negative thoughts are more likely to cross someone’s mind, and that cognitive factors could be more common in women. But Rowe and his colleagues wanted to see if they could find any causal connections.

Using a study involving over 5,000 male volunteers, Rowe’s team found that those participants who reported feeling more optimistic, reported fewer health problems. They also had more friends — which is a measure that some have argued is also associated with an optimistic outlook. The researchers found that optimistic men also lived longer. Their lives ended in better health as well.

The researchers analyzed data that had already been collected by the Chicago Health and Aging Project, which followed many of the men for 20 years. The researchers did not analyze whether that optimism was directly related to any changes in health outcomes. But Rowe said other research did. For example, a previous study by another team found that an optimism-predicting psychological inventory (i.e., one that’s used to assess how optimistic someone is) was linked to better physical health, even when accounting for the effects of age and other risk factors such as body mass.

In the current study, the women were not even asked about their optimism in the first interview; they only learned that fact in the year they were in the study. In the current study when the “optimist” was defined, it reflected a feeling of overall well-being. The researchers also did not adjust the results for health or other factors. And, the sample size was not as large as in the original study. But their analyses — which were adjusted for socioeconomic status (an indicator of how much money you make) and health — found the same positive findings about the survival advantage for the optimists.

The researchers hope that this study will encourage other scientists to replicate the findings. And Rowe and colleagues plan to try to find out what’s driving the positive effect. Is it that optimism leads them to be healthier, and healthier people live longer? Or do they feel that way because they live longer? Or is there something else?

That’s not the only study of optimism over these past few weeks in which we learned something interesting about aging. A study led by the National Institute on Aging (NIA) found that having a “positive disposition” of the person was linked to better physical and mental health even when you considered the effect of genetics. Another study out of the Yale School of Medicine followed nearly 1,000 people as they aged over three decades. It found that an optimistic trait that the researchers were able to measure in the early part of the research participants ’ lives, predicted a larger cognitive reserve. That is, as people age, they may experience an increase in cognitive decline and memory loss. In this work, the optimists, who tended to be younger at the start of the study, were less likely to experience those losses of brain function as time went on.

You can read the papers about the NIA study and the Yale study in this month’s issue, Volume 4, Issue 8 of the Journal of Neuroscience Research.

Prompt: Question: Is arch form influenced by sagittal molar relationship or Bolton tooth-size discrepancy? Answer:
Response:
The molar relationship shows a great influence and the second and third molars can be used to determine the arch width and arch relation in the sagittal plane.

**Case presentation:** A female patient, born with a low occlusion and high Bolton ratio, presented to our clinic for therapy planning. In detail: Angle class I, positive overjet, negative overbite and increased Bolton ratio. She had a Class I molar relation bilaterally and a slightly rotated U-shape maxillary molars. Therefore, the therapy plan was to open the maxillary molars slightly. Furthermore, the incidences were corrected and the lower incisors were extended slightly to compensate for the small-sized upper lip. The occlusion was corrected by the movement of the mandible. To maintain the final result, retainers were needed. We planned to have two premolar-like bonded retainers each composed of an incontinental 0.018-inch titanium wire embedded in the lingual surface of the crown of the maxillary lateral incisors and canines. The total treatment time was 28 months and was completed without any complications. During the follow up period the molar relationship was stable and there were no relapses.

**How to cite this article:** Kocaoglu D, Alper KÇ, Karan E. Influence of molar relationship and Bolton tooth size discrepancy on arches form. Surg Odontol Case Rep 8(5): 380-1-2. 2016;63:37-39.

They are not. Please read my comment to the answer by bobbogun.

A:

LEEP is "loop excision procedure": removal of one or more ring of the cervix.
Cold Knife Conization (CKC) is cold, often cauterizing, and usually involves the removal of small or tiny portions of tissue. As such, I suspect this was originally a method of treatment for cervical precancer, that became more widespread.
Now we use both to treat more advanced dysplasia, however. These have a higher chance of recurrence than pre cancer does, so they are removed or ablated more aggressively, and then followed with more treatment, in an attempt to remove as much of the lesion and possible precancerous cell, and treat the rest of it as effectively as possible.
The problem is that it isn't clear precisely which portions of the procedure are effective, nor the ideal duration of the follow-up - that has to be done by further research. So my answer might be "they are not the same, yes", but I can't be sure.

Prompt: Question: Are pectins involved in cold acclimation and de-acclimation of winter oil-seed rape plants? Answer:
Response:
Pectins have been identified in relation to cold acclimation and de-acclimation of winter rapeseed. Pectin lyases (PL) are enzymes involved in the catabolism of pectin degradation. They may influence cold acclimation and de-acclimation of tissues due to pectin degradation.

The cold hardening of seedlings of winter oil-seed rape is accompanied by an increase in the activity of pectin lyase (PL) (Eckhardt et al., 1988; Ekman, 1997). Moreover, in recent years more attention has been paid to the role of pectin in plant cold acclimation. The PLs are ubiquitous ubiquitous enzymes present in the majority of tissues of higher plants. The enzymes consist of four families: fungal PLs, animal and microbial PLs, endopolygalacturonases and pectate lyases (Elyan et al., 2009; Eckhardt and Kölliker, 1995; Eckhardt et al., 1988; Van der Kraak et al., 2007). Plants express fungal PLs, microbial PLs, and PGA depolymerases encoded by an extensive family of PL genes (Elyan et al., 2009; De Vliegher et al., 2007; Eckhardt and Kölliker, 1995). The role of pectin in cold acclimation and deacclimation of winter oil seed and other crops is well documented (Gupta et al., 1979; Ekman, 1997; Eckhardt et al., 1988; Ekman, 1997; Eckhardt and Kölliker, 1995; Van der Kraak et al., 2007). Recent research has focused on pectin in response to cold stress in winter oil-seed rape. Pectin is a complex and dynamic polysaccharide found in the primary and secondary cell walls of all plant species and has multiple roles in plant growth and development. The rhamnogalacturonan I, II and III regions are common within the pectic domains of the cell wall of plants, and they contain a highly conserved and highly methyl-esterified region that may affect tissue differentiation (van der Graaf et al., 1987; Zweers, 2009).

The activity of pectin lyase in winter oil-seed rape is significantly increased during the cold acclimation (De Vliegher et al., 2007). The enhanced activity may contribute to the plant’s ability to maintain cell wall integrity under low-temperature condition. PL enzymes have been shown to be involved not only in plant cold acclimation, but also in seed germination and plant development, such as hypocotyl growth, flower formation, fruit development, embryo development, pollination initiation, and flower senescence (Fukaya-Kobe et al., 2000; Liu et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2014). In order to analyze the function of PL in the cold hardening of winter oil-seed rape, transgenic techniques have been used (De Vliegher et al., 2007). The effect of PL mutants on cold acclimation and deacclimation in tomato plants have also been investigated (Gu and Xue, 2015).

The PL family encoded by the pectinase gene is widespread and is ubiquitous within the primary and secondary cell walls of all higher plants. The pectinase genes represent a multi-gene family within the PL coding. The enzyme encoded by the PL gene is known as pectinmethylesterase (PME). Pectinmethylesterase de-esterifies pectin at the intersection of the O- and C-groups, releases unsaturated carboxyl acid and an unsaturated aldehyde (C2-OH or C3-OH) as reaction products. The enzyme family consists of 10 members in Arabidopsis thaliana (Dhankher et al., 2010; Ekman, 1997; Yang and Xie, 2008) and 13 in potato (Sauviere et al., 1999). There are 11 pectinmethylesterase genes and 2 PL genes in the Brassica.

The genome of oil-seed rape has been published and the genome-wide identification of genes in Brassica is available. The PL gene family and the expression of PL genes during cold stress was studied on the basis of Arabidopsis thaliana. Three PL genes were found in B. napus, and they were designated BnPME1, BnPME2, and BnPME3 on the basis of their cDNAs, which has been cloned (Elyan et al., 2009).

The expression levels of three BPME genes have been assayed during cold and de-

Prompt: Question: Updating emotional content in working memory: a depression-specific deficit? Answer:
Response:
Yes and no.
Two experiments were conducted to determine under what conditions depressed and non-depressed samples differ in their ability to manipulate emotional contents held in working memory. In Experiment 1, two groups of non-depressed volunteers were instructed to remember neutral and emotional pictures for a subsequent recall test. In contrast, subjects with depression reported feeling negative when they saw previously negative and positive images. However, in contrast to the non-depressed group, the depressed subjects' verbal fluency also revealed increased negative and reduced positive responses to stimuli relative to their reports of feelings. In Experiment 2, negative and positive words were paired with pictures on the basis of whether the former was or was not a member of the same semantic category as the latter. Depressed and non-depressed individuals showed similar performance on this task unless the stimuli were congruent between words and pictures and they were instructed to suppress emotional responses. In all cases, the depression group was slower to respond to negatively and positively incongruent pairs than their non-depressed counterparts. These findings provide support for the hypotheses that verbal and visual emotional responses in depressed and non-depressed groups differ in both quantity and quality and that verbal fluency, as used by the depressed subjects in Experiment 1, might involve the cognitive process of suppression. The implications of these findings for models of cognitive dysfunctions associated with depression are discussed.

Prompt: Question: Does ultrasound imaging before puncture facilitate internal jugular vein cannulation? Answer:
Response:
There are no relevant reports.

Objective: To assess the quality of the ultrasound images obtained pre-venipuncture, so as to enable an ultrasound-guided internal jugular vein cannulation.

Methods: An exploratory retrospective study of the ultrasound images obtained pre-venipuncture at the Emergency Department was performed.

Results: Of the 624 procedures recorded, there were 7 pre-venipuncture ultrasound imaging failures (12% of the cohort). For 7 of these failures, a better quality image could be obtained in the subsequent puncture.

Conclusions: The quality of the images obtained pre-venipuncture may be compromised in one in every 14 procedures due to patient positioning or imaging equipment issues.

Introduction

When medical and surgical wards are closed, the number of patients seeking emergency care has increased markedly [1]. In these patients a correct venepuncture is challenging, and, frequently, the venous cannula cannot be inserted as planned. This is not a rare occurrence in critical patients: among the 849 patients in the Numerus Emergency Medicine Network, only 5.8% had the planned central venous line (CVL) inserted at the bedside in Italy [2]. An ultrasound imaging study of the internal jugular vein (IJV) in a lateral decubitus position is mandatory prior to a planned procedure. This approach, when it has to be done preoperatively (as the only information about the patient’s body or about the location of the IJV will be provided by an external puncture), is even more demanding.

According to the European Federation of Societies for Ultrasound in Medicine and Biology (EFSUMB), the puncture should:

[…] be performed in a manner that results in the minimum of external scarring of the patients as far as possible, and an avoidance of unnecessary traumas. [3]

Practical aspects of IJV puncture

The IJV can be considered the safest central vein for central catheters for several reasons. Firstly, it lies between the lungs and the vertebral column and presents less risk of complications than the subclavian vein. Secondly, it is more accessible than other catheterization sites, particularly in obese patients. Third, as opposed to other sites, it contains no valves, and insertion of a central catheter therein will not result in any significant reduction in flow rate.

A good anatomical knowledge is required in these procedures. The internal jugular vein begins 2–3 cm above the level of the skull base at the side of the neck, descends slightly toward the middle, and runs horizontally between the internal jugular tubercle on the side of the neck. The vein is surrounded by the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein (IJV) and sternohyoid muscle [4].

When this latter muscle is contracted, it presses against surrounding structures, thus reducing the space for the IJV to move. The IJV is thus usually accessible only when viewed from the lateral decubitus position [5]. The internal jugular veins, IJV are visualized by ultrasound as hypoechoic in the posterior part of the neck, as there is low blood flow. Their diameter can vary from 4 to 6 mm (Figures 1–2).

Figure 1.

Right lobe of the liver (L) and portal vein (PV).

Figure 2.

The middle hepatic veins (MHV) and inferior vena cava (IVC) are shown.

According to the latest ASE recommendations [6], patients should be placed in a supine position with the head placed in an upright position.

There are various options for IJV cannula placement. One common point of view is that externalizing the IJV is the easiest method, as it gives the most accessible vein for catheterization. An alternative approach is the internalization of the catheter through the pectoralis major muscle, so that it will be less likely to get lost under the skin, and a larger catheter could be inserted [7]. Both techniques should be considered based on anatomical access.

Several trials comparing the IJV cannulation methods showed better results from internalization of the catheter, particularly in obese patients. This, however, may lead to more complications [8].

This approach, however, is not so useful when the internal jugular vein is too superficial, or where the IJV branches, as it is a blind procedure.

Other points are the need for ultrasound equipment (for IJV imaging), the fact that an inexperienced user often produces poor quality images [see 3], and the presence of anesthesiologists or other medical staff that can help during the procedure.

The success rate of IJV catheterization in a supine position,

Prompt: Question: Does obstructive sleep apnea affect aerobic fitness? Answer:
Response:
The evidence indicates that a history of obstructive sleep apnea affects a patient's aerobic fitness. There is research indicating that the combination of poor ventilation and poor sleep quality can negatively impact performance. A few studies have indicated that obstructive sleep apnea increases the risk of in-hospital and post-hospital complications. Some studies do not indicate an association with the disease, but there are issues with small sample sizes and a healthy volunteer bias associated with most of these studies. As obstructive sleep apnea is quite common, I do not believe the overall consensus of the studies would change your clinical practice. Obstructive sleep apnea and its associated complications are associated with the metabolic syndrome, cardiovascular, and immune dysfunction. This evidence may impact overall fitness, but more importantly, it may increase the risk of cardiovascular and diabetes-related disease.

Question: Are there any tests you suggest before surgery for obstructive sleep apnea? Answer: A sleep history, snoring, body mass index, and the Epworth Sleepiness Scale are the most important tests prior to surgery (i.e., tracheostomy). The sleep physician can help you determine if there is excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) or periodic limb movement (PLM) disorder or if you need an overnight sleep study. I believe the sleep test is most important and I see patients preoperatively for about 10 minutes. Most patients have obstructive sleep apnea with a body mass index (BMI) greater than 30 kg/m. The patient should have an Epworth Sleepiness Score that does not indicate the need for a sleep study. The physician should refer the patient to a sleep physician before surgery as many physicians may miss the diagnosis of sleep apnea and many patients are not referred preoperatively.

Question: Can obstructive sleep apnea be treated in the outpatient setting? Answer: Yes, you can treat obstructive sleep apnea in the outpatient setting. This can be accomplished with a tracheotomy, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), oral appliance, or sleep training.

Tracheostomies are usually used in the intensive care unit when a patient is acutely ill or intubated. Patients with severe sleep apnea on a ventilator may consider a tracheostomy. The procedure is performed by a specialized otolaryngologist that is comfortable performing this procedure. Patients requiring a tracheostomy are evaluated for surgical risk versus the benefit of the procedure. Patients must be awake and cooperative because if this were not the case the procedure would be cancelled for the day. Patients are not intubated or sedated the day of the procedure.

An oral appliance should be used if the patient is compliant in wearing it. This appliance is used for the first night only, and patients go home when the use of the appliance is helpful. The oral appliance should ideally be used to treat obstructive sleep apnea. Many patients find that the oral appliance is a comfortable way to sleep at night. Compliance with the sleep apnea prescription improves the night of the week of the treatment. Some patients find that using the CPAP at night is better than the oral appliance.

Many sleep centers have sleep laboratories equipped with an intra-oral device. The device is similar to a retainer that fits in the mouth and can keep the tongue forward. This helps keep the airway open. The patient’s sleep is monitored. The physician may use additional aids to improve sleep quality before starting a CPAP during the night. The sleep physician will need to evaluate the patient's medical status, and if needed, perform or consider a sleep study.

A CPAP is the most common sleep management program. The air pressure is programmed for the patient and is provided through a mask that is attached to the nose or face through nasal prongs. It may be helpful for some people that are more comfortable sleeping on their faces. The patient has to sleep with the mask and prong attached on each side of their nose. Most of the time the patient only needs one mask and prong for good results. Some patients may feel nasal irritation but can tolerate this. Patients should practice in the evening before going to bed. Once the patient starts effective therapy, follow the manufacturer's instructions and go to sleep with the mask and prong.

Sleep physicians should evaluate each patient's needs by starting the therapy on the first or second night for success. The sleep physician will also teach the patient how to use the mask and how to go to sleep on the first night only by monitoring the patient’s breathing. Some patients sleep fine but wake up to breathe, and they will sleep worse on the CPAP because they are now waking up.

The patient may need to be monitored with an overnight sleep study to understand the level of the patient’s apnea. The physician will know if the patient needs continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), supplemental oxygen, a tracheostomy,

Prompt: Question: The effect of an intracerebroventricular injection of metformin or AICAR on the plasma concentrations of melatonin in the ewe: potential involvement of AMPK? Answer:
Response:
The question is valid and the answer is yes.

Introduction
============

Endogenous ligands regulate the activity of adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase (AMPK) ([@b1-ijmm-35-06-1525]--[@b3-ijmm-35-06-1525]) which is a heterotrimeric molecule that consists of a catalytic α-subunit and two regulatory β- and γ-subunits ([@b4-ijmm-35-06-1525]--[@b6-ijmm-35-06-1525]). The discovery of metformin (N\'-ethyl-N\'-\[4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl\]-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide) led to the development of an oral anti-diabeticeffective agent for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus ([@b7-ijmm-35-06-1525],[@b8-ijmm-35-06-1525]). Metformin is a small organic cation, which lowers insulin resistance via adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase (AMPK) inhibition ([@b9-ijmm-35-06-1525]). Additionally, metformin has also been described as an inhibitor of the mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 ([@b10-ijmm-35-06-1525]).

Activation of AMPK is a mechanism for improving insulin sensitivity ([@b11-ijmm-35-06-1525],[@b12-ijmm-35-06-1525]). Metformin is a natural product, isolated from the *Galega officinalis* plant, and one of the most popular anti-diabetic drugs of all times. The metformin-AMPK axis has been the subject of an extensive amount of research over the last years. Various studies are available in the literature showing that metformin directly activates AMPK in cells mainly by the inhibition of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex I ([@b9-ijmm-35-06-1525],[@b13-ijmm-35-06-1525]--[@b19-ijmm-35-06-1525]). It is well established that metformin modulates gene expression mainly by activation of AMPK ([@b20-ijmm-35-06-1525]). Recently, it was reported that melatonin improves insulin sensitivity mainly by reducing inflammation and enhancing insulin signaling pathway ([@b21-ijmm-35-06-1525]--[@b23-ijmm-35-06-1525]). This study aimed to detect whether melatonin is able to activate AMPK and modulate gene expression. Therefore, the present study was undertaken. The results demonstrated that melatonin activates AMPK and modulates gene expression.

Materials and methods
=====================

This study was carried out in strict accordance with the recommendations in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the National Institutes of Health and with the Spanish regulations for the protection of experimental animals under the Royal Decree 1201/2003 and the RD53/2013 regarding the protection of animals used for experimental and other scientific purposes. The protocols were approved by the Animal Ethics Committee of the University of Seville, Spain. Animals care and handling were performed with due consideration to reduce suffering and the number of animals used in experimentation.

Chemicals
---------

Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), Dulbecco's modified eagle's medium (DMEM), fetal bovine serum (FBS), trypsin-EDTA, penicillin/streptomycin, Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA). The anti-α (H-300 Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA, USA), anti-β (A-12 Santa Cruz Biotechnology), anti-γ-subunits (sc-744 Santa Cruz Biotechnology) antibodies and metformin (Sigma-Aldrich) were supplied by Santa Cruz Biotechnology. MitoTEMPO ((2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyl)octa-1,4,7-triol, 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy) was procured from Cayman Chemical Company (Ann Arbor, MI, USA). Melatonin was supplied by Melatron Gmb

Prompt: Question: Literacy after cerebral hemispherectomy: Can the isolated right hemisphere read? Answer:
Response:
The isolated right hemisphere can read in the same way that a blind person can sense light. For example, a blind person can perceive light with a part of his "sense mechanism." The blind man can "see" something called a "retinal image," which we understand to be the equivalent of what goes behind the eyes of a living person. The blind person can also be made to see a "visual image" by stimulating the proper part of his "sense mechanism." We can use the same principle to teach an isolated right hemisphere to read. It is a kind of "stimulated vision." However, all the visual images are located elsewhere. The part of the brain that is equivalent to the eye, when isolated, does not know how to see anything. In the same way, the part of the isolated brain that is equivalent to the brain that sees, when stimulated, does not know how to read. However, an isolated brain is free to read in the same way that the blind become "sighted." We must think about a blind man in the same way as we think about someone living with one hemisphere of the brain removed. (Cerebral Hemispherectomy by E. G. Miller, p. 7-9) (The italics are mine.) So the blind who is deprived of just one hemisphere of his brain is still a "blind" since he is actually seeing what they call a "retinal image". That visual image must be "received" by another part of his brain, the cortex, before it is processed further so it can be put in a kind of file for future "learning". So, this person is in a situation much like someone who is blind but, instead of being deprived of sight in one eye, has been blinded in one side of his brain so as to deprive him of sight in that half of his brain (which processes the image he is seeing). This is an amazing statement about what is really going on in the left hemisphere of the brain after a hemispherectomy. It is like a blind person suddenly having one side of his blind-spot removed. If the right hemisphere of the brain has a visual image, it has to go through the cortex of the left hemisphere, which can then record it so that later it can be used to "read" - the isolated right brain is "sight-blind" (blindsight) in the same sense as the isolated eye is actually blind.

I feel like I am being confronted by my old enemy again: The devil is in the details. How do you use the fact that the left hemisphere does most of the sensory processing and "records" in the "memory"? By using brain imaging (EEG, fMRI, PET), one can see the same areas of the brain that function to process sight and to store memory are very active as the blind are told to think of different objects. Even the right hemisphere is active during visual processing in the cortex but is not being used until after this "processing" is finished (if done with the help of a blind therapist) by a learning process (in the cortex). The left hemisphere does not have direct access to the right hemisphere since both are connected by the corpus callosum so some kind of indirect connection must be made via the cortex of the left hemisphere. What is being seen is an almost-normal right cerebral hemisphere with an occasional "miss" depending on the specific function being done in the brain (the right hemisphere is not used to play chess or touch-typing). The patient does learn to touch-type and some learning has been done with the right hemisphere on the other side of the brain as well. And these studies are done by people who have some idea of right hemisphere functions. I think the right hemisphere is being used by the blind in the same way that the blind are helped to "see" by light. There is a kind of visual image in the right hemisphere, which can be stimulated and learned by the blind. Here is one example. http://www.academia.edu/136622/Stimulating_Blind_Readers_through_Blindsight_by_EEG:_Reading_in_Hemispherectomy_Patients The patient will read in the same way that a blind person "sees" using a part of their "sense mechanism" and the isolated right brain is being "sighted" in the same way that a person with blindness becomes sighted by using the "sight mechanism" of the blind.

So, it is not so much that the "sense mechanism" of the blind can be "used" by the brain as in the case of the patient with blindness and the removed right hemisphere, but it is that the "visual images" that are created in the right hemisphere can be stored in the right hemisphere. Prompt: Question: Characterization of the gender dimorphism after injury and hemorrhagic shock: are hormonal differences responsible? Answer:
Response:
Yes.
An adequate understanding of shock, one that is specific not only to the organism but also to specific regions or the entire body, is needed to formulate possible interventions. With this study we sought to evaluate the possible role of gender on the hemodynamic consequences after acute arterial hypotension caused by hemorrhage. Three groups of rats were studied: intact male, intact female, and castrated. Castration of the rats increased their mean blood pressure during the resting state and attenuated the effect of induced hypotension in the group of males. Hypotension induced significantly greater decreases in the heart rate in castrated male as compared to intact male and intact female. In the female and castrated rat, hypotension induced bradycardia. Female rats demonstrated greater decrease in cardiac output during induced hypotension, suggesting higher sensitivity to cardiovascular stimulation with decreased flow. Therefore, male rat seems to be more protected than females during hemodynamic stimulation. To investigate the causes for this difference, we proposed that there were significant differences in the amount of blood perfusion or hormonal levels. As a result of the study, we concluded that the hemodynamic response was modified by the gender. To clarify such gender-related differences, hemodynamic measurements need to be performed in more sensitive experimental models.

Prompt: Question: Can communication with terminally ill patients be taught? Answer:
Response: To some people it seems almost unfathomable that they would be able to "talk back" to a doctor or nurse and tell them everything they have been doing wrong. In fact, it can be argued that this seems so impossible, that it cannot exist. But for many terminally ill patients, the last thing on their minds is dying, or anything to do with death, and it is only when your own life is in grave danger that a patient will be able to talk to you. With the help of the Euthanasia Task Force, a new communication therapy programme has been developed where terminally ill pateints are trained to communicate with doctors and nurses using a simple, language they understand. The programme was devised by Dr Jan Sparwasser who was, until 1997, a clinical psychologist working with HIV patients. She also ran a training programme for HIV patients to learn how to have more control over their lives in those final days, which was successful after more than 50 people had undergone the training. "I began to realise just how painful that time could be" Jan says. "I thought there must be a better way." Following several years of researching, she and a colleague, Dr. Jo Hirsch-Rechinger, were to develop the communication therapy programme. "The programme has three steps... First, we teach patients how to communicate. Most patients get the idea of talking to their doctors without the use of gestures, though they should remember that doctors don't like questions. "But with practice patients can learn to say what they want in language they know best, and doctors will respond to questions rather than to answers. "This programme is ideal for people that have had no experience of illness as the language they use while talking is more or less the same as they use with friends and families. That makes it easy to remember what they are telling us when they are talking to us. "Second, with a view to having more control over their lives - the kind of control that people dying with cancer now have - patients can be taught how they can give doctors directions. "Patients know that they are dying, and that life for them, whether it goes well or badly, is over. Patients know the disease they have, and so they know the time of their death, but this doesn't happen suddenly. They may have an infection, which will kill them; or they may have the brain which doesn't work, after which they usually die within days. Then there are people whose disease develops into a more serious form like bowel cancer or leukaemia with a rapid rate of decline - they will die quickly but they usually know what is happening, and so this is when the patients get more control over their lives through their own knowledge. These patients often already have more information about how they are feeling, and they often have people who support them, or who, if they can't support them, will talk to the doctors and nurses for them. "This is when patients first learn about their illness and their pain. As they begin to cope with this, their experience of illness begins to change. This is a particularly important time for the patient as they must learn how to cope with their feelings about their disease, the treatment they may be receiving, and other distressing events like being told that the end is near. The third step is for patients to think about the end, so that in their minds they can begin to take control over their lives. To me, the end is not just to die, it is to die because someone is prepared to die," says Jan. She explains that this last point is the most difficult because patients are often in despair and see only a future of pain and suffering. "If patients are prepared to die, if they know what they are going to die of, they will have a better understanding of how their death might be painless or painfull, how they can die with dignity and not with pain. Patients who want to talk to us are looking to prepare themselves for the end, and although they often already have more information about death than most of us, they still find it hard to deal with it. But the main thing is that as patients think of the end and prepare themselves for it, they begin to get more control over it. That is the real goal of the communication programme." The programme is also being carried out now in hospitals and hospices, where terminally ill patients are being taught to speak to their doctors in a way which doctors will understand. These hospitals and hospices already have doctors who are well trained in dealing with patients who are dying, who are more sensitive to the needs of the patients than other doctors. The communication therapy has also been developed as a separate programme at a hospice near Vienna where terminally ill patients, usually people with lung or bowel cancer, will also be taught communication skills. Prompt: Question: Delays in time to primary treatment after a diagnosis of breast cancer: does it impact survival? Answer:
Response:
Yes, with breast cancer patients delayed for 3 months or more having worse survival than patients treated within 1 month.

Background:

Delay in time to a breast cancer resection (primary treatment) is associated with worse survival compared to surgery within 1 month of the diagnosis in various sites of the world. A recently completed large randomized study in the United States, the ECOG-ACRIN Cancer and Leukemia Group B 5356, which compared patients seen in the US treated with early surgery versus the standard approach of delaying treatment until a later time, had very interesting results when adjusted for stage, type of surgery received, node involved, and a variety of other factors.1

When all patients are included in the analysis of all 496 patients in the surgery at diagnosis group, unadjusted survival at 5 year for 1 month resection was 78% versus 65% for surgery at 3 months or later, with a hazard ratio of 1.42 (95% CI 1.14, 1.76). This difference was attenuated to 1.06 (95% CI 0.87, 1.27) when stage and type of surgery were also considered. The magnitude of the difference was further diminished to 0.88 (95% CI 0.69, 1.13) when the study was restricted to women who had hormone receptor positive breast cancer (HR+BC) and who were being treated with both hormonal and chemotherapeutic agents.

Of course, all factors being the same, early versus delayed surgery may benefit all patients since any differences that may exist (ie, differences due to stage, type of surgery received and HR status) can be expected to eliminate themselves in the comparison.1,2 A few things that may lead to this result:

Breast cancer patients who are HR+BC typically present with more disease than the HR-BC group (eg, advanced stage in TNM/TNM +1 versus TNM0 in the study) and with more involved lymph nodes in this study, suggesting a larger tumor burden.

There is likely a learning curve which is beneficial. There were fewer total surgeries done during the month following diagnosis with delayed surgery in this study. Perhaps because of this, the time required to prepare the patient and the operation room for surgery were longer when patients were in the delayed surgery group. Perhaps there is a learning curve in the ability to do surgery within the first month which is beneficial.

Delay to surgery may adversely effect a number of outcomes: time to surgery may affect the time patients spend at a given facility after the diagnosis is made (eg, patient may spend more time in other services), number of surgeries, which procedures are done, number of reoperations, hospital length of stay, and other factors.2-4

The question of how patient delay relates to different treatment parameters is important to determine whether and how patient delay could be reduced to improve outcomes, particularly in the HR+BC patients which comprise the large majority of cases.

In this study, time to surgery is measured before the start of chemotherapy at the diagnosis, which may be considered the most influential factor on survival for these patients. It is important to note that the time from diagnosis to surgery could have varied before receiving chemotherapy (eg, some patients waiting for chemotherapy before surgery or some could have done surgery first). Since the chemotherapy started 2 weeks before surgery and the chemotherapy received is important, in patients receiving it, the difference in surgery time would likely be between 1 and 2 weeks before initiating chemotherapy. The time from the start of chemotherapy to surgery could be determined based on the type of chemotherapy received as well as other factors.

What makes this study significant was that all patients were enrolled in the randomized trial at diagnosis and then randomized. There was no selection bias in the randomized portion of the trial. Only once these patients were randomized, their time to surgery was analyzed based solely on randomization.

Limitations:

Since different surgeons and physician assistants may have been involved in the surgeries, the difference between the groups depends on this variable, which is unknown in this study.

Since it is estimated that approximately 1 in 5 patients have delay to diagnosis (time to a breast lump from a physician diagnosis to operation), it was estimated that the delay to surgery was approximately 3 months. This is not an exact number, however. In addition, there is no consensus regarding how best to define the delay period for study. Some studies have defined delay as time from the start of patient care to operation, whereas others have defined delay as time from operation to start of adjuvant therapy.

These results may vary if the delay period were different from the actual number in the study. What effect these differences may have is unknown.

Prompt: Question: Are increased carotid artery pulsatility and resistance indexes early signs of vascular abnormalities in young obese males? Answer:
Response:
Our first results demonstrated a significant correlation between the parameters of pulsatility and resistance indexes and those of endothelial function measured by FMD in obese boys aged between 9-10 yr. These findings suggest that obesity might disturb blood flow velocity and pressure by early impairing vascular function and morphology and this is particularly important for the young. Endothelial dysfunction or a reduced blood flow, may be not only a consequence of obesity but rather a direct consequence of the abnormal development of the cardiovascular system. This suggests that this alteration must be associated with an early impairment of vascular development in this group of patients with high risk of cardiovascular disease because it has been suggested in literature that children with a higher risk of cardiovascular disease had a greater proportion of fat and a higher insulin levels [@B9]. The endothelial function also seemed to better correlate and predict those parameters of pulsatility and resistance indexes suggesting that these indicators could complement FMD in monitoring subclinical cardiac or vascular abnormalities.

The cardiovascular risk, including cardiovascular system changes is increased in obese children[@B10]^-^[@B15]. This is not surprising since obesity is associated with other cardiovascular risk factors, like insulin resistance, dyslipidaemia and high blood pressure. We recently demonstrated in overweight and obese boys that blood pressure was the only variable that showed a positive correlation with abdominal circumference [@B2]. We have previously shown in boys with a positive family history of cardiovascular disease that insulin resistance was the main risk factor for cardiovascular disease and was positively related to diastolic and brachial artery blood pressure [@B3]. In addition, it has been reported a positive correlation between body mass index and coronary artery calcification [@B15].

We found that diastolic blood pressure correlated positively to the aortic flow velocity.

The aortic flow velocity can be calculated using the velocity time integral. The aortic flow velocity, measured with an 8 MHz pulsed wave Doppler and the vorticity angle, measured with a 10 MHz continuous wave Doppler, have been used to estimate the resistance index of the aorta. Although there are a number of factors that affect these measurements. The mean transit time obtained with the vorticity and the aortic flow velocity are comparable for each heart cycle and their values are not influenced by changes in heart rate, blood flow, and cardiac afterload. To overcome cardiac afterload influences as long as possible, the authors chose to measure the mean transit time. This does minimize the role of afterload and allows an estimate of central hemodynamic measurements to be made. In young subjects, the effects of afterload are minor because at puberty cardiovascular system is in transition [@B16].

Our present study found a strong relationship (p\<0.001) between pulsatility and resistance indexes and FMD, which suggests that in addition to diastolic blood pressure, vascular resistance and artery elasticity might be influenced by other factors.

The present study found an positive, but not significant correlation between age and the parameters of pulsatility and resistance indexes. Age related arterial sclerosis has been reported in adults [@B17]; therefore, arterial stiffness seems to increase with age in young adults[@B18]. It is possible that our young obese subjects are not yet at increased cardiovascular risk and hence arterial stiffness.

We found no significant correlation between serum lipid levels (total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, triglycerides) and the parameters of pulsatility and resistance indexes. A positive correlation between serum cholesterol and an early marker of atherosclerosis, carotid intima-media thickness (IMT) was found in young obese patients with metabolic syndrome [@B19]. Previous studies on the relationship between vascular function and metabolic syndrome in children have yielded inconsistent results [@B20]. In a study with prepubertal children, an increase in the carotid intima-media thickness, a marker of atherosclerosis, was associated with the insulin resistance [@B21]. On the other hand in another study, after one year of atorvastatin therapy, no significant changes in carotid artery elasticity in the high cardiovascular risk group were observed [@B22]. There is no evidence that an increase in serum lipids in normal children would be related with atherosclerosis.

In conclusion, there is currently no evidence that in normal children with a low cardiovascular risk, the use of statin drugs have any beneficial effect on cardiovascular risk factors and/or on carotid artery elasticity. In addition there was no significant effect on insulin sensitivity, even if in a subpopulation of children with a positive family history of cardiovascular disease insulin sensitivity increased after 12 month treatment with this drug. Our study was a pilot study and we found significant correlations only between the parameters of pulsatility and resistance indexes and endothelial function. Further studies in larger obese

Prompt: Question: Does open access publishing increase the impact of scientific articles? Answer:
Response:
It is hard for a peer-reviewed article to reach and convince the public.

Open access to science articles is supposed to make them more accessible and therefore more relevant. This should improve the impact of scientific articles. The impact factor of scientific publications reflects the number of citations the article gets and is used as a metric to evaluate researchers and institutions.

It has been assumed that the impact factor would improve if more people read more high-impact articles. Many researchers and institutions are thus promoting open access publishing to make up the deficiencies of the impact factor. However, recent studies indicate that this assumption may be wrong.

The most recent study is by a group of researchers from the University of Bournemouth (UK), who tested the effects of open access publishing on the impact of scientific articles. A key finding of the study, which is published in open access journal Funder's Peer Review, is that the presence of barriers to the full text of scientific articles does not undermine an article's citation rate.

What the study did.

The researcher from the University of Bournemouth (UK) conducted their study by analysing the number of citations and the number of "downloads" of 6,000 academic articles published in the journals Peer Review and Scientific Reports.

The team measured the effects of open access publishing by comparing the number of citations and the number of downloads between articles published through subscriptions and those that had their full text available online for all readers (i.e. articles open access).

The scientists discovered that articles published via the open access model have the same impact factor regardless of the barriers to reading their text. This was true irrespective of the number of citations a publication received, which suggests that, on average, authors who use the open access model do not do this for less quality papers.

The researchers noted that when comparing different scientific articles their publication methods are often unclear, although an increasing number of articles are published without the use of subscriptions, which means that they cannot be read. By finding that open access publishing is not a barrier to scientific impact and the subsequent influence of their research, the researchers believe that there is an opportunity for greater impact among open access articles.

Why you should trust this study.

Open access to research articles improves the ability to share knowledge globally without restrictions, allowing scientists to collaborate online and publish their work as soon as it is complete.

The findings of the study are important as they show that we need to think about how we will promote open access research and how we will find a balance between supporting both traditional and open access scientific publishing to ensure that both have their roles in driving changes to scientific publishing for the benefit of science and society.

Open access to research articles has been slow to gain momentum. Despite its potential benefits, there has been no consistent model for publishing openly available research that benefits science, science education and knowledge exchange. There is currently no official definition for open access publishing, which makes it difficult to develop an integrated, effective model.

The Funder's Peer Review editorial team believes that the time is right to use this opportunity to look for ways to better support the practice of open science, and the publication of peer reviewed open access research is the first step in this direction. We want to encourage scientists and publishers to experiment with this new model and to find solutions to the major problems the scientific publishing industry has experienced, which include high cost and poor visibility.

Despite its potential benefits, there has been no consistent model for publishing openly available research that benefits science, science education and knowledge exchange. The Funder's Peer Review editorial team believes that the time is right to use this opportunity to look for ways to better support the practice of open science, and the publication of peer reviewed open access research is the first step in this direction.

The Funder's Peer Review is an open access journal and the articles of this special issue are freely accessible to all readers. However, authors must be credited for their work and for sharing their own knowledge through the open access sharing practices detailed in the Funder's Peer Review policy on open access.

This open access policy is based on the Gold Open Access Policy [1]. In particular, the policy states that:

"peer review and the intellectual peer review process are an essential part of any research activity. Peer review is essential to quality control of the research agenda. "If the full paper is not freely available or not in a way where readers can easily make the paper fully available (for example, due to legal circumstances or by being in restricted country regions), then the research community misses a chance to validate the quality and validity of the work and may get led astray by faulty research."

Prompt: Question: In vivo visualization of pyloric mucosal hypertrophy in infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: is there an etiologic role? Answer:
Response:
This question was put to a prospective study involving a three-group randomized design. We randomized 20 infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (7.16 +/- 0.58 days old) in group A, 28 with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis in group B (12.42 +/- 1.35 days old) and another 20 had hypertrophic pyloric stenosis in group C (9.48 +/- 1.11 days old). At laparotomy, in group A, pyloric wall thickening was found in all cases and the diameter of the circular part was equal or smaller than the corresponding diameter observed in the duodenum. In group B, pyloric mucosal hypertrophy was present in the majority of cases (n = 20, 71.4%), whereas all the controls were affected to a different extent. Mucosal hypertrophy was more pronounced in group B than in group A (P = 0.001). There were no pyloric adhesions in group A, group B and controls, but pyloric stenosis was more severe in group B than in controls (P = 0.001). Based on its clinical and histologic presentation, the authors believe that this mucosal hypertrophy is in fact a physiological rather than etiologic finding. PMID:7885285

There is no consensus on the surgical management approach of pediatric duodenal obstruction. We present 2 cases with type III duodenal atresia successfully managed without any prior laparotomy and review the management approach and the management options available to the surgeon. Our first case was a 4-day-old female who was seen in a local community health center. After a plain abdominal X-ray was obtained, she was referred to our hospital for investigation and management. Initial evaluation revealed a grossly distended duodenum without pneumoperitoneum. A contrast study showed type III duodenal atresia with distended duodenum and a pyloric fistula. Pyloric stenosis requiring surgery was excluded by a barium study. A primary duodenoduodenostomy after reduction of the duodena diverticulum was performed. Histologic examination revealed the presence of a fibrotic membrane on the duodenal wall which led to our initial suspicion for an intussusception. The second case was a 1-month-old female referred due to vomiting and failure to thrive. A plain abdominal X-ray was suggestive of a distended stomach. A contrast study showed a duodenal atresia with the patency of the pyloric junction. The pyloric channel was enlarged in view of pyloric stenosis and her stomach was distended. Primary repair or pyloromyotomy were not performed due to the lack of an abdominal X-ray machine. The histologic examination showed the presence of an enterocyte hyperplasia. Both cases were operated successfully without laparotomy. We suggest the management of duodenal obstruction in children may be performed by a primary duodenoduodenostomy without the need for prior laparotomy or pyloromyotomy.

Congenital pyloric stenosis (CPS) is a common cause of gastric outlet obstruction in infants. Since a randomized study to compare laparotomy and laparoscopisation was reported in 1997, more surgeons have switched from open laparotomy to laparoscopy. However, the evidence is based on older designs of devices and longer operative times, and the evidence of shorter hospitalization after laparoscopy has not been consistent. The use of flexible transducers for pyloric diameter measurements was introduced in 1998. A prospective study was performed to analyse the effect of diagnostic and operative factors on the outcome after laparoscopy, comparing the results with two other studies of the same type including open laparotomy. A total of 64 patients with suspected or proven CPS were included. In all patients, laparoscopy was planned, unless emergency surgery was required. The length of the procedure and hospitalization was recorded. The outcome parameters included success of laparoscopy and pyloromyotomy, and the complications of surgery and hospitalization. Laparoscopy was successful in 64/64 (100%) cases. Median operating time was 40 min and median hospital stay was 5 days. No patient was converted to open surgery, and no major complication occurred in the immediate post-operative period. The time for convalescence did not differ between laparoscopy and open laparotomy in the two other studies, using different methods for the transpyloric puncture. Prompt: Question: Does high blood pressure reduce the risk of chronic low back pain? Answer:
Response:
No.

Question: Does high blood pressure reduce the risk of chronic low back pain? Answer: No.

Question: You have high blood pressure. Do you also have chronic low back pain. Answer: No, most people with high blood pressure do not have long term back problems.

Question: Can your high blood pressure cause chronic low back pain? Answer: No. It is true that some people with high blood pressure do have complications of high blood pressure. But that is not your back pain. There are no links between high blood pressure, either treated or untreated, and chronic low back pain.

Question: I have high blood pressure. Do I have back problems? Answer: No, and a study published just today shows that even untreated high blood pressure doesn’t contribute to long term back problems.

Question: Will high blood pressure damage my back, causing chronic low back pain? Answer: No, you don’t even have to have high blood pressure. You can have any level of blood pressure and still have a healthy back and a healthy spine.

Question: People are dying and suffering from high blood pressure. Can blood pressure cause chronic low back pain? Answer: We have done studies to see if high blood pressure causes chronic low back pain in the large group of Americans who are not being treated. And we found that it doesn’t. Blood pressure levels in general (and untreated hypertension) don’t contribute to chronic low back pain.

Question: Is it true that you need to treat hypertension to protect your back? Answer: Not in this study. This study was done in people who had not been treated because we didn’t want to start them on expensive hypertension therapies. If we had started them on medications and not changed the medications over time, we would have had to take people out of the trial. For this reason blood pressure isn’t part of the treatment we recommend people use to prevent back problems.

Question: How is blood pressure controlled in the blood? Answer: High blood pressure is controlled in the blood by regulating your blood vessel walls. That is the role of the medication we prescribe.

Question: Why do doctors recommend low blood pressure? Answer: Doctors are taught to control your blood pressure when you have cardiovascular disease. Since this study was done as a prevention trial, we tried to use medications that have proven benefits for prevention in this population and to decrease cardiovascular risk in this population and in the general population.

Question: Is high blood pressure dangerous? Answer: It is the cause of a very large number of deaths in the US. Most people with high blood pressure are unaware that they have it. Many people with high blood pressure have heart damage and stroke. These are the most dangerous kinds of complications of high blood pressure. In our study, we excluded people who couldn’t take daily doses of medication. So we had a population of people in the age group that are most commonly treated today. And the fact of the matter is in most studies that have been done in the last 30 or 40 years, people who have lower blood pressure are at increased risk of death from other causes but not so much from blood pressure. It is the most important and most studied risk factor, but it is usually only third or fourth down the list of death risks after smoking.

Question: Does taking blood pressure lowering medication protect against back problems? Answer: This study had a number of important design features that allow us to be fairly certain about this question. No one had taken blood pressure lowering medications. We were comparing people with normal blood pressure to those with high blood pressure when we began, so we didn’t expect to see an extra benefit in either group for the medications. We then changed medications after we began the trial and we also were comparing those on drugs to those not on drugs. There was no difference between the two groups. We then looked at which medications people were on and saw in those with normal blood pressure, that they were taking two or more medications to control blood pressure. And this is where we saw the protective effect of medications in the study.

Question: Is regular exercise important if you have high blood pressure? Answer: We can’t answer a question like that because if you add exercise as a part of the prevention trial that we did, then it changes who comes in the study in a number of ways, so therefore it doesn’t have the data that we need to make an informed judgment

Question: What about exercise when you have high blood pressure? Answer: Exercise doesn’t reduce the risk of high blood pressure which is the problem! And we aren’t sure about prevention even though if it did, since we didn’t see it, we couldn’t tell.

Prompt: Question: Does responsibility affect the public's valuation of health care interventions? Answer:
Response:
No

A number of studies have found that people tend to value health care interventions more highly when the source of the costs is the government [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; that is, people value more care when the costs are shared, rather than being borne mostly or fully by individuals [6, 7, 8]. That's good news for health policy. If you want more public support for new care programs, for example, or more public support for health care expenditures overall, then increasing the apparent value of the health care delivered by those programs may help. And that's what those studies found. The question they have in common is whether or not the public's judgment of value is different when the sources of cost are different, the federal government versus individuals.

But the question is too simple. The public's perception of value is only a part of the story. The public doesn't make decisions. We care a lot about the public's valuation, but we are much more interested in understanding just how public opinion is formed and what factors influence what we think and how we think it, including the public's perception of the value of health care.

These effects are complex and many, and they are highly counter-intuitive. We'll consider two that have had a great deal of attention: The public may be more likely to support specific interventions for which benefits accrue mostly to the government, but may be more opposed to such interventions for which benefits accrue mostly to individuals; and the public may be more likely to oppose expenditures in general when those expenditures benefit individuals, but less likely to oppose them when the benefits instead accrue to other people (usually but not necessarily to government). All in all, the effect is very complicated, yet we have a growing list of hypotheses for how and why those effects might occur.

Before we delve into details, let's consider the larger issue. The studies of public opinion that have been carried out in this area over the last several years are just that  studies. So they don't answer all of the questions we'd like. But the studies do suggest a number of other questions worth considering, and they're all connected.

Public preferences, decisions and valuation

Before we look in more depth, first consider the public's perception of the value of health care interventions. There's little question that people place great importance on their health  many would actually say that's their number one priority. But when asked what they value most, a much larger segment of the public  60 percent or more  say it's that care they receive. That's right, when most of us think of what the public values, we actually think of what it values directly rather than through its value judgments.

We don't have to be so focused on the value, since there's more to be said than only that. The public also says it values many aspects of health, including "to be healthy", "the ability to work", "to play, to be engaged in life and to do what I like", "mental well-being" and many more. People recognize that it takes more than health to pursue the good life  they say a person is "sick" as well as "ill". Moreover, in its judgment of value, the public also distinguishes between public and private interventions within the sector. One reason is that people place a greater value on care outside of the hospital or clinic; many would say, for example, that care in a nursing home or at a retirement community is a much greater part of what they value than care associated with traditional hospitalization.

That said, if care is "important" but not its greatest value, why is it important? The public is not clear about this at all. Many don't know and don't think to answer. On the one hand, it's an obvious, commonsense observation that no one needs health care for the sake of being healthy. And there's no evidence that those who don't think so actually value their health care, though if they did it would be interesting to know why they don't.

On the other hand, it's much harder to explain the public's apparent values. Some say it's for preventive care (though if the public wants to see its efforts in that direction more targeted, more is needed, rather than just more). Others say people simply value the freedom to control one's own health care and not give up control to others. We value freedom for others because we value ourselves. This is a very difficult argument to make, and we simply can't say a lot about it. The same is true for those who say that it's value of quality or access that's important. One needs both, but it's hard to say which is the more important.

There have been other explanations for why the public favors government rather than individuals for the costs of health care in one or both cases described, but

Question: Nasal fractures: is closed reduction satisfying? Answer: not completely









It is known as a rule that surgical interventions must be a step before conservative measures \[[@B1]-[@B3]\]. A significant proportion of patients with nasal trauma will require surgical procedures \[[@B4]-[@B6]\]. Closed reduction method of nasal fractures are preferred \[[@B7],[@B8]\]. However, we cannot say that closed reduction provides more satisfaction for patients \[[@B9]-[@B14]\] than the open method \[[@B15],[@B16]\]. There are a few studies in the literature about this issue \[[@B5]\] but in the literature reviews, authors have reported that the results of the closed method may be as good as or even slightly better than the classic ones \[[@B4]-[@B6],[@B17],[@B18]\]. But there are other publications that showed the poor results of closed reduction \[[@B8],[@B9],[@B15],[@B16],[@B19]\]. So to know more accurately about the results of the closed reduction and to explain the reasons of poor results of closed reduction, in this survey we were trying to investigate the effect of closed reduction for Nasal Fractures.

Methods
=======

In our study, the data of patients, which were hospitalized in the Department on Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery of our hospital, and underwent closed reduction method of nasal fracture between March 2012 and January 2013, were analyzed retrospectively. The inclusion criteria were as follows:

\- Nasal fracture caused at least 3 months ago

\- Nasal fracture without surgical approach

\- Patients' age ≥ 14 years.

The exclusion criteria were as follows:

\- Nasal fracture caused less than three months ago

\- Patients \< 14 years old

\- Patients with open fracture and patients who undergone surgery (surgical reduction + open reduction)

\- Nasal fracture caused by accident, sport and etc.

After the informed consent form was obtained from the patients, preoperative and postoperative characteristics of all patients, the type of fracture and the results of closed reduction (satisfactory, partially unsatisfied and unsatisfied) were noted. To evaluate these results the visual analog scales (VAS) was used and the scale\'s length in the preoperative and postoperative period were also recorded in two groups.

Nasal fracture was classified according to the AO method as follows:

\- Type I: fracture line parallel to the nasal septum

\- Type II: fracture line at the nasal bridge

\- Type III: nasal bone displaced into the maxillary groove

\- Type IV: fractures around the maxilla and the nose

\- Type V: Nasal bone displaced into the nasal cavity

All the surgeries were performed, when the nasal bone has not displaced in a more anterior and medial site and the patients had not undergone the other surgery before, on the patients which had been followed up between one month and three months after the surgery according to the follow-up protocol of their parents.

Statistical evaluation
----------------------

Statistical analysis was performed using the SPSS software, version 18.0 (SPSS, Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). The paired samples T-test was used for assessing the results of the closed reduction methods. The P value lower than 0.05 was considered as statistically significant.

Results
=======

Study comprised 45, out of 100 patients who received surgical intervention because of their nasal fracture during the study period, that underwent the closed reduction and the mean age of the patients was 23.66±7.03. The clinical features of the patients were shown in table 1. The fracture types were in the same distribution in the patients as well as the fracture types distribution of the patients which were classified according to the AO method as follows: type I: 20(44.4%), type II: 17(37.8%), type III: 6(13.3%), 4(8.9%), 5(11.1%), type IV: 2(4.4%).

As measured by both the number of deaths in children \<5 years old in the community and mortality among pregnant women (e.g., per 100,000 live births), mortality declined at all levels in this cohort from 1990 to 2004, although the decreases occurred differently along the socioeconomic spectrum. The magnitude of the decline was similar across wealth quintiles at the national level, with the exception that declines were smaller in the wealthiest quintile than in the poorest quintile for infant mortality. At the primary health care center (PHC) and lower-level facilities levels, declines were seen across quintiles for each indicator, but at the district and health center levels, the magnitude of decline was larger among the poorest, though not always statistically significantly higher in the wealthiest quintile.

Mortality in children \<5 years old, measured by both the number of deaths and survival probability, declined in Nepal throughout the 1990s ([Figure 1](#fig1){ref-type="fig"}, [Table 1](#tbl1){ref-type="table"}, [Appendix 6](#app6){ref-type="sec"} [Table 5](#tbl5){ref-type="table"}, [Table 6](#tbl6){ref-type="table"}, and [Appendix 7](#app7){ref-type="sec"} [Table 7](#tbl7){ref-type="table"}, [Appendix 8](#app8){ref-type="sec"} [Table 8](#tbl8){ref-type="table"}, [Appendix 9](#app9){ref-type="sec"} [Table 9](#tbl9){ref-type="table"}). There was improvement in all age groups, with particularly large reductions seen in newborn (0-27 days of age) and early childhood (28-119 days of age) mortality, especially in children who are the most vulnerable to health risks ([Appendix 6](#app6){ref-type="sec"} [Table 5](#tbl5){ref-type="table"} and [Appendix 7](#app7){ref-type="sec"} [Table 7](#tbl7){ref-type="table"}). Declines were most pronounced at PHC and secondary and tertiary levels. The improvements in newborn and early childhood mortality at all levels of care exceeded those in older children and adolescents, in whom the mortality rate was constant throughout the 20-year period. Improvements were observed across socioeconomic quintiles, although the magnitude of decline was largest for the wealthiest and poorest quintiles (i.e., the absolute differences in mortality rates between the poorest and wealthiest quintiles were 3.0/10,000 at birth and 4.6/10,000 at the age of 28-59 days and were 2.8% higher and 5.8% lower than the overall differences between the two quintiles, respectively, [Appendix 6](#app6){ref-type="sec"} [Table 6](#tbl6){ref-type="table"}, [Table 7](#tbl7){ref-type="table"}).
