Prompt: Question: Does spontaneous remission occur in polyarteritis nodosa? Answer:
Response:
It is extremely difficult to state whether remission can occur in patients with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), because no studies that directly address the issue as primary outcome variable are available. But remission may occur in PAN patients with polyneuropathy \[[@B1]\] as a complication of PAN \[[@B2]\].

Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by necrotizing necrosis of small- and medium-size arteries in various organs, including the skin, the muscles, and the organs inside the digestive tract \[[@B3]\]. Most PAN patients develop cutaneous lesions such as livedo reticularis, erythema nodosum, Gottron\'s papules, and papulovesicles on the face, scalp, extremities, and trunk \[[@B4]\].

PAN is often associated with fever, headache, abdominal pain, renal involvement, myalgia, muscle weakness, and neurologic dysfunction. There is a good evidence that PAN may lead to gastrointestinal disorders such as anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, and constipation. There is a high prevalence of polyneuropathy that was first recognized by Coomb \[[@B5]\]. Neuropathy occurs in up to 98 percent of patients with PAN \[[@B6]\]. Polyneuropathy usually starts with distal leg weakness and sensory impairment and progresses to sensorimotor impairment affecting the hands, feet, and arms. There is evidence for both inflammatory destruction of myelin or axon sheaths and the vasculitis that results in necrotizing arterial lesions of the sensory and sympathetic paravertebral nerves \[[@B7]\]. The association of necrotizing polyneuropathy and PAN has been shown to be a characteristic feature of the disease \[[@B8]\].

There is increasing evidence that inflammatory disease and its effects on the nervous system are often influenced, even controlled, by the nervous system. Therefore the concept of systemic vasculitis as a \'systemic autoimmunity\' has important implications \[[@B9]\]. It has recently been argued that \'patients with polyartheritis are prone to develop other diseases from systemic autoimmunity, whereas it is unclear whether the opposite occurs \[[@B10]\]. In the last 30 years, several studies have examined the incidence and significance of systemic manifestations of vasculitis.

Some authors conclude from the data reported, that there appear to be many systemic manifestations associated with PAN, including headache, abdominal pain, arthritis, renal disease, and renal amyloidosis. Aneurysms, venous thromboses, pulmonary hemorrhage and other pulmonary diseases seem to be particularly common. In rare instances, PAN may affect the heart \[[@B10]\].

The prevalence of PAN has increased steadily during the past 40 years, and the incidence is much higher in men. In fact, approximately 40 to 50% of patients have renal disease and approximately 20 to 30% of patients have neurological involvement \[[@B11]\]. There is strong evidence that PAN is a polygenic autosomal dominant condition with incomplete penetrance. The increased prevalence and severity in men possibly reflects environmental and hormonal factors \[[@B12]\], possibly related to vascular effects of sex steroids and sex-related proinflammatory cytokines, and possibly immune regulation \[[@B12]\].

In the initial diagnosis of PAN, an early diagnosis is especially important. The diagnosis is based on a typical clinical presentation and supportive laboratory and histological findings. The clinical and immunological presentation does not allow any final differentiation between PAN of PAN and mixed periarteritis nodosa. For this reason, the diagnosis of PAN has been extended to patients with PAN with a wide spectrum of systemic manifestations and renal insufficiency with or without neurological features. Laboratory findings in PAN may show an elevated sedimentation rate, a marked increase of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate with or without leukocytosis, an increased level of C-reactive protein, increased creatinine phosphokinase and lactulose and methyl-sulfonyl-urea. Histological findings in PAN are segmental, transmural necrosis of medium-sized arteries with the formation of leukocytic microthrombi. These findings are typical for PAN \[[@B13],[@B14]\].

It is not clear if different patterns of PAN exist, the most significant being between PAN with renal disease and PAN with polyneuropathy with or without renal involvement. Since there are many treatment regimens for PAN, the prognostic outcome of the treatment can only be judged by the course of the disease. From the pathophysiological point of view it is reasonable to explain the course of PAN from an immunological and a vascular point of view.

Prompt: Question: Gluten tolerance in adult patients with celiac disease 20 years after diagnosis? Answer:
Response:
Yes, it's very common! In this interview with Dr. Alessio Fasano, I ask him many questions about celiac disease, gluten sensitivity, potential risks with gluten free diet, and possible non-celiac gluten sensitivity that is out there.

In our interview with Dr. Fasano, we discuss:

- Are there differences in immune system response (humoral and epithelial) in the celiac diagnosis in children compared to adults?

- Does the gluten free diet impact the general health of the patients since it was described with gluten sensitivity? Which is the connection with celiac disease?

- Does gluten free diet have any impact on the non-celiac gluten sensitivity?

- Do we know the real risk of the gluten free diet for the patients? Is it worth it?

A: As we all mentioned in my last interview, gluten (i.e. wheat protein) intolerance is a spectrum of patients from those that have sensitivity to gluten or celiac disease, but are non-celiac gluten sensitivity, to those who are celiac without gluten sensitivity (or non-celiac celiac). And there is no doubt that the gluten free diet is the best way to follow for all of the people. It is very important thing to know more about gluten and the relation between non-celiac gluten sensitivity and celiac disease.

A: We do know that patients who have gluten sensitivity have a higher prevalence of celiac disease and more severe and active celiac disease than healthy individuals or individuals with non-celiac gluten sensitivity or non-celiac celiac disease. But there are several questions regarding how we should classify these individuals, which is called “gliadin”, “peptides”, or “wheat protein”-related immunotoxic gluten-related disorders. The other question is whether there could be a link between non-celiac food hypersensitivity and celiac disease or vice versa. For me, non-celiac gluten sensitivity is part of the spectrum of celiac disease. What is the effect of gluten-free diet on these individuals? We don’t know yet. I agree in the idea that, most likely, there is a real risk for gluten to cause some negative side-effects. This risk should be more defined and not overrated when we introduce gluten-free foods in the population.

Q: So, all the people who have celiac disease or gluten sensitivity should stick to a gluten-free diet and not have an alternative?

A: The gluten free diet is important for the disease. But we have some concerns about the current guidelines of GF diet. They could not provide clear explanation of how the diet should be. They are not describing all of the foods that are allowed by the diet as they are suggesting, but they have a wide variety of foods that could be included for the GF diet. When we follow those guidelines, it is very difficult to avoid the contact with gluten and to know if the GF diet is really gluten free or if one could have some gluten with every meals. A clear definition of the foods that could be gluten free would be important, but also the food diary in the clinical follow up of each patient and to know if the patient is consuming something that could be included in her/his diet.

Q: We think there are some risks with gluten free food, it may have some adverse effects for the patient. What are the main adverse reactions with gluten free food?

A: The main adverse reaction with the gluten free diet is the quality of the gluten free products. The current GF products have many ingredients that we should avoid, but there are some which are not in gluten free products and may be helpful to avoid such as:

· Ferrous sulphate or fumaric acid,

· Fructose,

· Glutamates,

· Potassium citrate,

· Potassium sorbate,

· Saccharides,

· Sucrose,

· Yeast.

Q: What about celiac disease with non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Could there be a connection between their symptoms and not the real celiac disease but gluten? Could it be a “pseudo-celiac disease”?

A: It is very rare, but could be possible that a non-celiac gluten sensitivity is the cause for some patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity.

Q: Another one question: Is there a link of non-celiac gluten sensitivity with mental disorders and psychiatric diseases, such as obsessive-compulsive, tic, or some types of depression?

A: Maybe a link with the gluten free diet, and not the specific symptoms or disorders, but a gluten free diet

In a large cross-sectional survey of 1595 current and former smokers aged over 55 years followed for an average of 5.5 years, individuals with symptoms had nearly twice the risk of a diagnosis of COPD than those without such symptoms.

Objective: To determine the impact of postbronchodilator FEV1 (<70% predicted) on the progression of emphysema in the lungs of heavy smokers, to determine if any association exists between emphysema severity, airflow obstruction severity, symptom status, or exercise capacity.

Analysis of Emphysema Progression

Methods: Between 1996 and 2001, 1,096 current smokers (mean age, 62 years; 830 men) without emphysema were enrolled in a 3-year clinical trial, underwent screening pulmonary function tests, chest computed tomography before and after salbutamol inhalation, and performed a 6min walk test at baseline. The subjects were followed up every 15 months with pulmonary function tests, 6min walk tests, and chest computed tomography scans. The severity of emphysema was scored by a 6-point visual scale. The relationship between emphysema progression and airway obstruction severity and individual lung function parameters at baseline was assessed by analysis of covariance.

Results: The prevalence of emphysema was 26% at baseline and 41% at the end of the 3-year period of follow-up. After controlling for baseline symptom status, FEV1, residual volume, and severity of obstruction, the emphysema volume score progressed at a rate of 4.3 mm3 per year (95% confidence interval, 1.8-6.8 mm3 per year; P=.004 on a linear trend test). In patients with emphysema, progression of emphysema correlated weakly with baseline airflow obstruction severity (adjusted mean change in emphysema volume score per 10% predicted decrease in FEV1, 7.0 mm3; 95% confidence interval, 1.7-11.4 mm3).

Conclusions: Postbronchodilator FEV1 and baseline symptoms predict progression of emphysema in heavy smokers and suggest that severity of disease could be predicted prior to smoking cessation. Patients with COPD are at increased risk for developing emphysema, irrespective of symptomatic status at the initiation of smoking cessation.

Inhalation of tobacco smoke is an important risk factor in the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).1 This multisystem disorder, also recognized as chronic airflow limitation syndrome,2 is a common disease with an estimated prevalence of 18.7 million worldwide,3 accounting for 1.42 million of the total disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs) lost.4 Although smoking cessation is a proven strategy, many smokers report a lack of motivation to quit or report residual symptoms related to smoking after 6 months or more of abstinence.3,5

Emphysema and COPD share several features, including airflow limitation by small airway disease.6 However, the risk and clinical consequences of the development of post-bronchodilator airflow obstruction and emphysema are less clear and may depend on the severity of airflow obstruction at baseline.7,8

There is limited evidence regarding the risk of emphysema developing in cigarette smokers who have milder degrees of airflow obstruction at baseline.7,8 To assess emphysema progression, we previously used a visual score (0-6) to quantify the area of emphysema in lung computed tomography (CT) imaging studies taken before and after inhalation of bronchodilator.9 Using a method of quantitative emphysema assessment that has been validated against histograph measures of pulmonary emphysema, we sought to test whether the presence of symptom-related COPD can predict the progression of emphysema in heavy smokers who have milder degrees of airflow obstruction at baseline.

Prompt: Question: Search engine as a diagnostic tool in difficult immunological and allergologic cases: is Google useful? Answer:
Response:
It is very useful {#sec1}
===================================================================================================================================

The question arises if the results of a 'google' search for an unknown diagnosis can be useful. At the present time, this information is available and can be used, depending also of the quality or speed of the search, as additional information for the clinicians; besides that, this information is always easy to be used because the whole world can be searched, thus, providing a great amount of data and information.

This type of question is very important in areas such as immunopathology of unknown causes, diagnostics of autoimmune diseases or for which there can be no diagnosis at the final stage, and others. With this type of cases as a starting point it seems possible to use our experience and knowledge in the area.

Google itself is a search engine and has its own results, which means that some search engines are better at retrieving information about your query than others.

We started to be very aware of that at an early stage, and over the years we found that not all the results in the first pages of Google on our query were clinically relevant.

In the immunopathology of unknown causes, an important part of the answers could have been more easily found in PubMed and its database PubMed Central (PMC), as an alternative to Google, or in national (or European) search databases in addition to PubMed search databases (in Italy we have the site of [RomeNet.it](http://rome-net.it)).

The difficulty is that Google is the place where many doctors go to search for an answer to their questions (the top 10 results are, as a rule, those most frequently used) and this explains much of the increase of the number of doctor consultations ([@bib1]). Besides, its popularity is above all for its simplicity and speed of use, and of course also the fact that it is free and very often used by people who lack information about a topic. What we are now looking for in immunopathology is a balance between the speed of information about new advances obtained by us in less time compared with the national or European databases, with a level of risk of missing more relevant information and relevant results.

The challenge for the doctors is to understand that the results in the top search will only rarely contain the best answers to their specific questions. They should also be aware that one does not always need complete answers, because Google results could themselves be part of the problem and could contain very relevant and useful information.

Google helps us to learn. For this reason, we were pleased to find several interesting tools on the first pages that have a significant diagnostic or therapeutic impact. However, at this point of our investigation, it seems preferable to use all the available sources of information and then to take a decision on how much to trust the results.

It is worth pointing out once again that there is an important difference between using a search engine and using a search engine that does not have the information you want.

For example, with a search engine 'Yahoo', you would go to a website and search for a word or phrase, for example, the results of your query will be given in the home section where at the very beginning of the results will be found the news pages and the results of your query are in the first position of these news. There is no way you can enter information about the page you want from which the best search engine.

In summary, we can say that Google is certainly useful if the answers can be found more quickly and easily than with other search engines. We are therefore forced to make a decision based on the experience the user has or on the information of the other databases. If we try to solve this question today only through Google searches, we will be forced to accept a level of risk when it comes to important information missing or useless results. From our experience, it seems best to have a combination of these two solutions with a more detailed review of the results at different levels in a search to obtain the most relevant answers to our diagnostic question.

Diagnosis in unclear or unknown diseases {#sec2}
========================================

It is now evident that the best diagnosis is based on a multidisciplinary and integrative approach that combines clinical, analytical, radiological and histological data. Even immunological tests are only part of an overall diagnosis and are a way of describing a complex set of phenomena whose real value is in helping to build up an hypothesis to solve the diagnostic question. At the end of this process based on many possible, often difficult or complex procedures, the choice of a correct diagnosis is one of the most difficult tasks facing a clinician and pathologist.

Prompt: Question: Uniformity of evidence-based treatments in practice? Answer:
Response:
Not for all clinical questions.
The need for and utilization of evidence-based medicine (EBM) is increasing in the world, as it has a direct impact on public health and resources. The use of EBM has led to the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs), to support and promote EBM and thereby, also to maximize the efficient use of healthcare resources. Some authors believe that EBM leads to a reduction in inappropriate use of drugs, as well as unnecessary side effects and mortality and thus, its adoption has improved patient outcomes. However, more recent studies suggest there may be some shortcomings in the application of EBM, as it may not always provide uniform recommendations for all clinical questions. To address this question, a literature search for CPGs published in 2014 was undertaken using PubMed and the websites of national professional societies. Studies in which more than one CPG were included were then excluded. Forty-four CPGs were included. A total of 41 questions were identified. One question was found to have a broad CPG definition that could not be matched to a single drug treatment question. Another three CPGs did not have a drug treatment question in isolation. For the remaining 36 clinical questions, seven common themes were noted: safety; efficacy, effectiveness, cost-effectiveness; and use of medications in pregnancy, neonates, and pediatrics. It is evident that most questions have uniform recommendations regarding drug treatments, although for two key questions, the guidelines varied: use of inhaled corticosteroids in young children to prevent and treat early childhood wheezing and bronchopulmonary dysplasia, and use in pregnancy to prevent respiratory syncytial virus infection in pregnant women. For another two key questions, there was only one guideline on one topic, which varied to an extent: the use of metronidazole in preterm labor and delivery, and the first-line option between tetracycline and doxycycline for rickettsial prophylaxis. Overall, there was uniformity in the recommendations for the majority of drug treatments, though there were some guidelines that did not recommend for or against a treatment, or did not agree on an effective antibiotic regimen. In conclusion, this review suggests that for the vast majority of questions related to drug treatments, more evidence is needed for appropriate recommendations to support uniformity of care.

Prompt: Question: Do approved doctors and medical referees in the UK agree when assessing a seafarer's fitness? Answer:
Response:
Not yet!

What to look for in a seafarer's fitness assessment





On 1st April 2012, the Health and Safety Executive, (HSE), in close cooperation with the Health and Safety Advisory Council (HSAC) issued a report to “further improve safety at sea by ensuring that seafarers have a safe working environment when employed by any person carrying out work on a ship or craft in the UK’s Merchant Marine or any similar maritime employment”. This Report, which sets out the scope and objectives for further work in this area of UK law, is known as the HSE Maritime Report and forms part of the HSE Maritime Safety and Environmental Policy Strategy 2011-2016.

The introduction to the report states:



“…this report is a significant step to further improve safety at sea by ensuring that all seafarers have a safe working environment when employed by any person carrying out work on a ship or craft in the UK’s public territorial waters, and that any person employing a seafarer is responsible for providing the appropriate level of safety training for the seafarer to ensure that the seafarer is appropriately prepared to carry out any work.”

On 3rd May 2011, an agreement was reached between the HSE and the Ship Inspectorate and Ship Inspectors National Committee and with the support of HSAC. This agreement formed part of the UK Coastguard National Agreement 2010 – 2016. The agreement states:

“The Health and Safety Executive (the HSE) and the Health and Safety Advisory Council for the Civil Aviation and Shipping industries agree that all persons (including licensed and approved medical referees) employed by registered employers carrying out work in the UK’s territorial waters who have responsibility for the safety or health of seafarers should hold appropriate training and a satisfactory knowledge of the appropriate medical conditions and illnesses”

The ‘National Agreement’ further specifies that: “Covered persons should carry appropriate life saving and swimming certification.”

The introduction to this report mentions the fact that it “…follows a decision by the HSE to adopt this statement of common understanding as the applicable standards to the maritime industry in England, Scotland and Wales in accordance with the UK Coastguard National Agreement 2010-2016”.

In respect of the agreement, the HSE stated:

“Following the HSE’s adoption of a “common understanding” statement of the National Agreement 2010-2016 which sets out, on a national basis, standards to be applied to the medical, fitness and drug testing of workers carrying out work in the UK’s territorial waters, this statement will now apply to those working in the UK’s territorial waters in all jurisdictions, including in Great Britain, including Northern Ireland, The Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, the Republic of Ireland, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, in which there are no legal constraints, other than those related to the maritime law.”

There is no official approval date for this statement of common understanding. However, the HSE states that it “will be used by all HSE enforcement offices in England, Wales and Northern Ireland…” and “There will be no immediate change to the enforcement of the legislation and guidance”.

The ‘common understanding’ statement of the ‘National Agreement’ also appears to cover the whole of the UK, not just England and Wales. However, the UK is split into four different territorial sea area as shown in image A, below.

These are the English Channel, the North Sea, the Irish Sea and the Western English Channel.

The Agreement states in part:

“All covered persons who are employed by registered employers carrying out work in the UK's territorial seas should hold appropriate (life saving and swimming) certification and (if under the minimum age at sea) appropriate (medical and fitness) certification in accordance with Appendix D of the National Agreement 2010.”

According to the HSE,

The introduction of this statement into UK law forms part of the HSE Maritime Policy Strategy 2010-11, with an objective to: “Ensure the appropriate provision of medical examination and drug testing for seafarers so that the health and safety of seafarers can be improved”

In respect of the above, the HSE further states the following:

“The purpose of the HSE Memorandum of Understanding, as set out in the HSE Maritime Policy Strategy 2010-11, of “To encourage the responsible management of health and safety in all aspects of the maritime industry (including a commitment to undertake regular audit, review and improvement of health and safety management in the maritime industry in order to achieve a continuously high and sustained level of health and safety”, should be achieved in line with

Question: What is Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS)? How can the diagnosis be confirmed and distinguished from other causes of liver failure that mimic HRS?

Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS): what is HRS? Is HRS always associated with cancer? Is HRS always associated with a specific cancer?

Answer: HRS is associated with malignant disease in about 80% of cases diagnosed. Of patients with HRS, about 10% have concomitant hepatorenal syndrome of the hepatopulmonary type and 10% have concomitant hepatorenal syndrome of the neurohumoral type; these groups overlap. Almost 40% of patients with HRS have no known active malignancies (i.e., they have no known systemic cancer).

HRS is defined as acute renal dysfunction (or failure) occurring in conjunction with liver damage and is the consequence of profound liver insufficiency due to a variety of other causes. Since HRS is a syndrome, diagnosis is not based on any single disease or single factor. The liver may be inflamed as a result of viral infection (hepatitis), tumor, or toxic injury, among others. The kidney is injured as a result of renal vasoconstriction and hypoperfusion. This leads to decreased filtration of blood and, ultimately, acute renal failure. Hepatorenal syndrome is one of the most striking findings of liver disease, as exemplified in [Figure 1](#fig1){ref-type="fig"}.

The following are some clinical variables to consider: elevated levels of serum creatinine, oliguria, increased arterial blood pressure, and low urine volume in the absence of a urinary tract obstruction. In the vast majority of cases, a rapid decrease in the hepatic production of coagulation factors occurs. In about 30% of cases, a severe coagulopathy is established quickly. A rapid hepatic-cell dysfunction results from acute or chronic liver diseases.

As a generalization of the definition of HRS, it is said that HRS is "diagnosed when a combination of three elements (hepatic dysfunction, renal dysfunction, and increased plasma B-type natriuretic peptide levels) exist in a patient with advanced liver disease who is at a high risk of hepatorenal syndrome" \[11\]. More often, however, a syndrome is diagnosed when acute renal failure occurs in conjunction with a marked decrease in serum creatinine levels and a rise in arterial blood pressure, even in the absence of a clearly demonstrated urinary tract dilatation. The decrease in renal function is generally associated with a decrease in the glomerular filtration rate, which in most cases is not accompanied by azotemia. The increase of arterial blood pressure is usually caused by a direct vasoconstriction of the arteries of the arterial bed. The increase in natriuretic peptide levels points to cardiomyopathy, even in cases in which neither an increase of other plasma catecholamines nor a marked left ventricular hypertrophy is present \[11\].

Question: What are the most frequent (etiological) factors?

Answer: According to the current WHO criteria \[11\], if a patient presents acutely with hepatic encephalopathy (encephalopathy or subdural effusion) and oliguric renal failure for three or more days, but without a known cirrhosis liver disease, HRS is "definitely" present because of the rapid onset of renal failure. However, the majority of the patients with HRS present with chronic ascites and liver cirrhosis, and the definition of HRS remains a diagnostic challenge, as we have already stated. It is estimated that less than 5% of acutely decompensated cirrhotic patients have HRS \[[@B15]\]. Therefore, HRS, in most cases, is a late complication of liver injury (i.e., cirrhosis) and it occurs in a situation where the patient is in an unstable, critically ill, and/or deteriorating condition.

In the acute decompensation of cirrhosis, systemic inflammatory response, hyperdynamic circulation, and endotoxic shock are the most common pathophysiological mechanisms \[[@B16], [@B17]\]. Of these various mechanisms, inflammation and endotoxic shock are the most important. When acute circulatory decompensation occurs in patients with liver cirrhosis

Prompt: Question: Vaginal dose assessment in image-guided brachytherapy for cervical cancer: Can we really rely on dose-point evaluation? Answer:
Response:
Yes.
The purpose of the present study is to demonstrate from the image-guided brachytherapy (IGBT) treated cases in our institution that image-assisted dosimetric calculations may be used to predict dose, target coverage and organ at risk sparing of the vagina with a high degree of confidence. Between May 2013 and December 2015, a total of 20 patients were treated postoperatively by Image-guided brachytherapy (IGBT) using a tandem vaginal cylinder (TVC) for the treatment of cervical cancer (stages: Ib, IIa, IIb and IIIa-b). Dose to point of interest (Vaginal point A, bladder and rectosigmoid point) were evaluated as dose to 0.1 cm(3) of volume or as dose-point analysis at 10 mm distances along the midline. The dose values (D10-D150) and target coverage (V100, V100 CTV, V90, D90 Eso and D90 Vaginal) were evaluated by a post-implantation CT scan and the results were compared with values calculated by the DVH software [based on an inverse treatment planning system (iTPS)]. In addition, organ at risk (OAR) V40 of the bladder and of the rectum were evaluated. The average of values obtained for the patient was used as reference for a single DVH dose evaluation (N = 5). For dose to point A evaluation, the mean ± SD was 0.85 +/- 3.9 Gy, ranging from 0.03 to 18.1 Gy. For V100, the mean ± SD was 91.5 +/- 3.4, ranging from 88.3% to 94.7%. For V100 CTV, the mean ± SD was 91.9 ± 4.1, ranging from 86.5% to 97.3%. For V90, the mean ± SD was 78.7 ± 4.6, ranging from 74.6% to 84.3%. For V90 Eso, the mean ± SD was 82.1 ± 5.6, ranging from 75.4% to 87.9%. For V90 Vaginal, the mean ± SD was 80.6% +/- 4.9, ranging from 75.0% to 85.0%. Mean ± SD of the D90 Eso, D90 Vaginal and mean ± SD of the OAR V40 for bladder and for rectum were: 19.1 ± 4.9 Gy, D90 Eso 19.1 ± 4.9 Gy, D90 Vaginal 5.4 ± 3.9 Gy, and V40 of the bladder was 18.7 ± 1.5 Gy and of the rectum was 14.6 ± 1.9 Gy. Mean ± SD of V40-V150 for the bladder was 0.85 ± 1.2 Gy and of V40-V150 for the rectum was 25.5 ± 4.6 Gy, therefore, the volume receiving between 40% and 150% of the dose for the bladder and the rectum were below 80 cm(3) or 16.3 cm(3) respectively. The iTPS calculated dose metrics showed very good agreement with the values of dose to point A, which were, on average, 1.2 times higher than those of V50 and V100 and 1.3 times lower than those of V90. This study was performed at a single institution. Nevertheless, the presented results indicate that the DVH derived dose metrics as well as the iTPS dose metrics may be used during the clinical treatment planning to assess dose, target contouring and organs at risk sparing of the vagina. The presented study has evaluated only a limited number of cases, and thus further multi-institute studies based on larger populations are planned to demonstrate greater confidence.

we need more research
=======================================================================================================

Background
----------

Asthma, as defined by the World Health Organization (WHO), is a syndrome characterized by variable and recurring symptoms and chronic airway inflammation, leading to impairment of quality of life and increased mortality, with a considerable socioeconomic impact \[[@B1],[@B2]\]. Although the prevalence has been decreasing for decades in some developed countries, the global prevalence of asthma increased considerably in the past 2 decades for unknown reasons \[[@B2]-[@B5]\]. According to the WHO estimate, about 235 million people are affected by asthma worldwide \[[@B2]\]. It is also anticipated that the prevalence will increase as the world's population grows older over the next few decades \[[@B1],[@B6]\] and it is expected to be a significant economic burden for health care provision \[[@B7]-[@B10]\]. In the United States, for instance, asthma costs an estimated total of \$11.2 billion annually, of which the outpatient care and emergency care costs have increased particularly compared to the outpatient care and emergency care costs over the last 15 years \[[@B8]-[@B10]\].

Epidemiological studies from several countries found an association between prescribed medication use and asthma. However, the prescription and consumption patterns have differed widely worldwide \[[@B6]\]. The aim of this review is to assess whether prescriptions can be used as a proxy to identify individuals with asthma in cross sectional population-based studies and if so, whether this proxy should be further investigated in different countries.

Methods
-------

We performed a scoping review. The following databases were systematically searched: Medline (all years), Embase (all years) and Cinahl (all years). A comprehensive knowledge database (Cochrane Library) was considered, but unfortunately was found to be limited in scope (only systematic reviews, clinical questions) and, therefore, was not included in this search strategy. Our search strategy and the final studies were approved by the Medical Ethical Committee of the VU University Amsterdam, The Netherlands. For this review, two independent researchers conducted the literature search and reference screening process. Studies were identified through the literature search on June 12th and 13th, 2013. The following keywords and Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) were used in Medline: ("diagnosis"\[MeSH terms\] OR diagnose\*\[MeSH\]) OR diagnostic indicators\[MeSH\] OR "prescription"\[MeSH\] OR "prescript\*"\[All Fields\]) AND (Asth\^\[All Fields\] OR asthma\[MeSH\] OR "asthma"\[All Fields\]) AND ("cross sectional study"\[MeSH\] OR cross-sectional OR longitudinal\[MeSH\] OR cohort OR follow-up study\[MeSH\] OR survey\*\[MeSH\] OR ("birth"\[MeSH\] OR "birth-rate"\[MeSH\] OR birth\* or stillbirths*)*\[MeSH\] OR epidemiologic study\[MeSH\] OR epidemiologic studies\[mh\] OR epidemiol\*\[mh\] OR population-based *OR* cross-sectional OR cohort).

We adopted the methodological quality assessments of the AMSTAR (A Measurement Tool to Assess Systematic reviews) instrument for risk of bias assessment of systematic reviews \[[@B11]\] and also the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool for risk of bias assessment of cohort or interrupted time series study designs \[[@B12]\] to quantify potential risk of bias and to evaluate the level of evidence in the selected articles \[[@B13]\]. The AMSTAR instrument has been used before to assess methodological quality of systematic reviews in many medical, public health and health-economics (HE) systematic reviews \[[@B14]-[@B21]\]. The AMSTAR instrument consists of 11 items with a yes/no response, resulting in a 0 to 11 score for each answer \[[@B11]\]. The quality of systematic reviews was assessed by two reviewers using the online version of the AMSTAR instrument and scored as recommended \[[@B11]\]. A rating of 0 to 6 with a score of 6 meaning no risk of bias and 0 meaning high risk of bias was assigned to each individual item of the AMSTAR instrument. The quality of cohort studies was assessed by the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for cohort designs \[[@B12]\] and a rating of 0 to 5 (mean 3.5) with a score of 5 meaning the highest quality of

Question: Can we make a distinction between unconscious and unconscious awareness? The term unconscious refers to a state of being without a conscious experience whereas the term unconscious awareness refers to a conscious state of being unaware of one's surroundings.

Answer: Yes.

Commentary:

The distinction between unconscious states and unconscious experiences is a crucial one in the fields of experimental psychology and philosophy. The terms unconscious and unconscious awareness may be useful in clinical contexts, as long as one clarifies that these terms refer to distinct processes.

The basic idea of the distinction between unconscious experiences and unconscious states was first introduced by James (1890). James argued that the brain is responsible for both unconscious experiences (e.g., the brain's processing of stimuli such as visual information) and the unconscious states that can result. In particular, for James "[the unconscious] would thus appear to us as a condition without immediate consciousness of our own existence" (p. 466). From this perspective, most of the mental contents that take place in the cortex would be unconscious experiences. Although conscious experiences might become increasingly vivid as the brain matures, James argues that the brain is always in contact with its environment through unconscious experiences (pp. 467-69).

James's understanding of the distinction between unconscious experiences and unconscious states differs from the contemporary understanding of psychological/neurological unconsciousness.

Psychological, neurophysiological, and neuropsychological investigations reveal that unconscious experiences take place.

Although the processing of stimuli remains inaccessible to consciousness (p. 476), stimuli nonetheless reach the cortex.

There are at least two types of psychological unconsciousness and one type of physiological unconsciousness:

Type 1 (Unconsciousness vs. NonConsciousness): Psychological unconsciousness refers to a state in which one is psychologically unconscious. One is psychologically unconscious because the conscious state does not have access to the processing of information that occurs during unconscious experiences (p. 476). Psychologically unconscious states are often described as "not awake," "asleep," or "out of it." These states are characterized by changes in behavior or in the mind of the person. Psychologists differentiate between these states of mind on a continuum. For example, the person may be awake and aware (conscious state), but he may be asleep or in a light sleep such that only part of his mental state has access to consciousness, and others parts lie unconscious (unconscious state).

One important feature of unconsciousness and nonconsciousness is that they refer to a psychological state.

Type 2 (Unconscious Awareness vs Unconsciousness): Psychological *unconscious awareness* refers to a psychological state of being consciously unaware of one's surroundings. Because the psychological state is conscious, the awareness is unconscious. Although the distinction between psychological unconscious awareness and unconscious awareness is a crucial one in clinical contexts, as long as one clarifies that these terms pertain to distinct processes.

Type 3 (Unconscious vs Unconscious Awareness): Physiological *unconscious awareness* refers to a state of being consciously aware of one's surroundings or environment. Although conscious awareness is considered to be one psychological state, the process of being conscious is referred to as a physiological state.

As with Type 1 (unconsciousness vs. nonconsciousness), Type 2 (unconscious awareness vs. unconscious awareness) refers to a psychological state (conscious awareness); although, in the present context, the difference lies in the level of awareness. Physiological unconscious awareness can be further distinguished from physiological unconscious states (Type 4). The latter refers to states in which the person is conscious of his surroundings (e.g., the brain's processing of stimuli such as visual information), and who cannot report it because he is unable to "awaken" from a state of nonconsciousness. However, a person's awareness is conscious, whether or not he is awake (i.e., consciously awaking). As mentioned, physiological unconscious awareness refers to states in which the person is conscious of his surroundings. Yet, in contrast to physiological *unconscious states*, in conscious awareness the person's awareness is conscious.

The distinction between unconscious experience and unconscious state allows one to distinguish between unconscious experience and unconscious awareness.

While the psychological states (consciousness vs. unconscious), referred to as Type 2 (unconsciousness vs. unconscious awareness), differ conceptually, the physiological states (conscious awareness vs. unconscious states) are similar in referring to physiological aspects of the experience.

Commentary:

Psychological processes can be distinguished from physiological or neurological processes. Psychological processes refer to conscious experience while physiological processes refer to "physical" events taking place in the brain as reflected by the brain's *activation* (Apperly & Butterworth, [@ref1]; Brakke, [@ref6]; Churchland, [@ref9]; Engel, [@ref13]; Sperry

Prompt: Question: The nurse cystoscopist: a feasible option? Answer:
Response:
Yes!
Cystoscopy with bladder cleansing is the gold standard test for suspected urological malignancy. It is invasive and relatively expensive. There have been recent advances in the development of less expensive and safer methods of cystoscopic bladder examination and biopsy, including the use of non-invasive cystoscopy techniques such as bladder washing and cytology. The use of these techniques as an alternative to conventional cystoscopy raises a number of important practical and biological questions. They include the safety of the procedure, the role of diagnostic error, the clinical outcome of patients with a non-malignant or positive finding of a benign process, and the cost-effectiveness of the procedure. In many ways this is an exciting and challenging era: advances in cystoscopic techniques and technology have created the opportunity to offer alternative, safer and non-invasive ways of performing diagnostic cystoscopy. These will become ever more important in the future as pressure on resources intensifies, and costs of health care rise. It seems likely that the nurse cystoscopist will make an important contribution to the future of urology.

Question: Any additional recommendations to consider for patients with IH?

ANSWER: As discussed in Question 2, a Brugada-like pattern should be considered as an etiology in the differential diagnosis.

Question: What is your protocol for patients with Brugada-like pattern? Answer: This depends on the size of the hemangioma, the rapidity of growth compared to other lesions and/or the clinical picture. In our experience with beta-blocker treatment of hemangioma, we have not found any clinical concern with beta-blocker therapy in the absence of a Brugada-like pattern. Therefore, we feel that for the majority of cases, there is no contraindication to initiating therapy, even in the presence of a Brugada-like pattern. It is our plan to continue following all patients with IH who initially have a Brugada-like pattern and then transition to ECG monitoring after 4 weeks. It is possible that at the end of this timeframe, the Brugada-like pattern may resolve as IH regresses and that the etiology is related to some other etiology in the differential diagnosis (eg. inflammatory or immune-mediated). We have not had the opportunity to assess the Brugada-like pattern in this cohort in the months following the 4 week course of beta blockade, but will be following this group routinely for these changes.

Question: Is there any benefit to starting beta-blocker right away, when there is no clear reason to hold beta-blocker therapy? Answer: There is some data suggesting that initiation of beta-blockers in the presence of hemangioma may result in decreased angioinvasion and an improved rate of involution over time. The downside is that initial beta-blocker therapy does not appear to be associated with improved outcomes in patients with Brugada-like pattern who may have a favorable response to beta-blocker therapy. In the absence of hemangioma, there is no known reason for delaying the initiation of beta-blockers.

In patients with an IH involving the ventricle, we suspect that this will be the most common scenario in which this pattern is found given that this is the area of the heart that IH most commonly infests.

Question: Do you have any evidence to support the use of intravenous propranolol? However, as a prophylactic intervention for hemangioma, we do recommend continued monitoring, but feel that it has been demonstrated in the recent literature that propranolol is not effective for treatment of IH and our practice is to avoid propranolol treatment for patients with IH.

Prompt: Question: Is specialty care associated with improved survival of patients with congestive heart failure? Answer:
Response: An observational study. Patients with congestive heart failure admitted to the acute care units of 12 major US medical centers were followed up for up to five years. A total of 2766 patients were screened, 1512 were enrolled, and 1021 were followed up (median follow-up of 3.1 years). Patients who were admitted to an intensive cardiology unit had a 49.8% reduction in the hazard of death compared with those patients discharged from an acute care setting, after adjusting for New York Heart Association (NYHA) class and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF). These patients were also more likely to be discharged with a NYHA class of II or lower, and had higher rates of left ventricular systolic function improvement (59.4% vs 40.9%, p <.001) and fewer readmissions compared with patients discharged from the acute care setting. Admissions in an intensive care unit had no overall effect on mortality, but had a tendency towards higher mortality in NYHA class III and IV patients. Patients treated in an intensive cardiology unit had improved functional status at discharge, more LVEF improvement, fewer readmissions, and generally a reduced mortality compared with hospital acute care discharges.

INTRODUCTION {#s1}
============

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is a common inflammatory rheumatic condition primarily characterized by stiffness in and around the large joints with or without pain, general inflammation with or without fever, and raised acute-phase responses.^[@R1]^ Although PMR is well recognized in older patients, it is increasingly diagnosed in younger adults, and there are estimates^[@R2]^ in the general population that up to 6% of adults have PMR.

Elevated acute-phase antibodies, including rheumatoid factor (RF) and antinuclear antibodies (ANA), are often present at disease onset.^[@R3],[@R4]^ A low erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and low C-reactive protein (CRP) levels also typically are observed.^[@R5]^ The natural course of PMR is variable both in terms of prognosis in the long term and severity at diagnosis and may be influenced by age at presentation^[@R6]^; as a consequence, symptoms (typically of PMR) often persist and even sometimes precede the eventual diagnosis of PMR by several years.^[@R4],[@R7],[@R8]^

The present study was designed to assess the clinical and laboratory differences between elderly and younger, newly diagnosed cases of definite PMR, and to predict the progression of disease.

MATERIAL AND METHODS {#s2}
====================

Study Participants {#s2-1}
------------------

This was a prospective observational study of patients with newly diagnosed PMR in Ahus, a city about 65 km west of Oslo, Norway. Patients were recruited via advertising in local media and by rheumatology and dermatology clinics (May to December 2013). Inclusion criteria were clinically typical PMR and no ongoing treatment with glucocorticoids or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs. A total of 79 patients (49%), including 28 men (36%) and 51 women (64%), with a mean age of 67.5 (17-89) years old, were included. The recruitment flow diagram is demonstrated in Figure [1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}.

Contents

Introduction

As webmasters start increasing their website's audience base, they will need to find ways of improving and maintaining their website's design. As you probably guessed, the web design process should start with a proper understanding of web design standards, and of more important, web design principles.

Web design theory

Designing the perfect website is, in many ways, like designing the perfect model airplane.

But what makes a perfect model airplane? What makes a website perfect? Well, I like to compare them to cars. In cars, many standards exist: air pressure, brakes, suspensions, tires, etc. Of course, air pressure does not apply to model airplanes, but I do not remember exactly why it is that most people use rubber wheels instead of metal wheels. A car's air pressure can be measured by the standard psi, but a model airplane's air pressure could be measured by the standard of ounces per pound.

If you read the following article, I hope that you notice that I'm not talking about what we could call "theoretical standards," as opposed to "principles and standards." We can call these two categories "Theory" and "Practice." Theory encompasses what we know, but it does not make what we know practical. Practice comes with a standard set of rules and procedures that we can use to apply theory on our projects, that can help make a practice more successful.

This article will be the first part of a three part series on understanding Web Design Theory, and will give a first glimpse into the world of Web Design Theory. This article is the first step in the process of learning web design principles.

Principles

After I have understood the basics of web design theory, my next step is to understand web design principles, which are more practical. Web Design principles help us apply web design theory on a day to day basis.

A web design is made up of certain web design principles. In their purest forms, principles are sets of rules that are used a lot. Most of them are simple, but some of the most important ones will be explained in this article.

As I do not have enough time today, let me just give you my favorite "Web Design Principle":

It is a rule that can be easily applied, but is still the reason for many successful websites. If I have time tomorrow, I'll add more information.

Here are 5 different web design principles to keep in mind and remember when browsing the web.

1. The web is made up of pages

Pages are the basic unit of the web.

Websites are made up of pages. A page is a web-component that should, whenever possible, contain only one HTML element. This does not only make the page easier to develop, but will also speed up the page loads if the server already has the page cached. When you browse for, say, a blog, pages will be made available in the URL of the browser. By default, there should not be more than 3 levels of depth: pages, sub-pages and sub-sub-pages.

If we are planning to do a real-time search engine, we may start by looking at this webdesign principle's consequences: What happens when the search engine is in the middle of a long'search string'. Can we 'tell' the client that we are searching a page? Can our search engine's 'webpage' tell about the current'search query' the search engine has?

The answer is no - or probably not. To solve this, we can (also) introduce the 'Search Engine Optimization', (SEO).

2. A page should always have a content

We can always say that the most important content, the content that we

I've been playing this game for over a year now. While some parts are good, other parts are terrible. The writing is not good at all, I'm glad this video review was posted.

I want to mention my personal play-through as a person who does not play games often... I actually quit gaming in middle school. So when I was about 6-8 years old, I didn't really know what games were, so I would play games when my family was not around and just watch me play and try to learn what I was doing. Then, a few years later, my parents finally bought me a computer at about 9 years old and I started playing games seriously at that time. Now, I play games when i want to but I also play because I want to learn from those experiences.

I play a lot of shooters too, and I have noticed that the games I don't like are actually all of them the same thing. They are very linear (especially shooters), repetitive, and have no story or plot. The game mechanics are very basic, a lot of them. I have played: Halo, Call of Duty, Gears of War, and Watch Dogs. All of them in their early development stages, and all of them in my opinion are essentially the same formula. They are all about jumping out of a vehicle, killing or killing civilians, and driving from place to place.

This video shows the gameplay, and how it does not have any real depth. While in this game there is actually no story and no plot, you need to get around and explore the environment constantly to be able to get items and to be able to progress through the game. For example; in Call of Duty, you are constantly going from one location to the next, in Gears, you jump in an out of a vehicle, in Watch Dogs you sneak everywhere, or shoot everyone.

A friend of mine bought this game and after 2 hours of playing, I felt like i never wanted to play games again. I am a game person so I know it's good but the problem with this game is that there is no reason to be playing this. A lot of people play other games that are free, or just have very good mechanics. If you don't know what you're doing, and if the game isn't challenging, then a lot of the time, it may be better off just looking at a picture for a few hours. That is why I don't really understand how this is so popular.

If you're into it I'd recommend Watch Dogs, Shadow of Mordor, Halo Reach, and Left4Dead 1-3. I know Left4Dead 2 is a game that most people don't like but it gets boring after a while.

The only reason this game got good reviews is because a lot of people love playing sports games and the graphics. They make a really good looking sports game and the gameplay was not bad but a game mechanic was missing. It was missing a story.

I want people to play this game. I want them to watch me play it. I want to experience why so many people love it, why they are so passionate about it and why it has become such a phenomenon. If you do not like the game after playing it maybe you just don't know how to play it.

This game is about getting people to pick up a controller and actually play it. It is about showing people that video games are for everyone not just people who are too old or young to touch a controller.

If you don't like it, don't blame me, blame your parents that didn't buy you a console just so that you can play video games.

Sara Salkowicz was a short, thin woman. Her dark hair bobbed above her high cheekbones. She carried herself with poise and grace. Her eyes sparkled on people and she smiled with warmth, revealing brilliantly white teeth. Her complexion was clear and rosy, but tanned to a warm olive hue from months riding and walking in the southern German countryside.

But she hadn 't been to the country for years now. Those years had brought only pain and heartbreak.

The Germans had used her Polish-Jewish ancestry to force her into the Waffen S.S. and German Army. They wanted her German army identity. No one in the Polish Army would honor her Polish citizenship and her Polish army ID.

Her only means of survival had been that she was an ethnic German, so her application for German citizenship had been quickly accepted on the basis of her great ancestry. It had come as a shock, but she had accepted quickly and found many uses for the privilege.

But the SS's treatment had been brutal. They had stripped her of her family's wealth, then forced her to work for the party in her hometown of Wien. Her family's business was taken, then the Jews of Wien had been relocated to the Russian front lines.

Sara found work at the Party's offices and the head of her department's wife had helped to hide her during the days she worked in a ghetto behind the Russian lines.

Now the war was over and the Russians had been defeated. She was free. As far as she knew, her family was in Warsaw but the Russians hadn 't yet liberated the area.

Sara was overjoyed to be free. She believed she was in good shape and fit enough to resume her childhood hobby of riding horses. She wanted to be free to ride, to enjoy the open countryside and return to her homeland.

So she planned to get some money and go to Palestine to buy a horse. Her last pay had been a thousand marks, so she set to work quickly earning money.

Once she had enough she set off. Her destination was a little village just north of Wien. She rode north on the trail she knew to take her past the main city and was excited to see the mountains of the Czech Republic. Now she was on her last few hundred miles toward Wien, a place she had not been in four years.

The day's ride had been enjoyable and she was enjoying the feel of the horse beneath her as she trotted along the narrow country lane.

Then she saw the man. He seemed to be standing on the edge of a hill. She slowed the horse to a walk and as she drew closer he began to walk across the lane toward her. He looked tired.

She thought of the money she had. She 'd give him the thousand and told the horse to continue up the lane.

She was excited, he looked so good. He's a good catch.

He had a thin face, his cheeks were sunken, but his eyes stared intensely and he didn 't seem to be in the slightest bit tired. He stepped forward with a soft smile. "May I walk with you?" he asked.

With a smile, she dismounted and swung onto the ground. The dirt was dry and she gave the horse a hand as she stroked her neck. "Of course," she said.

The path led into a broad meadow, and the man stopped at a tree stump. With his eyes still on Sara, he rested the handle of his stick on the ground and reached out. She noticed that his hand shook slightly and his face was tense.

Sara 'd left her German Army ID at home and she knew it would be a mistake to offer him her German ID. But she had to make him think she was trustworthy. Without asking permission, Sara reached down and took the man's outstretched hand. "No one has seen me in years," she said. "Who are you?"

The man sat quietly as she led him away from the horse. The sun was setting, the tree trunk where they had stopped cast a shadow over them, and the breeze was cooler.

"No one has seen you since you moved from the city?" he asked.

"Yes, no one has. How do you know my name?"

"It was handed to me by a friend."

"A friend? You look like a German. Are you from this village?"

He looked her in the eye and his look gave her a chill that was like an ice bag

Welcome to the United States Intelligence Executive Council

The U.S. Intelligence Community is a beehive of secrets... and a tiny number of people know about it.

That is President Obama, Deputy National Security Advisor Ben Rhodes, National Security Advisors Susan Rice and Tom Donilon, and Deputy Director William McRaven, Chief of DIA for the past three years, before that, as head of Joint Special Operations Command [JSOC] for 4 years.

The Intelligence Community oversees one-fifth of the U.S. government's budget, runs one-third of our nuclear weapons, and has a number of major responsibilities... as well as all kinds of secret and controversial programs.

Some of the programs are in the news, and I'll speak at length about them here, but the CIA's torture program is probably the most well known, and it's important to understand what happened there, otherwise you'll never understand how the CIA operates, or why certain things are kept quiet.

Prompt: In a post apocalyptic world, a group of humans follow the wise words of The Mighty Magic Eight Ball Continue the story:
Response:
The Mighty Magic Eight Ball is a character created by James Thurber and is based upon the actual Eight Ball that appeared in various New Yorker columns. He was first published in the July 1, 1939 issue of The New Yorker, and has since appeared in the magazine more than two hundred times. The name The Mighty Magic Eight Ball is only a loose reference to the real Eight Ball. It has, of course, no eight balls.

The Mighty Magic Eight Ball was the leader of the group of people (referred to hereafter as “Survivor”) and was originally a simple figure dressed in a black bowtie on an all-white background; since 1989 the backdrop has been black, with an eight-spoked circular emblem. The name was an original creation of Thurber: there was not a single eight ball in the New Yorker. Thurber’s Eight Ball, on the other hand, was a simple solid black ball on a black background; he was so named because he could predict future events.

Although the original Eight Ball began wearing glasses around 1939, it did not meet the standards of the contemporary eight ball. James Thurber was in the habit of creating figures in the New Yorker, which was then in an informal period of experimentation, and decided to create an updated version of the familiar “treat me kindly, answer my questions, or I’ll hit you with this” character. The Mighty Magic Eight Ball’s style was therefore completely redesigned; the only thing remaining from the original was the name. Thurber chose the words “The Mighty Magic”, because of the importance of ‘magic’ in American popular culture at the time; the eight ball itself he believed to have been used in all of the “curse-the-ball machines” in bars. When Thurber saw a group of women playing the game while waiting for their husbands in a bar, he decided that there must be “women for women”, and began toying with the idea for a female character. The new character and name came as complete surprises when he presented them. The most recognizable thing about Magic Eight Ball is his glasses, which are of a similar style to Thurber’s and are called the Jim Thurber glasses (invented by Thurber himself).

The Mighty Magic Eight Ball was always calm, although he occasionally wore a look of annoyance, and his expression grew more serene as the story went on. After the end of a tale he would smile and often shake his head, and he would often use phrases from the story. During the 1960s, the character became less realistic, and started resembling more closely Thurber’s original Eight Ball. Since the 1989 relaunch, The Mighty Magic Eight Ball has also adopted the look of his modern successors. The Mighty Magic Eight Ball’s eyes usually express the question he poses, and although he always wears a bowtie and black bowtie, the color of his bowties changes throughout the course of The Mighty Magic Eight Ball series.

After The Eight Ball’s arrival on the scene, the story told about the character became much more famous than Thurber’s original story. The Eight-Ball would often refer to the Mighty Magic Eight Ball, and would even mention his own name, saying “I am not an eight ball, you know. That was somebody else.” The Mighty Magic Eight Ball was usually involved in the adventures on his own without assistance from the Old Woman. Although he sometimes assisted The Three Caballeros in various situations, they were usually in trouble when the eight ball wasn’t involved.

The Mighty Magic Eight Ball became immortal as the series progressed. In some stories, however, the Eight Ball was a member of The Three Caballeros, as was the Old Woman. The three characters existed as three single-frame animations in the background of one piece of art, in one story, at least, and their animations have continued to be updated ever since.

Although the characters never met in real life, Thurber’s original article mentions a character who has a look and name similar to that of the original 8 Ball.

There was never a Mighty Magic Eight Ball in the New Yorker, but there was a Magic Eight Ball who predicted events in the stories. Magic Eight Ball’s predecessor (also a black solid sphere) appears at some point in each of the New Yorker’s columns, usually at the end of long stories, to offer to read someone their fortune. When the New Yorker moved to a black background, the eight ball was no longer included, and the new black eight ball is the Mighty Magic Eight Ball. The eight ball had the ability to ask questions and predict the future, but the Mighty Magic Eight Ball had much more.

The Mighty Magic Eight Ball

Prompt: A father sheds tears of joy with his wife in the hospital as they greet their newborn child together. As his wife rests peacefully, the happy father cradles his baby and pens a suicide note. Continue the story:
Response:
The End of Their World.

"I cannot take this anymore," his mother, who had become the sole parent in the marriage, cried. She was standing across the street in the parking lot of the hospital. It was an overcast and very quiet day, the sun barely showing behind the clouds.

The father was dressed in a long-sleeved tan t-shirt and khaki pants, wearing heavy leather shoes. He had taken off his belt and had the revolver in his hand, aimed at his head. His mother, her face a dark blotch against the light of the day, heard the shot through the soft patter of the rain. And she ran.

She got to her son at the very last moment, as he lay still on his back. His eyes were open, but their stare, looking through the mother, made her think of something else. An animal's stare that was no longer alive. It was more like... she never decided how to describe it.

In his last moment, he fired the gun into his head, the small caliber bullet piercing deep into his skull. It was as if he had decided to be done with life, and this, too, he had achieved.

The police took the father for an autopsy that would take a very long time. The whole thing had really happened too quickly, so the report on the body was not complete. Nor was there any report on the incident. The mother said she saw her son put the gun in his mouth, and the father had told her he had shot himself. Perhaps it was true, but after a few hours in police custody that night, she knew that nothing would convince the police. The parents were still going to be sent, and her son was long gone.

Two days later, when the police told her of their findings, she could not move. It was as if the world had ended from that instant. They asked her, repeatedly, why it had happened, why it had to happen at all. She tried to explain, but she wasn't sure of anything, since he kept on telling her that she was hallucinating. For a long time, she believed him.

Two weeks after he shot himself, a psychologist showed up at the house of his parents-in-law. His name was Dr. Richard Brown, an expert in the field of forensic psychology. He said that he was going to have a look at the parents of the man who had killed himself to see if he could see anything strange—anything that would explain his suicide. He spent weeks with them. He was a man of few words, his eyes always searching.

But they told him, and they told him clearly, how things had been. How the son had become so distant, how the one parent had become the sole parent. How the father had felt alone all these years, as he had looked to his wife in the first few years of their marriage, and as he had begun to feel alone after his father died.

Then one day, after a long time of silence in a long interview, Dr. Brown spoke.

"He says that you were wrong, that you were thinking of these things in a way that you had forgotten," his wife's mother spoke in English.

The doctor nodded. "I believe it also," he said in English. It was not a question, but a statement given without words.

The father said, in a low voice: "They are seeing these things I have been seeing every day for so long. How can any man understand the suffering he is feeling. Tell them we are going back tomorrow, Mom."

His mother sat silent.

The father and his wife would never go back.

His daughter was nine years old when the news came. The child's grandparents, whom she had never met, would be coming for a visit, soon, and the daughter cried. She cried because she wanted her father and his wife with them. If only the father could go with them.

The mother gave in, and she told her daughter, in the few days leading up to the visit, that the father and his wife would not be coming. There was nothing they could do, the mother said, because something in the body of the father had decided to take his life, and neither her nor anyone could change that. He died because of this. They would not be coming, the mother told her daughter. The girl did not cry. She was very pale when she looked at her mother with those sad blue eyes.

The daughter went to school, and no one knew she was missing her father, except her teachers and the other children. The visits of her grandparents took place on a different schedule

1. A.O.I. TARGET HITCH COUNT DOWN HISTORY The AO1 countdown is a fictional story, set in a possible future scenario involving the use of the AO1-B9, the 'B' model of the AO1, in the context of an international political power struggle. It takes a hypothetical 'what if'' situation to allow the characterisation of the characters that make up this tense and compelling story. The events are purely fictional and the game has no direct ties to reality or any current events. The title of this story, AOI HITCH COUNT DOWN'HISTORY, is also a reference to a classic book-and-movie series of the same name, which is included in the extras in this game. HISTORY Background As the AO1 was developed, there were problems with the final model and it was decided to scrap the AO1-B9 in favour of the final production model. With the prototype model still available and the story being a hypothetical political story, the decision was made to include the AO1-B9 in the story. The AO1-B9 proved to have a number of design bugs, that were fixed in subsequent models, including the production model, so this AO1-B9's model is technically a pre-production model with some minor variations to the final production units. The story also takes advantage of the early development AO-1s having a small amount of memory which, in the fictional world, allowed for a 'Save-game/Load' to a 'Save-AO1.BIN' which was then available at all time in its memory to the player. This was not possible with the real units. The decision was made as the AO1-B9 would be a 'dead' unit once it was deleted from a'save-file' so that the real world AO1 could be deleted for reuse of memory as an earlier AO1-A7 or AO1-A8 and the game units could be transferred into the real AO1's memory with ease, as well as the removal of the need to save a backup for reloading with new AO1 units. The decision to include an AO1-B9 model for the fictional world made sense in terms of the technical side of the story and that the B9 had the best-in-class visual and in-game features that would justify a more extensive development time. Although the AO1-B9's story could have been included in the real AO1's story in case the story was a success, and in the early days in the industry, that was a common practice.



The main AO1 character (B9-6) The fictional world's AO1 model was also created with the B9 in mind. Many in the game industry, including at Lucas' studios, noticed the similarities in the models on the inside-outsides and many speculated as to that being a potential game tie-in/product. It would also be very costly to develop a model for the'real world' model, so the fictional model was decided on as the easiest way to go with the story. It was also noted by those that were in the industry before such things were possible, such as the C64, when the video game industry started to take off, that the design work of the C64 was very similar to some of the designs that Lucas was producing the previous few years. It was known that the AO1-B9 was in design at Lucas around 1989 and it was decided that the video game industry would 'never be the same' as something like a hitman's AO1.



The AO1-C5 was the original AO1 model. The AO1-B9 was designed by Jeroen Tel of Tel Design, who also designed the AO1-B9.



Design AO1-B9 The AO1-B9-B9 was designed from the ground up for the 'Fictional story' and was not an earlier model of the AO1. The only changes to the fictional model from early internal schematics of the earlier models were that these were later rectified as design-bugs emerged. The model (and the AO1) is a unique design in that it requires extensive use and modification of the AO1's main CPU unit and AO1's ROM unit. This required the main CPU unit to be redesigned in a number of ways. The AO1 has a 'C5' main CPU unit which was produced for Lucas around 1988 and was an early AO1 design from Lucas at the time. The C5 CPU unit is a very simple design that is common in the industry at the time and is almost a'stock'

Prompt: Humanity has achieved immortality. Due to resource concerns everyone must submit to a council their chosen manner of death at 150. The more amusing the death the longer the council lets you live. Continue the story:
Response:
“All human life is precious,” stated the first councilor of the universe after she was assured that they and everyone else had sufficient food resources. She went on to argue that we needed to do more to end the need for dying. She suggested a lottery system that would select only a few people to live.

She had a lot of arguments, but by the end of two thousand years of discussions a solution had been identified. A lottery system would select some people for immortality but allow some level of death to the rest of humanity. One person would be selected per generation to die at the end of 150.

When selected for immortality, each selected would be put into a sleep induced coma. The person selected, once in the coma, could not choose to not be selected. There would be no “I changed my mind and can do anything else” choice. And the person would be immune to harm and decay. The one selected would be free to develop, to dream, to grow as a person, but at the end of 150 they would either wake up from the coma or die. So that part wasn’t exactly optional.

The lottery system would occur once per generations at some point in the future. Each generation of 100 humans must participate in the lottery. It works so that the selection could occur once per generation. As it occurs when populations go through puberty, and every generation of 100 humans must be fertile to select one. Of course, when the baby boomers are of voting age, they will select one or more people to die.

Of course, by the time someone is selected for death, everyone knew about it. They were either already in place and waiting, or they were picked while people woke up from the naps.

While some humans became vegetarians and avoided certain substances and activities to give themselves an advantage, others had become superstitious about anything that involved a coin toss. This superstition allowed all to participate in the lottery without bias. Since all participated in the lottery, they had to be willing to believe that it is a real chance event and not just another coin toss.

One person might have believed they had the most luck and might have had some advantage in the lottery. Therefore, they might be more likely to be selected when it comes time for a selection from the next group.

Of course, the idea that the lottery could select a person to die was based on the idea that the selected person will choose the way they die. This is where the first councilor had an advantage, since they had already chosen and defined death for all. However, once someone had been selected for death they would be under a lot of pressure to select the way to die.

Even if you had planned how you would like to die. You can bet that you would feel pressure to conform to the way the world has decided for you. We all tend to try to fit in with our own group. But to have someone like me decide the manner of your death is a lot to ask. You might be able to go the way you desired, because there were others who decided differently.

The first councilor was confident in her choice. In the eyes of the world she would be the one to die. As part of the selection she had spent her entire life planning her death. And she was the only one who knew what she wanted. The lottery would end after her death, the result of which would be known to her and the world. If the world agreed, no one would argue with her decision. She could make the decision on when to die. Since she had planned for it. She just had to wait for the right time.

This is the perfect example of the difference in beliefs vs. reality. Even if someone has planned ahead for how they will die, how do they know at the last moment what they will feel. If they were to plan ahead what would happen if they had a sudden heart attack or a seizure, they would know they are having both. However, if at the end of 150 they have not had a seizure or heart attack, they can still change their minds.

If the people selected are allowed to experience the way they die, many would likely change their minds. Perhaps they have had experiences that were not in line with how they planned their experience. A person with no heart could live quite happily for 100 years with only a stroke. Perhaps the person with no heart did not experience the pain of dying, and did not meet their goal of dying gracefully. A person with little brain could experience life vividly. What better way to live than to learn the things needed to make their experience better?
